articles.headline: Untitled Snippet
articles.full_text: [Communicated] . The commissioners of Clarendon Model School are to be congratulated on the success of their school during the past year. At the Government examinations last June the Mod- el school presented 23 pupils of whom all pas- sed. From the report of J. M. [Harper, Inspec- tor of Superior Schools, which is to be found in the Educational Record for October, we find that Clarendon surpassed Aylmer, Bry- son and Portage du Fort in the percentage for each pupil, and in appliances and specimens of work. The percentage for each pupil in Clarendon was seventy-nine per cent for ap- pliances and specimens of work 665 marks, whereas Aylmer, Bryson and Portage du Fort came below six-one per cent. for each pupil, and below 530 marks for appliances and speci- mens of work. Clarendon took the highest percentage in the province for each pupil ex- cept Bolton 83 per cent. and the highest marks for appliances and specimens of work except Waterville, 690 marks. The last meeting of the Council of Public Instruction voted a bon- us of $75 to the model school. We are grati- fied to learn that the past year has been one of marked success. We congratulate the com- missioners upon the excellent results both in the financial statement and in the examina- tions and heartily recommend the model school to the people of the county. 图: 12 · 自己的 12 · 自己的 12 · 自己的 12 · 自己的 12 · 自己的 12 · 自己的 12 · 自己的 12 · 自己的 12 · 自己的 12 · 自己的 12 · 自己的 12 · 自己的 12 · 自己的 12 · 自己的 12 · 自己的 12 · 自己的 12 · 自己的 12 · 自己的 12 · 自己的 12 · 自己的 12 · 自己的 12 · 自己的 12 · 自己的 12 · 自己的 12

articles.full_text: EL EC Is it True? the The Pembroke Observer states that Mr. P. was Fitzpatrick, while up exploring the timbered nary lands recently offered for sale by the Quebec erv Government, found where a raft of timber had and spel. been taken off Government land, and had rom never been reported. Our cotem, adds that for this does not speak well for Quebec bush- ras. rangers, which indeed it does not, if the facts to are correctly reported. But Mr. Fitzpatrick elo. | may have based his conclusions in regard to the matter upon evidence which was not rs of thoroughly authentic. The men who hold the not positions upon which this rather discreditable ning reflection is cast, have always been regarded ear- -so far as we know-as painstaking and thoroughly efficient officers, against whom ices no charges of dereliction of duty have before al- been brought. In the face of this it does seem the strange that Mr. Fitzpatrick has discovered a case of such wanton negligence as that he represents. It would be interesting to hear the other side of the story, and we doubt not ath when the matter comes to the notice of the ort. officers whose duty it is to look after the ter- on- ritory recently visited by Mr. Fitzpatrick. the they will be in a position to gratify the public rly on that score. 118- me- Eryson Bubbles. vas On Wednesday last the Registry office was est removed from itsold stand in the town hall. to more commodious and comfortable quart- ers rented for it in the Clifton House. Mr. James McLean had the contract for remov- ing the ponderous sales and office furniture. eet and so well did he superintend and direct the efforts of his boy assistants that on the even- er. ing of the same day everything was located ace and in order for the Registrar to resume the rn- duties of his office the following morning. The Registrar, Mr. Rimer, expresses himself tit as being very well saushed with the arrange- or- ments made, as he will be very much more he comfortable now than in the dilapidated old ruin he has abandoned. ost A free fight was indulged in a few nights nat since, at one of our hotels, by some of our local celebrities. Stones seem to have been used to better advantage than fists, as some of the parties received stone cuts about the head. P. Friday evening last was the occasion of a large assemblage of our young folks at the es- residence of Mr. G. D. Porteous, when a silver ir- cake basket and address were presented to Ic- | Miss Wright on behalf of her Sabbath School class. Miss Wright has been in our midst for B. over a year, and by her kind heartedness and he lady-like demeanor during that time has won the esteem and good will of all who have had at thep'easure of her acquaintance. As the time 8i- for her return to her home in Montreal is ap- proaching, the members of her Sabbath School n class took this means of expressing their ap- preciation of her assiduous efforts as their teacher. She will be much missed by all when she leaves. Mr. James Moore is having the interior of P. the new addition of his residence plastered. Messrs. Clarke & Pattison's stove foundry is r- turning out nine stoves every week. The de- n- ne | mand is equal to the supply. X. Y. Z. in last week's 'Advance,' touched K, x- upon a project that must commend itself to ld | every resident of Bryson, and to all who ever to | have occasion to enter our town from above. t- The hill known as 'Scott's hill' has to have a ts large amount of labor expended on it every d | year by the Litchfield Council-1 believe en- d ough to construct one-fifth of the road round ot | the hill by the river; so that the amount of y labor expended on said hill in five years would build a good road around, which, after being constructed, would require but very triffing y repairs annually. The project should receive the hearty co-operation of the municipal councils of township Litchfield and Bryson, and the suggestions of X. Y. Z. be acted upon, as the construction of such a road would greatly facilitate ingress and egress to and from this town, and eventually lessen the of statute labor now borne by Le | Datacu or presente responsation source of the y, municipality of Litchfield. Mr. Thomas Marshall, late book-keeper for ne Mr.C. Turpain, is conspicuous by his absence. d he having left here last Wednesday. Mr. Rogers, accountant, of Montreal, is in y town in connection with the business of Mr. E. B. D. Leffeur, of Mr. Robert Bryson, of Almonte, is in town on business. n A very successful missionary meeting was o | held in connection with the Methodist church here on Wednesday evening last. Rev. Mr. Walker occupied the chair, and after a few in- o troductory remarks with regard to the na- n ture of the meeting, called on the Rev. Mr. Irving, of Portage-du-Fort. Mr. Irving spoke at some length and strongly urged upon the people the necessity of giving liberally for the advancement of missionary cause and missionary effort. The choir were then called 5 on for some music which they rendered in their usual excellent style, after which Mr. Wright, a student from Shawville, addressed the meeting. Collectors for the ensuing year were then appointed, and a unanimous vote of thanks tendered Misses N. Smith and Car- rie McDonald for the efficient manner in which they had carried out the work last year. The meeting was then brought to a close. Mr. George Carswell of Calumet Island was in town over Sunday, having returned from a business trip to Montreal, on Saturday night last. Miss Emma M. Hurdman of Eardley, is visiting her sister, Mrs. R. McC. Ritchie at the Forest House.

articles.headline: RELATED BY THE GOVERNOR.
articles.full_text: RELATED BY THE GOVERNOR. Martyrs to gout know, by sad experience, that they suffer under one of the most capri- cious of maladies. An attack of this dis- ease will shift, in the most unaccountable manner, from one part of the body to an- other; or it will release the victim when there is every reason to fear that it is about to strengthen its hold on him; or, having shown the fairest promise of submitting to medical treatment, it will cruelly lay the matient prostrate again in a state of relapse. Adverse fortune, in my case, subjected me to this last and worst trial of endurance. Two months passed-months of pain aggra- vated by anxiety-before I was able to help Eunice and Miss Jillgall personally with my sympathy and advice. During this interval I heard regularly from the friendly and faithful Selina. Terror and suspense, courageously endured day after day, seem to have broken down her resistance, poor soul, when Eunice's good name and Eunice's tranquility were threatened by the most infamous of false ac- cusations. From that time Miss Jillgall's method of expressing herself betrayed a gra- dual deterioration. I shall avoid presenting at a disadvantage a correspondent who has claims on my gratitude if I give the sub- stance only of what she wrote-assisted by a ma while the newspapers which she sent to me, while the legal proceedings were in progress. Honest indignation does sometimes coun- sel us wisely. When the doctor left Miss Jillgall in anger and in haste he determined on taking the course from which, as a hu- mane man and a faithful friend, he had hitherto recoiled. It was no time to shrink from the prospect of an exposure. The one hope of successfully encountering the vin- dictive wickedness of Helena lay in the resolution to be before hand with her in the appeal to the magistrates with which she had threatened Eunice and Miss Jillgall. The doctor's sworn information stated the whole terrible case of the poisoning, ranging from his first suspicions and their confirm- ation to Helena's atrocious attempt to accuse her innocent sister of her own guilt. So firmly were the magistrates convinced of the serious nature of the case thus stated that they did not hesitate to issue their warrant. Among the witnesses whose at- tendance was immediately secured by the legal adviser to whom the doctor applied were the farmer and his wife. Helena was arrested while she was dress. ing to go out. Her composure was not for for a moment disturbed. "I was on my way," she said coolly, "to make a statement before the justices. The sooner they hear what I have to say the better." The attempt of this shameless wretch to "turn the tables 'on poor Eunice-suggest- ed, as I afterwards discovered, by the record of family history which she quoted in her journal-was defeated with ease. The farm- er and his wife proved the date at which Eunice had left her place of residence under as followed their roof. The doctor's evidence followed. He proved by the production of his profes- sional diary, that the discovery of the at- tempt to poison his patient had taken place before the day of Eunice's departure from the arm, and that the first improvements in Mr. Philip Dunboyne's state of health had shown itself after that young lady's arrival to perform the duties of a nurse. To the wise precautions which she had taken- perverted by Helena to the purpose of a false accusation—the doctor attributed the preservation of the young man's life. Having produced the worst possible im- pression on the minds of the magistrates, Helena was remanded. Her legal adviser had predicted this result; but the vindictive obstinacy of his client set both experience and remonstrance at defiance. At the renewed examination the line of de- fense adopted by the prisoner's lawyer prov- ed to be-mistaken identity. It was asserted that she had never enter- ed the chemist's shop; also, that the assist- ant had wrongly identified some other lady as Miss Helena Gracedieu; also, that there was not an atom of evidence to connect her with the stealing of the doctor's prescription paper and the forgery of his writing. Other assertions to the same purpose followed, on which it is needless to dwell. The case for the prosecution was, happily, in competent hands. With the exception of one witness, cross-examination afforded no material help to the evidence for the defense. The chemist swore positively to the per- sonal appearance of Helena as being the personal appearance of the lady who had presented the prescription. His assistant, pressed on the question of identity, broke down under cross examination-purposely, as it was whispered, serving the interest of the prisoner. But the victory so far gained by the defence was successfully contested by the statement of the next witness, a respectable tradesman in the town. He had seen the newspaper report of the first examination and had volunteered to present himself as a witness. A member of Mr. Gracedieu's congregation, his pew in the chapel was so situated as to give him a view of the minister's daughters occupying their pews. He had seen the prisoner on every Sunday for years past, and he swore that he was passing the door of the chemist's shop at the moment when she stepped out into the street, having a bottle covered with mary white paper in her hand.

articles.headline: THE CHRECITION I
articles.full_text: THE CHRECITION I The doctor and his servant were the next witnesses called. They were severely cross- examined. Some of their statements- questioned technically with success-receiv- ed unexpected and powerful support, due to the discovery and production of the prisoner's diary. The entries, guardedly as some of them were written, revealed her motive for attempting to poison Philip Dunbeyne; proved that she had purposely called on the doctor when she knew that he would be out, that she had entered the con- sulting room, had examined the medical books, had found (to use her own written words) "a volume that interested her," and had used the prescription paper for the purpose of making netes. The notes them- selves were not to be found; they had doubtless been destreyed. Hnough, and ake the

articles.headline: Untitled Snippet
articles.full_text: magistrates committed Helena Gracedieu for trial at the next assizes. arrived in the town, as well as I can re- member, about a week after the trial had taken place. Found guilty, the prisoner had been re- commended to mercy by the jury-partly in consideration of her youth, partly as an ex- pression of sympathy and respect for her unhappy father. The judge (a father him- self) passed a lenient sentence. She was condemned to imprisonment for two years. The careful matron of the jail had provided herself with a bott! . ot smelling salts in the fear that there might be need of it when Helena heard her sentence pronounced. Not the slightest sign of agitation appeared in her manner. She lied to the last, asserting in a firm voice and returned Der innocence in a min torce wire back to the prison without aid from any- body. My faithful corres pondent wrote these particulars to me in a state of great excite- ment, good Miss Jillgall hav ing a little confession of her own which served as a re- lief to my overburdened mind after what I had just heard. "I couldn't own it," she said, "to any. one but a dear friend. One thing, in the dreadful disgrace that has fallen on us, I am quite at a loss to account for. Think of Mr. Gracedieu's daughter being one of these criminal creatures on whom it was once your terrible duty to turn the key! Why didn't she commit suicide ?" creature ever yet committed suicide. Self- destruction, when it is not an act of mad- ness, implies some acuteness of feeling-sen- sibility to remorse or to shame, or prehaps, a distorted idea of making atonement, There is no such thing as remorse or shame or hope of making atonement in Helena's nature." "But when she comes out of prison what will she do? "Don't alarm yourself, my good friend. She will do very well." "Oh hush! hush! Poetical justice, Mr. Governor ?" " Poetical fiddlesticks, Miss Jillgall."

articles.full_text:
CHAPTER LXIII. When the subject of the trial was hap-
pily dismissed my inquiry related to Eunice.

articles.headline: THE LEDIA MOR HIGHE MILE
articles.full_text:
THE LEDIA MOR HIGHE MILE companiment of sighs and looks. Eunice had gone back to her duties as governess at the farm. Hearing this, I asked naturally what had become of Philip. Melancholy news, again, was the news that I now heard. Mr. Dunboyne the elder had died sud. denly at his house in Ireland, while Philip was on his way home. When the funeral ceremony had come to an end the will was read. It had been made only a few days before the testator's death, and the clause which left all his property to his son was preceded by expressions of paternal affection at a time when Philip was in sore need of consolation. After alluding to a letter re- ceived from his son, the old man added: "I always loved him without caring to con- fess it; I detest scenes of sentiment, kiss- ings, embracings, tears and that sort of thing. But Philip has yielded to my wishes and has broken off a marriage which would have made him, as well as me, wretched for life. After this I may speak my mind from my grave, and may tell my boy that I leved him. If the wish is likely to be of any use, I will add (on the chance) - God bless him." "Does Philip submit to separation from Eunice?' I asked. "Does he stay in Ire- land?" "Not he, poor fellow! He will be here to-morrow or next day. When I last wrote," Miss Jillgall continued, "I told him I hoped to see you again soon. If you can't help us (I mean with Eunice) that unlucky young man will do some desperate thing. He will join those mad-men at large who disturb poor savages in Africa or go nowhere to find nothing in the Arctic regions." form do Miss Tillwall shall " W natever I can do, miss dugan, shan be gladly done. Is it really possible that Eunice refuses to marry him after having saved his life ?" "A little patience, please, Mr. Governor; let Philip tell his own story. If I try to do it I shall only cry, and we have had tears enough lately in this house." Further consultation being thus deferred, I went up stairs to the minister's room. He was sitting by the window, in his fa- vorite arm chair, absorbed in knitting! The person who attended on him, a good natured, patient fellow, had been a sailor in his young- er days and had taught Mr. Gracedieu how to use the needles. "You see it amuses him," the man said kindly. "Don't notice his mistakes; he thinks there isn't such an- other in the world for knitting as himself.
You can see, sir, how he sticks to it." He was so absorbed over his employment that I had to speak to him twice before I could in- duce him to look at me. The utter rum of his intellect did not appear to have exercised any disastrous influence over his bodily health. On the contrary, he had grown fat- ter since I had last seen him; his complexion had lost the pallor that I remembered—there was color in his cheeks. "Don't you remem- ber your old friend," I said. He smiled and nodded and repeated the words. "Yes, yes; my old friend." It was only too plain that he had not the least recollection of me. "His memory is gone," the man said. "When he puts away his knitting at night I have to find it for him in the morning. But, there! he him like a wet sponge over a slate." The old sailor was right. If that wreck of a man had been capable of feeling and thinking, his daughter's disgrace would have broken his heart. In a world of sin and sorrow is peaceable imbecility always to be piried? I have known men who would have answered without hesitation, "It is to be envied," At breakfast, on the next day, the talk touched on those passages in Helena's diary which had been produced in court as evidence against her. I expressed a wish to see what revelation of a deprayed nature the entries in the diary might present, and my curiosity was grati- fied. At a fister time I may find an opportun- no me by the diary. articles.full_text: The poor fellow was so glad to see me that he shook hands as heartily as if we had known each other from the time when he was a boy. "Do you remember how kindly you spoke to me when I called on you in Lendon?" he asked. "If I have repeated those words once-but perhaps you don't remember them? You said: 'If I was as young as you are I should not despair.' Well, I have said that to myself over and over again for a hundred times at least. Eunice will listen to you, sir, when she will listen to nobody else. This is the first happy moment I have had for weeks past." I suppose I must have looked glad to hear that. Any way, Philip shook hands with me again. Miss Jillgall was present. The gentle- arted old maid was so touched by our

articles.headline: HOMITON DICE MANNEY
articles.full_text:
HOMITON DICE MANNEY meeting tha tshe abandoned herself to the genial impulse of the moment and gave Philip a kiss. The outraged claims of propriety instantly seized on her. She blueh- ed as if the long lost days of her girlhood had been found again, and ran out of the room. "Now, Mr. Philip," I said, "I have been waiting, at Miss Jillgall's suggestion, to get my information from you. There is some thing wrong between Eunice and yourself. What is it? and who is to blame?" "Her vile sister is to blame," he answered. "That reptile was determined to sting us, and she has done it !" he cried, starting to his feet and walking up and down the room, sense of wrong. "I say she has done it, when Eunice was ready to be my wife." "How has she done it !" Between grief and indignation his reply was involved in a confusion of vehemently spoken words which I shall not attempt to reproduce. Eunice had reminded him that her sister had been publicly convicted of an infamous crime, and publicly punished for it by imprisonment. "If I consent to marry you," she said, "I stain you with my disgrace; that shall never be." With this resolution she had left him. "I have tried to convince her," Philip said, "that she will not be associated with her sister's disgrace when she bears my name : I have promised to take her away, far away from England, among people who have never even heard of her sister. Miss Jillgall has used her influence to help me. All in vain! There is no hope for us but in you. I am not thinking selfishly only of myself. She tries to conceal it-but, oh, she is broken hearted! Ask the farmer's wife, if you don't believe me. Judge for yourself, sir. Go-for God's sake, go to the farm !" I made him sit down and compose himself. "You may depend on me going to the farm," I answered." "I shall write to Eunice to day and follow my letter to- morrow." He tried to thank me, but I would not allow it. "Before I consent to accept the expression of your gratitude," I said, "I must know a little more of you than I know now. This is only the second occasion on which we have met. Let us look back a little, Mr. Philip Dunboyne. You were Eunice's affianced husband, and you broke faith with her. That was a rascally action. How do you defend it?" His head sank. "I am asnamed to de- fend it," he answered. I pressad him without mercy. "You own yourself," I said, "that it was a rascal- ly action?" "Use stronger language against me even than that, sir-I deserve it." "In plain words," I went on, "you can find no excuse for your conduct. "In the past time," he said, "I might have found excuses." "But you can't find them now." "I must not even look for them now." " Why not?" "I owe it to Eunice to leave my conduct at its worst; with nothing said-by me-to defend it." "What has Eunice done to have such a claim on you as that ?" Eunice has forgiven me. It was gratefully and delicately said. From that moment (if it had not been too soon to trust him with the confession) I might have owned that I forgave him, too. But the duty yet lay before me of making myself acquainted with the circumstances from beginning to end of Eunice's melancholy love story. Justified by my own knowledge I might accept the position—the critical position, as I shall presently show-of Philip's friend. After more than an hour of questions put without reserve, and of answers given with-
out prevarication, I had travelled over the whole ground laid out by the narratives which appear in these pages, and had arriv- ed at my conclusion. There was Philip Dunboyne before me, resignedly waiting for my decision. A man with nothing absolute- ly wicked in him-but with a nature so perilously weak, in many respects, that it might drift into wickedness unless a strong- er nature was at hand to hold it back. Mar- ried to a wife without force of character, the probabilities would point to him as like- ly to yield to examples which might make him a bad husband. Married to a wife with a will of her own and with true love to sus- tain her-a wife who would know when to take the command and how to take the com- mand—a wife who, finding him tempted to commit actions unworthy of his better self, would be far-sighted enough to perceive that her husband's sense of homor might some- times lose its balance, without being on that account hopelessly depraved—then, and in these cases only, the probabilities would point to Philip as a man likely to be the better and the happier for his situation when the bonds of wedlock had got him. To the best of my ability I formed my judgment- and this, briefly stated, was the result. So I offered my hand to Philip and told him that he might consider me as his friend -with Eunice's best interests always held in reserve. My next proceeding was to shut myself up in my room and to seriously consider what course I should take when I went to the farm-house on the next day. Knowing what I alone knew, I held the marriage of these two young people at my disposal. I had only to relate what had happened on the day when the chaplain brought the minister to the prison, and the one obstacle to their union would be removed. I But, without considering Philip, it was simply out of the question to do this in mercy to Eunice herself. What was Helena's disgrace compared with the infamy which stained the name of the poor girl's mother? The other alternative of telling part of the truth only was before me if l could persuade myself to adopt it. Rashly enough, no doubt, I felt my decision to be influenced by the coming tinterview with Eunice.

articles.headline: Untitled Snippet
articles.full_text:
The next day I drove to the farm. Philip's entreaties persuaded me to let him be my companion, on one condition-that he waited in the carriage while I went into the house. I had carefully arranged my ideas and had decided on proceeding with the great- est caution, before I ventured on saying the all important words which, once spoken, were not to be recalled. The worst of those anxieties, under which the delicate health of Mr. Gracedieuhad broken down was my anxiety now. Could I reconcile it to my conscience to permit a man innocent of all knowledge of the truth to marry the daughter of a condemned murderess with- out honestly telling him what he was about to do? Did I deserve to be pitied? did I deserve to be biamed ; My mind was been undecided when I entered the house. She ran to meet me as if she had been my daughter; she kissed me as if she had been my daughter; she fondly koked up at me as if she had been my daughter. At the sight of that sweet young face, so sorrowful, so patiently enduring sorrow, all my pre- pared talk, all my doubts and hesitations, everything artificial about me with which I had entered the room, vanished in an instant I was resolved, come what might of it, that she should marry Philip. Impulse in a man at the end of his life? Yes, impulse-and nothing else. After she had thanked me for coming to see her I saw her tremble a little. The uppermost interest in her heart was forcing its way outward to expression, try as she might to keen it back. "Have you seen migne on wooh to person Philip ?" she asked. I was utterly reckless; I owned that he was outside in the carriage. Before she could reproach me I went on with what I had to say: "My child, I know what a sacrifice you have made, and I should honor your scruples if you had any reason for feel- ing them. "Any reason for feeling them?" She turned pale as she repeated the words. An idea came to me. I rang for the ser vant and sent her to the carriage to tell Philip to come in. "My dear, I am not putting you to any unfair trial," I assured her; "I am going to prove that I love you as truly as if you were my own child." When they were both present I resolved that they should not suffer a moment of need- less suspense. Standing between them, I took Eunice's hand and laid my other hand on Philip's shoulder and spoke out plainly. "I am here to make you both happy," I said. "I can remove the only obstacle to your marriage and I mean to do it. But I must insist on one condition. Give me your pro- mise, Philip, that you will be satisfied with the one true statement, which is all that I can offer to you." He gave me his promise without an in- stant's hesitation. "Philip grants what I ask," I said to Eunice. "Do you grant it too?"
Her hand turned cold in mine, but she spoke firmly when she said "Yes." I gave her into Philip's care. It was his privilege to console and support her. It was my duty to say the decisive words : "Rouse your courage, dear Eunice; you are no more affected by Helena's disgrace than I am. You are not her sister. Her father is not your father; her mother was not your mother. I was present, in the time of your infancy, when Mr. Gracendieu's fath- erly kindness received you as his adopted child. This, I declare to you both, on my word of honor, is the truth." How she bore it I am not able to say. My foolish old eyes were filling with tears. I could just see plainly enough to find my way to the door and leave them together. What had I done? That was not the question. I had done well if their happiness justified me. What had I concealed? I left Time to be my accomplice and keep

articles.full_text: Agriculture in the Cabinet. The bill to provide a Secretary Agricul- ture, passed the U. S. Senate last week. It had previously passed the Heuse. It now goes to the President for his approval. The bill provides that the Department of Agri- culture shall be an Executive Department under the supervision and control of a Secretary of Agriculture, who shall be ap- pointed by the President, by and with the advice and consent of the Senate. There shall be also an Assistant Secretary of Agri- culture to be appointed by the President by and with the advice and consent of the Sen- ate who shall perform such duties as may be required by law or prescribed by she Secre- tary of Agriculture; shall receive the same salary as is paid to the Secretary of each

Wolves Worked With Dogs. The following is taken from Ensign How- ard's report on Alaska: "In Arctic Alaska tne natives keep all young wolves that they catch and train them as dogs for teams. Dogs and wolves are reared together. The dogs are more than half wolf and have character-
istics of those animals. They are without One dog in each team makes himself master and overseer. If any dog shirks he will punish nim. If he cannot get at him while in harness he will not forget to give him chastisement when released at night. They arocapable of enormous endurance, like wild wolves, and can fast and work a long while. A French gentleman, after a grouse drive in Scotland, being asked by his host what he had killed, replied: "Of the grouse, none; they are too difficult; but of the moutons sauvages I have seven over the hill!" Father Ryan, a Reman Catholic priest, heard a noise in his church in St. Pancras, and on entering found three burglars trying to open the safe. They set upon him, but he beat them all single handed, capturing one. A young girl in London has turned the photographic art to profit by going about and taking incidents in the public thorough- fares and parks. She has an eye for situa- tions, and catches them full of natural spirit and action. She is out from 10 o'clock until 3, and under her camera characteristic scenes
of city life are being turned into hard meney.

articles.headline: BUODIOG GERE HILL
articles.full_text:
BUODIOG GERE HILL in fifty. The Rev. Sam Small is the Prohibition candidate for State Senator in the Atalanta district, and his opponents are pouring hot shot into him at a lively rate. But he isn't abit scared, as witness: "I am not running this race as a preacher, and no man need refrain from jumping on me on that account, It is but the convenient excuse of a coward." He also pleasantly refers to some of his accusers as "Godless and ghoulish scoun- crels and villains whom it would be base flatttery to call doge." It is a thousand pities that some others of the American unjailed criminals now resid- ing in Canada could not be served in the same way as Pitcher has been served in Montreal. This man was teller of the Union Bank, of Providence, a position which he prostituted to his own purposes, by doing his best to wreck the bank. He escaped across the border before he could be brought to justice, but brought himself within the clutch of Canadian law by purchasing a bill of exchange with the money he had stolen. This furnished the desired evidence against him. He was arrested, tried on a charge of bringing stolen money into Canada, and has been sentenced to seven years in the pene- tentiary. The mystery of the so-called Jon magical mirrors, so far as the cause of /s ir reflecting objects that are on the back side of the mirror is concerned, appears to have yielded to a little painstaking investigation.
They are thin metal hand mirrors, with rais- ed figures on the back of them, and are cast of an alloy of about eighty parts copper and twenty of tin making a very hard yet elastic metal. In grinding the mirrors they are presumably laid on a flat plate, and the grinding pressure and the thick parts, op- posite the raised figures, are ground more rapidly; the pressure removed, the plate springs back, and the mirror is concave on the face where the figures are. The light reflected from this mirror will show the back, not from any magfcal power, but be- cause of the concave surface produced over the figures—the result of accident rather than of design. Robert Browning, we suppose, is univer- sally conceded to be a great and original po- etic genius. He is emphatically the "one and only " of his kind in existence at the present moment. He is not a poet who is easily "understanded" of the people. The people indeed as a rule know nothing about him. He is studied with some enthusiasm and much apparent admiration by certain quasi literary coteries who exalt him in their es- timation much in the same way perhaps, and for the same reason, as ignorant persons sometimes admire sermons, in inverse pre- portion to the degree in which they understand him. Harper's Magazine tells of a Browning Club in some Western State which seemed to be almost ashamed of itself and its cult, or it did not call itself by the name of him whose works it professed to study. The truth came out when the Club gave a recep- tion at which everything that could be was of brown colour. A rather childish way, one would think, of showing admiration for a poet, and not calculated to inspire great Leabect let the mental stranken to be opram. ed by a study of his writings, but such nevertheless was the case. There was a brewn table cloth, and brewn china, brown bread and brown sugar, brown dresses on the backs of the hostesses (the club is compes- ed of women,) and brown curtains on the windows. Altogether the affair seems to have been "done up brown" in a masterful sort of way. The diary of the Emperor Frederick is caus- ing more and more stir, not only in Germany but all over the world. It is very pessible that in spite of all this the Professer will have hard times, while it is as well if the Empress mether can free herself of all complicity in the mat- ter, etherwise the werld might see the medi- eval exhibition of a mother sent te prison by her angry and somewhat un- natural son. In the meantime the Germans are made to understand what a loss they have sustained in old William living so long and in Frederick's life being so prematurely after the close of the Franco-Prussian war, what a gain, humanly speaking, it would have been to the world in general and to the Fatherland in particular. But mess are tempted to judge things after a very poor and limited standard. There is after all something not ourselves which makes for righteouness and in these arrangements which He may make, men will do well to acquiesce even when they are ready to fancy that they could have managed things in a much more satisfactory fashion. There is no life, however precious it may be, which is in- dispensable and even Frederick may event- ually accomplish more good by his death than he would have by a much longer life. Lincoln's death was not all less either to the warld's good or to his own regutation.

articles.headline: Untitled Snippet
articles.full_text: Russian Religion. One of the first things that strikes the stranger in St. Petersburg, and still more in Moscow, is the constant crossing that goes on in the streets. Whenever a devout Russian passes a church or a shrine or a holy altar he lifts his hat and crosses himself in the fashion of the Eastern Church. In Moscow the number of shrines is so great and the sanctity of some of them so over- powering that it must be difficult for the de- vout orthodox to get along the street. In St. Petersburg the number is much less, but it is still sufficient to keep your isvostchik's arms in tolerably active exercise. One thing puzzled me much. In St. Petersburg the women very seldom crossed themselves. For one woman who would make the sign of the the entrance to the Gostinnoi Dvor Sullue at the entrume it would be made by a dozen men, In Mos- cow the women were more careful to perform their devotions, but in St. Petersburg the males were much more devout to outward seeming than the women. Of the women who did obeisance to the holy places in St. Petersburg all were poor. I did not see one well-dressed lady cross herself in the streets all the time I was in Russia. Officers and gentlemen were not so particular as the isvostchiks and workmen, but it was no un- common sight to see them making the sign of the cross. I traveled with Gen. Ignatieff from St. Petersburg to Moscow. The mo- ment the train started the General crossed himself twice, remarking that although you should always pray, it was especially incumbent upon you to do so when starting on a journey. The number of shrines in Russia where candles are burning before noty pictu res is very great, and much greater importance is attached to the science of genuflexion than is easily credible to the non-ritualistic Eng- lishman. Sunday was much more generally observed as a holiday than I expected. The shops on the Grand Morskaya and the Nevsk Prospekt are almost all shut all Sunday. St Petersburg is not Sabbatarian by any means it is more a day of amusement and of visiting than of devotion, but there seemed to me to be a much more general cessation of labor of Sunday in Russia than either in German; or in France. 8 Address on Receiving a Bunch of High - land Heather in America. 8

Some im portant business was transacted. The bodies of the five men who were drowned while yachting at Brockville about three weeks ago have all been re covered. It is announced that Lord Dufferin Governor-General of India, has received the title of Marquis of Dufferin and Earl of Ava (?) At Watertown, N. Y., last week, J. T. Ryan, a Canadian was convicted of outrage on a young French girl at Clayton on May 11th. His defence was insanity, and his actions during the trial and before were intended to convince the court of his ir- responsibility, but Superintendent Bloom- er, of the Utica asylum, pronounced him sane after the ether test had been applied. This morning County Judge Watts sen- tenced Ryan to nineteen years imprison- ment at Auburn. At Mattawa, last week, Dr Benoit, Dr, Earle, and another practitioner, whose name could not be learned, were fined $25 each for practising without Ontario certifi- cates. Each had a McGill college certifi- cate. Commenting on the above the Ottawa Journal says: That graduates of McGill medical college, the best in Amer ica, should be fined for practising in On- tario is anomalous. articles.full_text: A farmer named Wencelas Dubois, liv- ing in the upper part of the parish of St. Cuthbert, Que., came to a horrible end near his home a few days ago. He had been unwell for some months past, but on the morning in question he took a pair of oxen and left his home with the ex- pressed intention of going to work in a wood a few acres away. Coming to the place indicated the terrible idea of taking his own life seems to have suddenly en- tered the man's mind. articles.headline: CHAPTER I.
articles.full_text: CHAPTER I. The Lady Betty was swearing. She was not drunk, however. Under the present conditions reigning at the fort, it would have been difficult to have attained to any such indulgence of body and mind. For there was little left to drink; still less to eat; while desperate anxiety darkened every face, and the shadow of death loomed close at hand. Yet, black as matters looked, with hundreds of Indians infuriated with blood-thirst closing them in on all sides, with only a dezen men to held the fort and protect the two women shut up there with them, with ammunition running short, with food and water distributed on principles of the strictest economy, with a blazing sun overhead to add to the torture of long hours with their ceaseless dread and expectation, with no prospect but death at the hands of a cruel, merciless foe; yet The Lady Betty was not swearing at the present conditions of her existence, but at the one other woman shut up with her in that besieged fort. It would have been difficult to say, look ing at her now as she stood within the stockade, drawn back into the doorway o one of the buildings to avoid meeting the other woman who had just passed by, why she had ever gained the title of "The Lad Betty." The usual tawdry finery with which she delighted to adorn herself wa faded, tern, and dirty, there being no or portunities in that doomed, out-of the worl fort, peopled only by that handful of des perate men, for repairing deficiencies toilet. There w .s no dignity in the reckles abandonment of herself to the low, vulga her The coars passions that convuised nor. beauty of her face was disfigured by hate rage, and desire of revenge. But some one in her past had given he the nickname, and it had stuck to her eve She had been little more than since. child then; she was but just a woman nov a year or two still off thirty, but the yea through which that name had clung to h might have reckoned as a century if the experience of reckless life were measure instead of time. The Lady Berty had e joyed herself after her own fashion. But this afternoon, in a vague, dumb wa as some maddened, pain-tortured bru might resent the agony of the lash broug on itself by its own ungoverned passion had brought their own punishment. which-but no! The Lady Betty only broke into more furious rage when she thought of this. That that girl should master her! The rage that desperately defied the thought was full on her at this instant, as Miriam Gres- ham went by with Sorry Carew. She hissed out a curse after them. The young man heard it; his face grew white to the lips. He did not look at his companion; but he knew how the delicate skin had flushed scar- let and then paled beneath the gratuitous in- sult, and his eyes blazed with fury against
the weman who had dared so to hurt her.
Yet there had been a yesterday when his eyes had glowed with a different light as they looked on that woman, and it was the remem- brance of that past which touched, with its chill hand of fear, his heart to-day. They did not speak till they reached that part of the low wood buildings in which rooms had been given her and her father. It was Miriam who broke the awkward siler ce. "Why does she hate me so?" she asked, looking up at him with eyes still bright with her hurt. "It seems hard, when she and I are the only women here—and when to- morrow we may be dead." Her voice caught and fell into lower tones. They had not told her what manner of e woman The Lady Betty was. She thought her coarse, vulgar, insolent, foul mouthed, but she believed her honest. Her father and the other men had kept up the delusion s sprung like an angel's fancy from her own pure soul. You must not mind her," said Sorry Carew, awkwardly, remembering her faced of "She's brave and she's true. She has faced death with us, and—' he stopped short. A r | he looked into the girl's sweet, half-indig e | nant, half-pained eyes, he felt it sacrilege to e, even speak of The Lady Betty's good quali ties. the way of the shots. The long, weary day passed, the afternoon waned. Miriam, rebelling against her captivity, ventured to disobey orders. As she stepped outside she caught sight of The Lady Betty disappearing into a small shanty, built on rising ground at the other end of the stockade. She looked about her; none of the boys were near. A sudden impulse-for which the girl could never account, unless it were a simple womanly desire for the sympathy of her own sex at this supreme moment of peril—made her run across the space between the building she occupied and the shanty. She reached the door, which The Lady Betty had left sjar. The girl called her softly. There was no answer, and, pushing the door open,
Miriam looked in. There was a square opening for a window at the end of the room, and through this opening poured the golden light of the western sun. It rolled in waves of dazzling radiance into the room, and in the midst of it, bathing her as in a sea of fiery light, stood, rigid still, gazing through the opening, The Lady Betty. She seemed to be seeing a vision, so pale was her face, so staring and fixed her eyes. The girl spoke again gently, but the woman did not stir, and Miriam, stepping half fear fully, for she did not know how she would be received, went up to her. But as she reached the woman's side, and instinctively followed the gaze of her rapt eyes, an exclamation of awed delight and wonder broke from her lips. Through a break of the wood-lined hills facing the window, the sun was setting in . perfect glory of red and gold. The whole horizon, narrowed to them by those hills s seemed a sea of fire, which stretched on in - liquid, quivering waves of light from heaves o to them, as they stood on the earth. friends were saved. She insisted upon get- ting up and going about the next day. Nor would she wait till the relieved garrison reached Fort James. The evening before they were to arrive she left. The sun was setting across the level prairie as she rode out of the fore and all the west was radiant with its glory. She turned her horse's head toward it and sat for a moment, with a wistful, rapt gaze in her eyes, looking straight into the radiance, flooding earth and sky, before her. Then she turned to the people who had come to see her start : "Tell Miriam Gresham and Sorry Carew ez how I'm goin' toward them golden gates -she'll know-and I reckon ez how I'll never keer fur to come back." And she rode away into the golden Nor did those who had once known her ever
see her come out of it again. What a Child Did. Will the world ever know what depths of Will the world ever know what depths of tenderness there were in the heart of Abraham Lincoln? An anecdote, which has never been published, brings out one more instance in which his sympathies, awakened by a little child, the young soldier, by the aid of influential gentlemen, obtained a position as a government weigher of hay and grain.
