articles.headline: TEA GROWING IN CEYLON,
articles.full_text: TEA GROWING IN CEYLON, Success of a New Enterprise in that Land.

articles.headline: BY DAVID KER.
articles.full_text: BY DAVID KER. It seems to be a matter of course that a man who has to write upon any subject should begin by touching upon every sub- ject in the world except the one on which he has to write. On this principle I myself, having gone all the wayout to Ceylon for the express purpose of examining the growing and preparation of the famous Cingalese tea, have described everything else in the island without ever mentioning its tea at all. I do not find, however, that I relish a cup of tea any the more now that I know all about its manufacture than I did when it was present to my mind only as a mysteri- ous powdery stuff that came from China in queer boxes covered with figures like the dolls in a toy shop, and was scmetimes black and sometimes green without any apparent reason. While I was studying the process I re- minded myself of nothing so much as one of those dreadful "instructive books" beloved by our fathers, in which some unfortunate small bey is mercilessly catechised right in the middle of his breakfast (or worse still, before being allowed to begin breakfast at all) respecting the manufacture of everything that he puts into his mouth-the bread, the butter, the tea, the sugar, the bacon-all in regular order. The most perfect instance of this style of thing which I ever encount- life was in a secluded valley eled in lear me are an acces among the mountains of Eastern Brazil, where I had all the ingredients of a cup of coffee under my eyes at one view-the sugar canes on a level ground, the coffee plants along the slopes, and the cows grazing upon the top of the ridge. To return, then, to the subject of tea plant- ing, it is to be noticed that this industry has only developed itself to an appreciable extent within the last few years, and that it is chiefly confined to one district which seems admirably fitted for the purpose. Fifty or 60 miles inland, in a direct line from the western coast of Ceylon, the uniform flatness of the island

articles.headline: IS SUPDENLY BROKEN
articles.full_text: IS SUPDENLY BROKEN by a circular group of mountains (already described in my letters from Kandy, Tata- pella, and Adam's Feak) as picturesquery steep and broken as those of Montenegro itself, and forming, though on a very small scale, a kind of Cingalese Switzerland. In the deep, sheltered valleys and upon the sunny slopes of these mountains grew till very lately the coffee plants and cinchona trees that yielded the coffee and quinine for which Ceylon has long been famous; but these are now being fast replaced by the glossy green leaves from which is manu- factured the now celebrated "Cingalese tea"-a "survival of the fittest" which would have charmed Dr. Darwin if he could have lived to see it. "I doubt very much whether coffee will ever recover itself in these parts," said one of the principal planters in the Agra Patana tea country, at whose pretty little country house among the hills of the Talawakele dis- trict we spent a very pleasant week in the course of our travels through the interior of Ceylon. "But even if it were to regain its old place to-morrow it would always be at a disadvantage as compared with tea for two very good reasons. First and foremost, although tea suffers a good deal from 'red spider and other things of that sort, the diseases of the coffee plant are more numer- ous by far than those of the tea plant, and when they come in earnest they simply mean absolute destruction to the whole crop. Then, too, when a crop of coffee is destroyed or blighted you have nothing more to hope for as regards that year, whereas if anything happens to a growth of tea you will have the comfort of knowing that there will be another 'flush,' as we call it, in 10 days' time, which, if it turns out well, may recoup all your loss and more. "But it seems to me," said I, "that that particular advantage is confined to the tea of Ceylon itself, for I remember that when we were in the tea growing districts of Northern India a few years ago, the plant- ers told us that there would not be another flush till April, and it was then about the middle of February." "That's very true," answered Mr. W., " and that's just where we Cingalese plant- ers have the advantage of the fellows in Assam and the Kangra Valley; they can only manufacture their tea at stated inter- vals, whereas we can keep on at it all the year round. And now, if you two come for a walk round the plantation with me, I'm going to see how the

articles.headline: THE REST TO SERVICE
articles.full_text: THE REST TO SERVICE

articles.headline: DIFFERENT GANGS OF PICKERS
articles.full_text: DIFFERENT GANGS OF PICKERS are getting on; and when that's done, we'll just step down to my factory at the foot of the hill yonder, and I'll show you the whole process of tea making from beginning to end." "Have you been successful with your tea so far ?" asked I, as the three of us picked our way in single file along the narrow, threadlike path that zigzagged up the steep hillside among the glossy green leaves of the fresh tea. Well, I've nothing to complain of at present, although of course I can't do very much in the manufacturing line till I get up that new machinery that I'm waiting for. But so far as the mere growing of the tea is concerned, there's no fault to be found. If I make my fortune by tea-and I've both made it and lost it again by coffee, eince I first came out here- I can ten you, since I miss out - I can put on the panel of my carriage the same motto that Dr. Johnson gave to an Indian tea planter in the last century : 'Tu doces,' (thou teachest,) which everybody who saw it read : 'Thou tea chest.' " "Or else." suggester I, "you might ap- propriate Theodore Hook's epigram upon Twining, the tea dealer: "Beneficent nature has curiously plant ed Men's names with their lives should agree; There's Twining, the teaman, who lives in the Would be whining if robbed of his T.,, But, now I think of it, is it true that some of the tea estates round here have been produc- ing 1,000 pounds of tea per acre?" Perfectly true, although some of the Madras newspapers wouldn't believe a word of it when the story first came out, and sent over correspondents to look into it. But by the time the correspondents arrived the same plantations were yielding fully 1,200 pounds per acre, and the worthy reporters went back again with a considerable enlarge- ment in their ideas of Cingalese tea growing. Now, here we come to a patch of coffee and yeu'll have a chance of seeing what prospect we've got of making any profit in that way."

articles.headline: Untitled Snippet
articles.full_text: It was indeed a hopeless spectacle for any planter to behold, and one whose ghostly desolation was intensified rather than re- lieved by the glorious sunshine around it and the bright blue sky overhead. Far and wide beneath us, the whole slope seemed blasted as if by fire. In some spots the withered leaves hung shriveled and lifeless, stirring slowly in the morning breeze like the hair of dead men upon a battlefield. In other places they had fallen away altogether, leaving the long bare rows of sapless plane,

articles.headline: STANDING GAUNTLY UP IN
articles.full_text: STANDING GAUNTLY UP IN endless perspective, like an army of skele- tons. And that nothing might be wanting to make this grim picture complete, the caprice of the pest had spared a few plants here and there, to stand as the living among the dead, and mock with their fresh sunny green the dreary bareness of their blighted brethren. But in a sheltered hollow beneath us lies one tolerably large patch of coffee, which seems to have escaped the destroyer, and here a gang of Tamil coolies-about 20 strong, including women and children-are engaged in "picking." One of their num- ber carries on his back a huge basket, into which the others keep emptying the coffee berries from the small panniers slung at their sides; and the group of dusky faces, white turbans, and long brown limbs, mov- ing ceaselessly to and fro among the green leaves and bright scarlet berries, has a very picturesque effect. But every one of the gang, from the biggest coolie down to the smallest boy, works in a spiritless fashion which proclaims more plainly than any words their consciousness that King Chiee reign is over, and that they may in every sense of the work "take it coolie." But Mr. W. goes by this gang with only a few passing words of advice and encour- agement, for the real business of the day lies behind the elbow of the ridge, beyond which the tea plantations begin. Here the picking is being conducted in the same way but there are at least five times as many hands engaged in it, and the briskness with which the work is going forward tells its own story. A little apart from the rest stands a tall man with two crossed sticks hung upon his back, which I conjecture to be a kind of official badge. And so it proves, for Mr. W. points him out to us as the "kangani" or rative overseer of the gang, who brings over the coolies from Southern India and lines inten ent planters, receiving a bounty equal to 4 cents per head upon all the laborers engaged. "It's a great thing to have an experienced overseer," says he, "one who can teach these fellows to do their picking properly, for you have no idea how much harm may be done by careless or clumsy picking. You'll notice that each picker breaks off from every fresh root one leaf, a bud, and the half of another leaf. Now, if in doing so he happens to break the eye of the sprout, leaf will spring from it any more, and when you think how many of these eyes one unskilful picker may break in a single day you can imagine how important it is to have the mands properly trained." "What wages do they get?" ask I. "The men 16 cents a day, the women and boys 8, for 10 hours' work. It doesn't sound much to you, I dare say, but I can assure you that according to native ideas it's a very fair rate. Do you see that young girl to our left there, he one with the big silver bangles on her wrists? She's one of the best pickers on the whole estate. She's going to marry one of my native servants next week, and a right good wife she'll make him. Just watch how neatly she brings off those leaves, never breaking nor hurting them a bit. Women are always better than men for this kind of work, because there touch is so light, only of course they cannot do so much work in a day. Look at that man, now, who is picking just in front of us. You would hardly think, see miles if it's an inch. He did, though, and thought very little of it when it was done." "Are these tea plants here full grown?" I inquire as we pass on. "Well, they're grown sufficiently to yield a good crop, if that's what you mean; but they're not come to their best yet, nor anything like. We only began planting about three years ago, you know. We consider a tea plant fit for yielding at 2 years old, and after that it goes on increasing till the end of the sixth year, when it is at its hest. We keep on pruning the plants till they're 18 inches high, and when they reach 22 inches we measure them with a cross-stick and pluck everything above the 22-inch level. Now shall we go down to the factory and see how the tea is made chona trees, shooting up straight and slen- der as a fountain jet and then breaking off in one great gush of green leaves, many of which are now dyed with

articles.headline: A GORGEOUS CRIMSON,
articles.full_text:
A GORGEOUS CRIMSON, such as any painter would love to copy. But Mr. W., noting the direction of my approving glance, says with a rueful smile : 'I see you're admiring those crimson leaves, 'but I can assure you that such bits of color- ing are not at all beautiful in the eyes of us planters, for the moment we see those red leaves upon any cinchona tree we know that it's blighted and that we'll never get a single ounce of quinine from it again." A few minutes later we enter the factory -a long, low building of the genuine East
Indian type, down in a hollow not far from The first thing that the bank of the liver. The man and we see on entering is a kind of gigantic squirrel's cage, 8 or 9 feet long, which a tall coolie is turning by a handle at one end and showering a rain of green |leaves upon the floor like pepper from a caster. A nearer view of this queer machine shows us that it is made of twisted wire and half full of tea leaves, and Mr. W. explains that this is the "sifter," used for separating the coarser from the finer leaves, which are then spread out to be withered. "And here," he concludes, "is the withering going on now." There, There, sure enough, are three or four strange-looking objects exactly like over- grown Venetian blinds, except that the horizontal "slats' are formed not of painted wood, but of sheets of stout canvas in wood- en frames, upon which the tea leaves, scat-

articles.headline: Untitled Snippet
articles.full_text: coffee pot fixed on top of a copying machine, and performing a kind of demen dance over a hole in the centre of a flat round stone, while absorbing mouthful after mouthful of leaves sheveled into it by a watchful native,

articles.headline: Untitled Snippet
articles.full_text:
only to cast them forth again the next mom- ent rolled neatly up in those tiny cylinders with which we are all familiar. Passing lightly over the "re-rolling"-a process to which only a certain proportion of the leaves are subjected-we go back into the large room to study the details of the two final processes, "fermenting" and "firing," after which the tea is ready to be packed and sent off. The firing is perform- ed in two different ways, the second and most complete of which is managed by a seven-chambered steam furnace of improved construction, the beauties of whose working are explained to me by Mr. W. in an ela- borate discourse, which, like the majority f scientific explanations given to unscientific men, leaves me just as wise as I was before. de of too hore " he "There are three kinds of bea here, he edds, "broken Pekoe, Pekce and Souchong. We're manufacturing a good deal of all three just now, but nothing to what we shall do when our new machinery's in op- eration, as I hope it will be next week. Take my word for it, all Ceylon will have gone into tea growing in another year or two, and 'real Cingalese' will be as well known in the English market as 'Kangra Valley' itself. By the bye, that reminds me that I mustn't let you go away without a sample of it." And in a trice a perfect stack of neatly- packed half-pounds of tea, compactly done up in air-tight leaden wrappers, lie await- ing our acceptance. It is hard to refuse what is so freely offered, as well as so pre- cious in itself, but the necessity of one portmanteau apiece has no law, and we can only accept three out of the twelve. "And now," says our obliging host, lead- ing the way to the further end of the build- ing, "I'm going to show you, by way of an appropriate wind up, what I don't think you'll ever see again in these parts-the method of preparing coffee." In a dark corner about two feet below the general lev- el of the floor we find a long narrow stone tank with a few inches of water in it, in which a half dezen bare-limbed natives are splashing about like Italian peasants tread- ing a winepress, except that in this case they are treading coffee berries instead, in order to wash off the inner husk when softened by water, thus leaving the smooth cream-colored bean within ready for that two days' exposure to the sun which is the final stage of the process. Mr. W. opens -1---- a side door and shows us several sheets of matting outspread on the ground in an open space just at the back of the factory, upon which lie strewn several hundreds of shin- ng coffee beans, exposed like ancient mar- tyrs to the full heat of the burning sun. "Coffee has this one advantage over tea," he observes, as we leave the factory and begin to ascend the hill again, "that it certainly requires less preparation, but in every other respect the superiority is quite the other way. You mag sum up the present history of coffee in Ceylon like the schoolmaster who, when a boy whose half-yearly char- acter he was writing tumbled off the top of the house and was killed, coolly added: 'I noticed a great falling off in him latly." How A Tiger Kill and Eats Its Prey. In a paper read before the Bombay Nat- ural History Society recently, and publish- ed in its journal, Mr. Inverarity, a noted shikari, discussed the habits of the tiger, and especially the mode in which it kills and eats its prey. Some think he seizes by the throat, others by the nape of the neck from above. Mr. Inverarity has examined scores of slain animals with special reference to this point, and in every case but one the throat was seized from below. Wnether dislocation of the neck takes place is doubt- ful. The tame hunting leopards always kill by pressure on the windpipe, without breaking the skin; possibly the tiger kills in the same way. It is only by accident, if at all, that tigers in killing sever any -- 3 4- important vein or artery, and no blood to speak of flows from the throat wounds. Having killed, the tiger almost invariably begins eating a hind-quarter, consuming one or probably both. Animals are never eaten where they are killed, but are always dragged a short distance. They are not lifted clear of the ground, but dragged. Having gorged himself, the tiger sometimes lies close by his prey, but if it is hot weather and there are hills in the neighborhood he will go a long distance off before resting for the day. He returns next night and finish- es what is left, but he never eats a second
time on the same spot, dragging the remains
of the prey 40 or 50 yards off. The tiger takes about two hours' steady eating to finish the forequarters of a bullock. Tigers are cannibals; they will make their meals off each other. They are supposed to kill once in five or six days, and no doubt the tiger after a heavy feed does not care to hunt much for a few days; but a tiger kills whenever he can. They have been known to kill on 14 consecutive nights. Mr. Inverarity believes that animals killed by tigers suffer little beyond the panic of a few seconds. The shock produces a stupor and dreaminess in which there is no sense of pain or feeling of terror. The powerful stroke of the fore paw of the tiger is a fiction; he clutches with his claws as one might with the fingers, but does not strike a blow. Tigers wander immense distances at night, and, as they like easy going, they go on roads and paths. They do not like to move during the heat of the day, as the hot ground burns their pads and makes them raw. They can on occasion climb - Qalantta one climbed after a trees. In parsette one cumous most certain Pandoo, but could not reach him and retired. Pandco, thinking the coast clear, got down and ran toward home, but on the way was caught by the tiger and killed. . The inquest report stated that "Pandoo died of the tiger eating him; there was no other cause of death. Nothing was left except some fingers, which probably belonged to the right or left hand." Natives have a belief that the ghosts of the man- eater's victims ride in his head and warn him of danger, or point the way to fresh victims. Nething makes a man se run after as te call him a heretic. Aluminum resembles silver in appearance, is stronger than steel, will not tarnish and is superior to silver for all purposes for which metal is used. Freshmen at Vassar have easier times than at colleges for boys, and they ought to. for they are girls, and etiquette rules, Every girl in the college early in the school year goes forth on certain afternoons, card case in hand, to call upon the freshmen or other newcomers in her corridor. If the freshman be out a card is left; if in, the ac- quaintance is formed. After this visite are more informal and parties are given,

articles.headline: Untitled Snippet
articles.full_text: A Series of Terrible Beeds That Shocked Scotland Years Age. A sensation akin to that which has been developed in London by the recent White- chapel murders was created just sixty years age in Edinburgh by the discovery of a series of crimes, which stood forth, then as now, wholly without example in any age or country. Two fiends in human shape, William Burke and William Hare, deliberately en- tered into a partnership to decoy persons to their houses to murder them in cold blood and sell the bodies to Dr. Knox, lecturer on anatomy at the University of Edinburgh. William Burke was born in County Ty- rene, Ireland, 1792. His parents were poor, but respectable cotters. He was brought nn a Roman Catholic and received a fair PL De Vacationes Changes and and education. He married early and subse- quently deserted his wife, who bore him seven children. Later on he met a woman Helen McDougal by name, while he was working in Scotland. They remained to- gether up to the day of their arrest. Burke worked in Scotland as a laborer and after the harvest of 1827 he, still accompanied the woman McDougal, went to Edinburgh and there met Hare. This man, his ature partner in the series of fearful crimes they jointly perpetrated, at this time kept a low ledging house, in Tenner's Close, Westport. Burke and the McDougal woman went to live at Hare's lodging house, which was managed by a woman who passed as his wife. Her maiden name was Laird and she was the widow of a man named Log.

articles.headline: A BODY FOR SALE.
articles.full_text: A BODY FOR SALE. The first idea of carrying out the series or erimes afterwards perpetrated by Barke and his associate appears to have arisen when one of Hare's lodgers died a natural death. The man was a pensioner. His debanched habits sufficiently accounted for his audden death. Burke and Hare managed to abstract the corpse from the coffin after the undertaker had left the house, and filing up the empty casket with bricks, packed in tan bark, the coffin was borne to the grave at the appointed time with all due solemnity. Tast night Here went to a College of Sur- geons and offered the body for sale. He was referred to Dr. Knox, of 10 Surgeons' Square. Here he saw some young students, by whose directions he carried the pension- er's corpse to the dissecting room of the college, having been paid £7 10 for the subject. The death of the pensioner and the profi- table disposition of his remains appears to have suggested to the two miscrean.s the earrying out of the villainous business in which they forthwith engaged. Within the space of a few months they murdered no less than sixteen persons. Barke used to frequent the low public houses of the neighborhood and when he found some way farer without a home or the means of obtaining a shelter he would offer them a lodging at Hare's house or his own. The victim was industriously plied with liquor till he or she became unconcious. Then the two partners in crime wou'd fa'l upon them and while Hare usually choked the poor wretch to death Burke, would throw himself upon the body and thus hasten the end. The two women were undoubtedly the orimes but they invariable privy to the crimes, but they left the room while the murders were being perpetrated.

articles.headline: WHAT THE MURDERERS WEER LIKE.
articles.full_text:
WHAT THE MURDERERS WEER LIKE. Burke was a man of 35, rather below the middle size, but stoutly built and of a deter- mined cast of countenance. His face was round, cheekbones high, with gray eyes, deeply sunk in the head, short snub nose and round chin. His hair and whiskers were of a light, sandy color and his com- plexion fair and slightly freckled. Helen McDougal is described as having been a woman of medium height, thin and sparely made. Her features were long, but by no means displeasing, and were rendered somewhat expressive by a pair of large full black eyes. Hare was about 35, and is said to have been one of the most squalid-looking wretches ever seen in a dock, with a sinister expres- sion, which rendered his appearance pecu- liarly revolting. His wife was a short, stout, round-faced and fresh-complexioned woman, with a look of coarse and determin- ed brutality. Hare appears to have been a rude boor with all the outward appearances of a ruffi- an. Drunken, ferocious and profligate he was far likelier to repel than ensuare vic- tims to their murderous lair. He appears however to have been the more deeply de- signing man of the two and to have over. reached his associate, whom he succeeded in always thrusting forward, probably with the view of disposing of him as he ultim- ately did, sending him to the gallows and bhereby saving his own wretched ne k.
Burke managed the outdoor business of the partnership for he it was who always went

articles.headline: PAR ATTON MATER IN THE WAY
articles.full_text: PAR ATTON MATER IN THE WAY on the prowl after victims. In his outward manners he wasentirely thereverse of Hare. Quiet in his demeanor, he never gave way to cursing and swearing even when the worse for drink. He was fawning in his ad- dress, and was a general favorite among the children of the neighborhood, any one of whom would cheerfully run upon his er- rand. The quarrels which were apparently so often happening in his house were pro- bably only make believes to drown the dy- ing cries of the unhappy victims.

articles.headline: THE FIRST OF THE CRIMES
articles.full_text: THE FIRST OF THE CRIMES The first of the series of sixteen murders was committed in January, 1828, and the last, that of an old woman, Mary Docherty, in October of the same year. This last erime led to the detection of the murderers, their arrest and the trial, conviction and execution of Burke. The woman McDougal was acquitted, Hare saved his neck by turning Queen's evidence and his wife also was used as a witness in the case. The murder of Mrs. Docherty's was discovered by a Mr. and Mrs. Gray, who lodged in Hare's house. They heard a noise as of quareling and fighting after they had retiesd one night and the next day Mrs. Gray found Docherty's body concealed under a heap of straw in Hare's bedroom. After Burke's conviction he made a full confession, in which, however, he sought to show that in each case Hare was the actual murderer as he had been the first one to suggest the execution of the crimes. Accord- ing to Burke's statement the first victim was one Abigail Simpson, a middled-aged woman enticed to the house by Hare's wife. She was carried to Hare's house at night, was induced to drink, went off in a leep sleep and was suffocated in the early merning. Then followed an Englishman, name unknewn, who came to ledge at Here's. Me had jaundice and was about 40 years of was sold to Dr. Knex for $10. Shee come

articles.headline: Untitled Snippet
articles.full_text: nameless old woman who took a night's lodging by chance in the murderer's den. She was smothered in the early morning in the usual way, with a heavy feather pillow, and that night the body was taken to Dr. Knex who paid the usual sum for is. Margaret Patterson, a young and exceed- ingly handsome girl, was decoyed to the home of Burkes brother, and their des- patched. She was carried four hours after death to Dr. Knox who paid £8'or the body. An old woman and her grandson, a deaf mute, were the next victims. They took lodging for the night at Hare's, were treated to I quor and suff cated shortly after mid- night. They stripped the boules, laid them side by side to coul, then packed them in a herring barrel. Dr. Knox paid the assas- sins £16 for the two subjects. As chance customers at this time recame rare, the regular lodgers were now requisitionized and a man known as "Joseph the Miller," who was well connected and had once possessed considerable means, was smoth- ered during the night and his body sold for £10 to the omniverous Dr. Knox. Shortly afterwards Hare fell in with a woman of the town, enticed her to his house, murdered her single handed and carried the body round to the doctor who gave him £8 for it. A cinder gatherer known as "Effy" was induced by Burke to enter a stable occupied by Hare. Here she was dosed with whisky. She fell asleep on a truss of hay and the two villains smothered her in the usual way. For this body they received £10. One night Burk encountered a policeman dragging a half-drunken woman to the lock-up. He induced the officer to release her, promising to see her safe home to her lodgings. The wretch took her round to Hare's house, where he and his bloodstained partner speedly smothered her and sold the body for £10.

articles.headline: LIKE A LAMB TO THE SLAUGHTER."
articles.full_text: LIKE A LAMB TO THE SLAUGHTER." James Wilson, commonly called "Daft Jamie," was a well-known character on the streets of the Scottish capital. He was a harmless idiot, but possessed of prodigious strength. Mrs. Hare persuaded him to ac- company her home on the promise of a drink of whisky. She then left him with her hus- band and Burke. In the latter's confession he says that Mrs. Hare led poor Jamie in as a dumb lamb to the slaughter, and, as a sheep to the shearers : he made almost con- stant ir quiry in his own way for his mother.

articles.headline: BUGILL IL I GILL J LLL LING CHILL
articles.full_text:
BUGILL IL I GILL J LLL LING CHILL and was told that she would be there pre- sently. They smothered the poor daft creature, nevertheless, and the complaisant Dr. Knox cheerfully handed over ten £1 notes for his corpse. Ann McDougal, a cousin of Helen's, was the next to fall a prey to these vampires. She was but re- cently married, and came on a visit to the Hares Burke and Hare gave her whisky and dispatched her in the customary way, and disposed of the body to their regular custo- mer, Dr. Knox, for £10. Then the blood- thirsty wretches fell back on the lodgers again, and killed a Mrs. Haldane and her daughter Peggy. Dr. Knox took the old lady's body at full price, but would only give £8 for that of the daughter.

The lodgers were now all exhausted with the exception of the Grays, and as drink ap- peared to be no temptation to them the whisky trap was tried upon Mrs. Hostler, a poor woman who came once a week to do the washing. She speedily became intoxi- cated, was put to bed, and the wretches, as soon as she fell asleep, smothered her.

articles.headline: THE TERRIBLE TALE COMPLETED.
articles.full_text: THE TERRIBLE TALE COMPLETED. A woman smothered by Hare while Burke was in the country, and sold for £8, makes up the awful tale of murders to which the wretched man confessed. It is from an ex- ceedingly rare book published in 1829, con taining Burke's confession, and a full ac- count of his trial and conviction, that the the above facts are taken. After Burke was hanged, Hare, with great diffic- ulty, managed to make his way out of the country. Finally, accompanied by his wife, he went to Australia, but in 1855 he returned to Edinburgh alone, a broken down old man, totally blind It was some years before he was recognised. Meanwhile he paraded the streets begging led, by a small dog and carrying a tincup to receive the con- tributions of the benevolent. When he found his identity was discovered he myster- iously disappeared, and has never been heard of since. Dr Koox also gave evidence in the case, and his protestations to the ef- fect that the idea never entered his mind that the subjects had died by violence appears to have been believed by the authori- ties, as no subsequent proceedings were When the woman McDougal was released she, with almost incredible audacity, at once returned to her old haunts in the West Port. She was at once set upon by the peo- that the police watch office, to which she ran for protection, was close at hand, she would probably have been lynched. She was subsequently hunted out of Elinburgh and returned to her native place, Redding, in Stirlingshire. From there she afterwards went to Glasgow and took up her abode with Constantine Burke, her late husband's brother. In Search of Stanley and Emin Pasha. The Germans are evidently disposed to go as quickly as possible now to the relief of Emin Pasha, and the ominous news of the failure of the Barttelot expedition will tend to hurry their preparations. They are also fully bent on moving by way of Zanzi- bar, and evidently would like to have Great Britain's exertions for the rescue either of Stanley or Emin put forth by the Congo route. But Great Britain has also a base of operations on the Zanzibaar side of the continent in her own East African Company and her relations with the Sultan. In such a matter effective co-operation is the main thing, and if the greater hope is to be look- ed for from starting on the eastern coast of Africa it is desirable that more than one expedition should go from there. No doubt eagerness to open a commercial route from the great Nile lakes to the coast is connected with these relief projects, but that does not render the humanitarian considerations less urgent. It is to be regretted on this account tnat bitter opposition has just at this mo- ment broken out among the natives of the interior to the Sultan of Zanzibar and those whom they consider his white allies, direct- ed especially, it would seem, against the Germans. A suggestive accident recently occurred to the Comptesse de Viel Castel. The spirit lamp for making tea burst, and her face and body were enveloped with ignited spirit. She was not seriously burned, though,

articles.full_text: A. H. FARNSWORTH, Maude Principal. hms and ne Hod- Death of Mr. Jas. Cowle, of Almonte. lop and The festivities of New Year's Day were os. Wil- at their height in town when the death Indgins; was announced of Mr. James Cowle, af- laylor. ter less than a week's illness, from inflam- cKillop; mation of the lungs. Many of our towns- Wilson. | men had scarcely heard of his illness, and est Hod- the sad news came as shock to them. d, Wm. and cast a gloom over the town. Mr. Cowie took cold while driving to Carleton . Lang; Place, on Christmas, and it developed rmitage. | rapidly, ending in what is known as bron- Naylor; cho-pneumonia. Everything possible was st Hod- done to avert a fatal termination-Dr. Wright, of Ottawa, being called in in ad- est Hod dition to the local physicians-but medi- os. Will- | car skill and the most assiduous care prov ed of no avail, and on Wednesday fore- noon the spirit went out to its Maker. Wilson, The late Mr. Cowie was in his 40th year. Few men in this district were better nie Mc- known, his business taking him all over known, his business taking him all over the Arm-leastern Ontario. He was proprietor of the Almonte pump factory and agent for Patterson & Bros., agricultural implement manufacturers. He was a pushing business man, and took 02. articles.headline: Untitled Snippet
articles.full_text: A Practical Lesson for Christians-"The Hast Kept the Good Wine Until Nov The Preacher's Eloquent Discourse Advice to Parents-Consolation Com In The Last Extremity. NEAR CANA, Dec. 22.—The Rev. DeWitt Talmage, D.D., preached here t day on "A Marriage Feast," taking f his text John ii., 10: "Thou hast kept the good wine until now." He said: Standing not far off, from the demolish sown of what was once called Cana Galilee, I bethink myself of our Lord's fir manhood miracle, which has been the a conishment of the ages. My visit last wee to that place makes vivid in my mind th beautiful occurrence in Christ's ministr My text brings us to a wedding in th village. It is a wedding in common lif two plain people having pledged each othe hand and heart, and their friends havin come in for congratulation. The joy not the less because there is no preter sion. In each other they find all the futur they want. The daisy on the cup in the table may mean as much as a score of arti tic garlands fresh from the hothouse. Whe a daughter goes off from home with nothing but a plain father's blessing, and a plain mother's love, she is missed as much a though she were a princess. It seems hard after the parents sheltered her for eightee years, that in a few short months her affect tions should have been carried off b another; but motherremembers how it wa in her own case when she was young, an so she braces up until the wedding he passed, and the banqueters are gone, an she has a good cry all alone. Well, we are to-day at the wedding i Cana of Galilee. Jesus and his mothe have been invited. It is evident that ther are more people there than were expected Either some people come who have no Deen invited or more invitations were sen out than it was supposed would be accepted Of course there is not enough supply of wine. You know that there is nothin more embarrassing to a housekeeper than ecant supply. Jesus sees the embarrase ment and He comes up immediately t relieve it. He sees standing six water pots He orders the servants to fill them wit water and then waves his hand over th water, and immediately it is wine-res Tasta of it and see for von

articles.headline: WILLO. TOPOLO OF IL CHICK BOO TOT TOWN
articles.full_text: WILLO. TOPOLO OF IL CHICK BOO TOT TOWN selves; no logwood in it, no strychnin in it, but first-rate wine. I wil not now be diverted to the question so ofter discussed in my own country, whether it i right to drink wine. I am describing th scene as it was. When God makes wine H makes the very best wine; and 130 gallon of it standing around in these water-pots- wine so good that the ruler of the feas tasted it and says, "Why, this is really Better than anything we have had! Thou hast kept the good wine until now." Beau tiful miracle! A prize was offered to the person who would write the best essay about the miracle at Cana. Long manu scripts were presented in the competition but a poet won the prize by just this one line descriptive of the miracle: The unconscious water saw its God, and blushed. We learn from this miracle in the first place, that Christ has sympathy with house keepers. You might have thought that Jesus would have said: "I cannot be bothered with this household deficiency of wine. It is not for Me, Lord of heaven, or earth, to become caterer to this feast. have vaster things than this to attend to.' Not so said Jesus. The wine gave out, and Jesus, by miraculous power, came to the rescue. Does there ever come a scant supply in your household? Have you to make a very close calculation? It is hard work for you to carry on things decently and respect- ably? If so, don't sit down and cry. Don't go out and fret; but go to Him who stood in the house in Cana of Galilee. Pray in the parlor! Pray in the kitchen! Let there be no room in all your house uncon- secrated by the voice of prayer. If you have a microscope, put under it one drop of water, and see the insects floating about; and when you see that God makes them and cares for them, and feeds them, come to the conclusion that He will take care of you and feed you, oh, ye of little faith ! A boy asked if he might sweep the snow from the steps of a house. The lady of the household said : "Yes; you seem very poor." He says: "I am very poor." She pays: "Don't you sometimes get dis- couraged, and feel that God is going to let you starve?" The lad looked up in the woman's face and said : "Do you think God will let me starve when I trust Him, and then do the best I can?" Enough sheology for older people! Trust in God and do the best you can, Amidst all the morriments of housekeening go to Him . mostimiento or monochechine, go oo man, He will help you control your temper, and supervise your domestics, and entertain your guests, and manage your home econo- mies. There are hundreds of women weak, and nervous, and exhausted with the cares of housekeeping. I commend you to the Lord Jesus Christ as the best adviser, and she most efficient aid, who performed His first miracle to relieve a housekeeper. I learn also from the miracle that Christ does things in abundance. I think a small supply of wine would have made up for the deficiency. I think certainly they must have had enough for half of the guests. One gallon of wine will do; certainly five gal- lons will be enough; certainly ten. But Jesus goes on, and he gives them thirty gallons, and forty gallons, and fifty gallons, and seventy gallons, and one hundred gal- mons, and one nundred and thirty gations of the very best wine. It is just like Him, doing everything on The largest and most generous scale. Does Christ, our Creator, go forth to make leaves? He makes them by the whole forest full; motched like the fern, or silvered like the aspen, or broad like the palm; thickets in the tropics, Oregon forests. Does He go Sorth to make flowers? He makes plenty of shem; they flame from the hedge, they hang from the top of the grapevine in blos- soms, they roll in the blue wave of the violets, they toss their white surf into the spiræa-enough for every child's hand a lower, enough to make for every brow a shaplet, enough with beauty to cover up the ghastliness of all the graves. Does He go forth to create water? He pours it out, not by the cupful, but by a river full, a

articles.headline: Untitled Snippet
articles.full_text: all the earth has enough to drink, a A enough with which to wash. Does Jesus, our Lord, provide redem tion? It is not a little salvation for the ST one, a little for the other; but enough f all-" Whosoever will, let him come." Ea man an ocean full for himself. Promises f the young, promises for the old, promis MO for the lowly, promises for the blind, for t ** halt, for the outcast, for the abandone Pardon for all, comfort for all, mercy f <u>____</u> all, heaven for all; not merely a cupful les monal aunnly, but one hundred and this gallons. Sorrow may endure, but jo ek cometh in the morning. at I remark further, Jesus does not shado y. the joys of others with His own griefs. H at might have sat down in that wedding an e, said: "I have so much trouble, so much poverty, so much persecution and the cro r, is of My face and of My sorrows shall be ca of My face and of My sorrows shall be car n- over all this group." So said not Jesu He said to Himself : " Here are two pe re sons starting out in the married life. Le 10 8- it be a joyful occasion. I will hide My ow n griefs. I will kindle their joy." There as N. many not so wise as that. I know a house n hold where there are many little children 18 where for two years the musical instrumer ì, has been kept shut because there has bee n trouble in the house. Alas for the folly 3- Parents saying, "We will have no Chris y mas tree this coming holiday because ther 18 has been trouble in the house. Hush the d laughing up stairs! How can there be an . joy when there has been so much trouble? d And so they make everything constantly doleful and send their sons and daughter n to ruin with the gloom they throw around r them. .6 Oh, my dear friends, do you not know l. those children will have trouble enough of t their own after a while? Be glad they car t. not appreciate all yours. Keep back th cup of bitterness from your daughter's lips of When your head is down in the grass of th g tomb, poverty may come to her, bereave ment to her. Keep back the sorrows a 8 long as you can. Do you not know that so 3- 0 may, after a while, have his heart broken 3. Stand between him and all harm. You may h not fight his battles long; fight them whil 0 you may. Throw not the chill of your own u despondency over his soul; rather oe iin Jesus, who came to the wedding hiding Hi - own grief and kindling the joys of others e So I have seen the sun, on a dark day 11 struggling amidst clouds, black, ragged and n s portentous, but after a while the sun, with e golden pry, heaved back the blackness e and the sun laughed to the lake, and the s lake laughed to the sun, and from horizon - to horizon, under the saffron sky, the water t | was all turned into wine. I learn from this miracle that Christ is not impatient with the luxuries of life. I was not necessary that they should have . e that wine. Hundreds of people have been married without any wine. When Chris y made the wine it was not a necessity, but . positive luxury. I think if circumstances , will allow, we have a right to the luxuries e of dress, the luxuries of diet and the luxuries of residence. We can serve Goo 1 drawn by golden-plated harness as certainly as when we go a-foot. Jesus Christ wil t dwell with us under a fine ceiling as well as . get wine made out of wtaer, drink as much of it as you can. f I learn, further, from this miracle, that Christ has no impatience with festal joy otherwise he would not have accepted the would not have done that which increased the hilarity. There may have been many would not have done that which increased he hilarity. There may have been many the miditely. Inche may make book mining in that room who were happy, but there was not one of them that did so much for the joy of the wedding party as Christ Him- self. He was the chief of the banqueters. When the wine gave out He supplied it and so, I take it, He will not deny us the jovs that are positively festal. I think the children of God have more right to laugh than any other people, and to clap their hands as loudly. There is not a single joy denied them that is given to any other people. Christianity does not clip the wings of the soul. Religion does not frost the flowers. What is Christianity? I take it to be simply a proclamation from the throne of God of emancipation for all the enslaved, and if a man accepts all the terms of that proclamation and becomes free, has he not a right to be merry? Sup- pose a lather has an elegant mansion and large grounds, to whom will he give the first privilege of the grounds! Will he say: "My children, you must not walk through these paths, or sit down under these trees or pluck this fruit. These are for outsiders. They may walk in them." No father would say anything like that. He would say, "The first privileges in all the grounds, and in all my house, shall be for my own children." And yet men try to make us believe that God's children are on the limits, and the chief refreshments and enjoyments of life are for outsiders, and not for His own children. It is stark atheism. There is no innocent beverage too rich for God's child to drink; there is no robe too costly for him to wear; there is no hilarity too great for him to indulge in, and no house too splendid for him to live in. Though tribulation and trial and hardship may come on to him, let him rejoice. "Rejoice in the Lord, ye righteous, and again I say rejoice." I remark again that Christ comes to us in the hour of our extremity. He knew the wine was giving out before there was any embarrassment or mortification. Why did He not perform the miracle soon ? Why wait until it was all gone, and no help could come from any source, and then come in and perform the miracle? This is Christ's way; and when He did come in, at the hour of extremity, He made first-rate wine, so that they cried out: "Thou has kept the good wine until now." Jesus in the hour of extremity! He seems to prefer that hour. You mourned ever your sins. You could not find the way out. You sat down and said: "God will not be merciful. He has cast me off;" but in that, the darkest hour of your history, light broke from the throne, and Jesus said; "Oh, wanderer, come home. I have seen all thy sorrows. In this, the hour of thy extremity, I offer thee pardon and everlasting life !"

articles.headline: Untitled Snippet
articles.full_text: Cantilever. The word cantilever is variously derived from cant, an external angle, and lever (Cas- sell's), and from Latin quanta libra, of what weight (Century Dictionary). The principle of a cantilever bridge is this: Take two see- saws and place them in a line, so that the ends of the two balanced boards shall be some distance apart; weight the outer ends, and lay a board between the inner ends. Now, if you've anchored the outer ends securely, you have a crude cantilever bridge. The piers of the bridge need not be directly under the center of the see-saw boards or cantilevers; they may be more or less under the ends of the cantilevers. The new Niagara bridge is a fair example of a cantilever bridge; the new Forth bridge is a perfect example, be- cause its cantilevers are accurately planned. How to Make a Map. A thorough knowledge of two elements is necessary in order to make a map, with a view to an accurate determination of the positions of places. These elements are lati- tude, or distance from the equator, and longi- tude, or distance east or west of the meridian adopted. Every map, whatever its size, must have some definite relation to the actual size of the globe. The scales of geographical maps range from about 800 miles to an inch (for maps of quarters of the globe) to 10 miles to an inch; those of topographical maps range from 1 inch to 25 inches to a mile. The ord- nance survey of Great Britain is made or mapped on a scale of 1-63,360 of nature, or one inch of paper to one mile of surface. The practice in this country is maintained very Hybrids Not Sterile. Instead of hybrids being sterile, the evi- dence is cumulative that sterile hybrids are the exception. In plants more sterility can be adduced in cases of undoubted species. The dwarf species of robinia, robinia hispida or rose acacia, is almost always sterile, and the well known Chinese wistara is sterile, except un- der special conditions, or in special seasons. Recently Mr. Veitch, the famous hybridizer of London, who has produced a large number of hybrids among a large number of genera, mostly, indeed, so far as is recorded, all fer- tile, produced a hybrid between species of rhododendrons that were themselves hybrids, thus showing that fertility followed through even two generations of hybrids.

articles.headline: EMIN PASHA.
articles.full_text: EMIN PASHA. leaving the Albert Nyanza has been general -some 200. In this forest for three weeks we lived on roots and fungi, and, though we hunted and fished, not a thing could we bring in. Of course our poor men died like dogs and we whites were just about pegged out when we reached food." This was written last August, when the expedition was still five months' journey from Zanzibar, which it has just reached. The facts recall the fierce controversy which raged in Europe over the route chosen. It was insisted that Stanley, to reach and re- neve Emin Pasna, should have taken one of three routes-from Mombassa through the British possessions northward to Wadelai; from Bagamoyo, in the German protecto- rate, directly to the Victoria Nyanza and across it, or, thirdly, from Bagamoyo to Lake Tanganyika and thence nortward. After receiving much advice from African explorers, Stanley embarked his expedition from Zanzibar, sailed around the southern part of Africa and up the west coast, and penetrated the country by way of the Congo. To understand his action and its results, a brief historical sketch must be studied. In 1874 the noted "Chinese" Gordon began the task of resuing Central Africa from barbarism and slave trade. He wrested a considerable section from the Arab slave hunters, and sent Emin Pasha,

At one time he had a native and Egyptian army of 2,000, had established many schools and missions and secured a nation of 6,000,000 people ir- against the slave trade. In the meantime. ets | El Mahdi, the "second Mohammed," had n. excited an Arab crusade and rebellion against the British-Egyptian government in the Soudan. He massacred the army of Hicks Pasha ca and captured most of the Soudan. Gordon's lla troops rebelled and murdered him, and hope from Egypt was cut off. El Mahdi then ns er- in turned upon Emin Pasha, but died (proba- bly by violence) before making an attack. ap and Emin was comparatively safe till st another Mahdi arose and the crusade re- ub vived. Years passed before the civilized world could gain any certain knowledge of lls Emin. Meantime, Stanley had completed he his early African explorations; the Congo is Free State had been established, with the he
se King of Belgium, Leopold, as its protector; the Germans and English had made a division of the east coast, each having its m own territory to operate in, and all parties nd
he
he joined in requesting Stanley to lead an ex- pedition to relieve Emin. As aforesaid, he rejected all suggestions. in and on the 25th of February, 1887, sailed from Zanzibar with an army of 600 picked en Zanzibarese and several English officers, in- ot cluding Major Barttelot, Surgeon Parke and Micasia, Ochison, Michigan, It in the the Alondino, Troup and Jamieson; 429 days later he was at Lake Albert Nyunza. It has taken him but 202 days to come thence to Zanzibar --- a fact of which his critics have much to say. but we must await his report to know the advantages of the route from the west. Up the Congo, and for some distance up the Aruwimi, he had comparatively free pro- gress; thereafter the march was a constant battle-against hostile natives much of the time, against disease all the time, and fre- quently against starvation; for the Arabs had in many places induced the negroes to destroy all the food on his line of march. He left his last depot June 28th, with 389 officers and men; he reached the friendly Ibwiri, Nov. 12th, with but 174; desertion, however, accounted for much of the loss. April 29th be reached Emin Pasha, but the latter was unwilling at first to leave his province. Later he consented. and on the 4th inst. they reached Bagamoyo, to the astonishment and delight of the civil- ized world, to whom the telegraph from that point soon made it known. His additions to science are wonderful. He has mapped out the entire course of the o Aruwimi and the great interior lakes, dis- covering the Albert Edward lake near the Albert Nynaza. He also discovered Mount Ruvenzori, 17,000 feet high, and made a fairly accurate estimate of the size of the great lakes, besides traversing the great y . topical forest, and adding immensely to our knowledge of the so called "high interior." articles.headline: BABYLAND.
articles.full_text: BABYLAND. i Have you heard of the Valley of Babyland. The realm where the dear little darlings stay σ. Till the kind storks go, as all men know, 0 And, oh, so tenderly bring them away? 0 The paths are winding and past all finding By all save the storks, who understand The gates and the highways and the intricate byways That lead to Babyland. All over the Valley of Babyland Sweet flowers bloom in the soft green moss, And under the ferns fair and under the plants there Lie little heads like spools of floss, With a soothing number the river of slumber Flows o'er a bedway of silver sand, And angels are keeping watch o'er the sleeping Babes of Babyland. The path to the Valley of Babyland Only the kingly, kind storks know; II filed ill over mountains or here come fountains, No man sees them come and go. But an angel maybe, who guards some baby, Or a fairy, perhaps, with her magic wand, Brings them straightway to the wonderful gateway. That leads to Babyland. And there, in the Valley of Babyland, Under the mosses, and leaves and ferns, Like an unfledged starling they find the darl- ing For whom the heart of a mother yearns; And they lift him lightly and snug him tightly In feathers soft as a lady's hand, And off with a rockaway step they walk away Out of Babyland. As they go from the Valley of Babyland Forth into the world of the great unrest, Sometimes weeping he wakes from sleeping Before he reaches the mother's breast. Ah, how she blesses him, how she caresses him. Bonniest bird in the bright home band

articles.headline: Untitled Snippet
articles.full_text: A Valuable Discovery. Uranium, a metal whose rarity is indicated by its market price, $12,000 per ton, was dis- covered just a hundred years ago, when Klaproth succeeded in isolating from a dark, colored mineral known as a pitchblende a yel- low oxide, which, after carefully testing, he pronounced to be the oxide of a new metal. Up to the present time it has only been met with in isolated pockets and patches, but now, according to the London Times, the centenary of its discovery has been marked by the ...nding of a continuous lode at the Union mine, Grampound Road, Cornwall, which is believed to be the only known lode in the world. This discovery is regarded as unique in the history of the metal, for the lode is what is known as a true fissure vein, see we of the ore moun as high as 30 ner with moon la or and ore to the we will see on bear cent. It is anticipated that the present discovery will enable two important applications of the metal to be followed up. The first is a substitute for gold in electro-plated ware, masmuch as with platinum and copper it forms two beautiful alloys, each having the appearance of gold, and the former also re- sisting the action of acids. The second appli- cation is in connection with electric insula- tions, where its usefulness consists in its high electrical resistance.

articles.headline: COTTING.
articles.full_text:
COTTING. The Dressed Beef Investigation. Mr. P. D. Armour reconsidered his d termination to ignora Senator Vest'a con mittee and appeared in Washington son time since with his attorneys and clerk His testimony is entirely too long for or columns, being for the most part an essa on cattle production, drawn up by his atto neys. He denies being a member of an combination to decrease prices, and main tains that the decrease is the result of over production-that his profits are not large they being for the year 1888 only $418 104 40 or $1.20 per head on the number of cattle killed. and the second of the second of the second At the conclusion of the reading of th paper the following colleguy occurred; "There is then," Senator Vest asked "ne combination between yourself and th other packers except one to prevent ruinou loss ?" "Yes, that is all. We have such a arrangement with some of our neighbors." "Whom do you mean by your neighbor -Nelse Morris, Swift and Hammond ?" "No, Hammond is not in it. Not all the beef men of the country are parties the arrangement." "Well, who are in it?" "I do not think, Senator, you care t insist upon my answering that question." "Then you never were in a combinatio with anyone else in buying cattle, or i somme meer or meke . "No, pir." "What, did you not have a sort of poo of hogs in 1886?" "There was an arrangement in 1886 as t hoge, but it did not kill prices. Ther were eighteen men in the the deal, and each one paid in twenty-five for each hog killed That was all." " Have you any arrangement now with your competitors as to prices in certain districts of the country ?" "Absolutely none." "Have you any contract or agreemen with other dressed meat men as to division of territory ? "Senator, I have made a very frank state ment to this committee. As to this ques tion, I beg to be excused." "Is it not a fact that you, Swift and Morris have an arrangement by which contracts to supply Government institu tions-for instance, the National Insen Asylum, of this city-are filled by one o you one week, by another the second, and the last the third week ?" "Not to my knowledge. I will say that know but little about such details as that We have an agent in this city, and he might make such a deal as that and I neve know it. But it is not like the principles o the house, and I am sure the parent house would not indorse such conduct on the par of its agent." "Have you any agreement with other houses of any so.t?" "Not to my knowledge." "Has your house ever taken any steps to force butchers to buy your beef?" "Never put down the prices in order to crowd out a rival?" "() aly once at Akron, Ohio." "Never at Pittsburg, or Freeland, Penn- sylvania ? " No. sir." "I will state to you, Mr. Armour, that is has been testified before this committee that yon sent a certain telegram to Freeland, in which you declared a certain man should be torced to do as you wished. I will read the dispatch: CHICAGO, Da sember 18th .- H. P. LACE, FREELAND, PENNSYLVANIA: Cannot allow Schwab to kill live cattle. If he won't come to our terms, make prices to bring him ARMOUR & Co. around. "I never sent that dispatch," said witness. "I do not endorse its sentiment, and es- pecially object to its phraseology. Though some of our agents do kill cattle, we do not as a rule like to have them do so. Our position is that they cannot well serve us both. Probably Schwab was about to be- come an sgent of ours, or had been an agent. He is not now." "Have you ever reprimanded the man who sent that dispatch? Is he still in your employ!" "Some of the best men I have fall by the wayside once in a while, play poker, or something like that, and I do not dis- charge for it." Here Senator Plumb took the witness in hand and brought out the fact that cattle from a large section of the country are taken to Chicago for sale. He asked : "Is the competition of sellers at Chicago met there by a similar competition of buy. ers?" "Yes, there are probably from fifty to one hundred buyers in that market, and the competition between them is fair and keen.' "Do your buyers compete with those of Swift and Nelse Morris? "Certainly. They go in and bid on a lot of cattle after Swift's buyer or Morris' buyer has made a bid." "I will inform you, Mr. Armour, that all the cattleman who have been before na say this is not so. They declare the competition of buyers is not a fair composit Do you make dummy bids, taling core not to outbid one another and them divide the cattle purchased at a lower price ?" r. Armour. " I state positively," said that there never was such a thing as the high man nulling out, leaving the cattle to go to the lowest bidder with a division of spoils afterward among the parties to the bargain. There is just as much competition there in the buying of cattle as there is in the selling of beef and pork. Abuy as cheap as I can and sell as dear as I can and my understanding in that that is what "Do you know that the wattlemen of the country say there is not fair competition in
buying at the Chicago yards?" cattle to us, just the same. Cattlemen talk so much about the terrible 'big four' that they make themselves believe anything without knowing the facts, but I do net think a majority of the cattlemen believe this charge. The Rebellion In the North-west has been suppressed and our citizens can now devote reasonable at- tention to their corns. The only sure, safe and painless remedy is Putnam's Painless Cora Extractor. It never falls, never makes sore spots worse than the original discomfort See that you get "Patnam's," and take none other.

When he was stationed in Canada, Lord Wolseley (he was not Lord Wolseley then, but that doesn't matter) spent a holi- day in the interior, where he and his attend ant built a wigwam and enjoyed the peace- ful solitude of nature. He had not then seen an Indian chief, and his knowledge of
the individual was derived chiefl, from the perusal of the works of Fenimore Cooper.
He had a desire to see the real article, and
some friends of his living twenty miles away promised to send along the first Indian chief they met. One morning Lord Wolse. ley was informed that a nobleman of the West, had arrived. With his mind full of the conventional picture of the high souled, noble-minded red man, he went out and found a gentleman clothed in an out-of- date dress suit and waistcoat, who, having had a great deal to do with the Hudson Bay traders, knew a smattering of French and of English. He talked incessantly for upwards of an hour and at the expiration of that time our only General became bored. Fieling in his pocket for a coin, he pro- duced a two-shilling piece, and with some fear that he was grossly insulting his guest offered it to him. The noble Indian looked at it carefully, felt the edges, and said, "Can you make it half crown?" You sturdy oak whose branches wide Boldly the storms and winds dety. Not long ago an acorn, small, Lay dormant 'neath the summer sky. Not malike the thrifty oak in its germ.

Ben jamin Butterworth, of Cincinnati, has in troduced a bill into Congress. which, i passed, will effectually secure reciprocity between Canada and the United States, so far as the latter is concerned, of a most unrestricted character. Mr. Butterworth was one of the first to realize how im- portant to the country at large would be an extension of its commerce beyond the line of separation between the two countries, and four years ago moved re- solutions with a view of obliterating the customs barrier between the two coun- tries. articles.full_text: lis The progress of the negotiations for the a meeting of Emperor William and the nd Czar on the Polish frontier in April i ne tensfies the official anxiety and watchfu iis ness in Austria. In diplomatic circl ce there is a lively discussion of the prospo- 111 of a renewal of the German entente wit II Russia. As Bismarck continues to fin ts the want of homogeneity in the Austria empire, and the growing discord between its various nationalites, and obstacles t good politics, and sees how greatly thes reduce the value of an Austrian alliance it is said he already contemplates a radical change of base in his policy, and specu lates upon a large application of the ide of races that was the basis of so many actionics and projects when Alsace and Lorraine were annexed to Germany. f His new application of the theory o y bringing all Gorman speaking people un der the German flag would be at the ex- pense of both Austria and Russia, but for Russia there would be compensations. The policy, in fact, would wipe out Aus- tria, as that empire now stands, for Ger- many would take the Austro-German duchies, and while Germany would also get the German Baltic province now held by Russia, Russia would get an equivalent in Galicia and Bokhara and would be given a free hand in Roumania and the Balkan countries. The Austrian govern- ment knows this is not merely a diplom- atic idea, but is one of the present possi- bilities of the Chancellor's policy and man of the Chancemor a policy and may become a probability. If the race feuds now pervading the empire, combined with hostility to Germany, shall force the chancellor to project alliances elsewhere. Richmond, Va., 5th.—The Dispatch prints a letter written by J. Wilkes Booth on the day he assassinated President Lin- coin. Its publication is said to have suppressed by the Government in 1865. In his opening Booth foreshadows his ter- rible deed when he says: "Right or wrong, God judge, not man, for be my motives good of bad, of one thing I am sure, the lasting condemnation of the -. ith. I leve prace more than life."

articles.headline: THE OTTAWA ELECTION CASE
articles.full_text: THE OTTAWA ELECTION CASE Judgment was rendered on Mond annulling the election of Mr. Roc the Legislative assembly for the el district of Ottawa, on the 14th Sept 1887. The court found evidence rupt acts by agents, sufficient to an election, but rejected the deman disqualification. The defendant i demned to all costs, which amou several thousand dollars. Jette J., delivered an elaborate ment, in the course of which he re first to certain preliminary obje I. Was the petition served with delay fixed by law? 2. Was the e al district correctly described in the tion? 3. Was the petition pr stamped? His Honor held that th vice was regular; that the insertion word "county" before Ottawa w material; and that the objection the stamps was unfounded. Comi the merits of the election, the cour up first the cases relied on for the qualification of the defendant. were four in number. 1st, The c Dr. Routhier. It was alleged tha defendant gave Routhier a promissery for $250 to induce him to vote for de ant, or to refrain from voting against After reviewing the evidence by wh had been attempted to support this ch His Honor came to the conclusion the accusation was not proved. The so case was that of G. Aubry, who, it suid, had received $50 with defend knowledge, to be spent in bri The evidence showed that Aubry rece $50, but as to the defendant's knowle the evidence was contradictory and court felt bound to give him the be of the doubt. The other two cases r on were also rejected by the court, the result was that the demand for qualification must be rejected. A the acts of agents, however, they numerous and clearly proved. The tion organization was vigorous, and t engaged therein appeared to have for and the property of and the and ten the severe provisions of the law on subject of corrupt practices. Neverthe these same persons, some of whom v members of one or other legislature, always eager to vote for even greater st gency which they afterwards pronou impracticable, and when the courts called upon to apply the law, there i general outcry against what is terr an arbitrary interpretation. Ottawa very large county, and if the paymen canvassers was admissible at all, it wo be in such an extensive constituen But section 407 of the act absolut prohibits such payments. In this elect a large sum had been subscribed for penses, and the agents did not seem lear notions of the distinct more rely clear motività or the distille between legal and illegal payments. Ca vassers were employed and paid; cart were paid; committee rooms were hire with more regard to the influence on t proprietors than to the rent; and this I on one side only, but on the part of bo candidates. A patrol was organized Hull whose members received pay each night and a supper, suitably water was served at midnight in a restaurant Hull. All this was done under the ey of the principal members of the ganization, and with their entire approb tion. In the presence of this unrestrict expenditure, it was unnecessary to go i to particular cases, and the court ha no hesitation in declaring the election har more no don nuil. As to the costs, they were no dou enormous, but the defendant had assume the responsibility by his stubborn con testation of the charges made by the pet tioner. He should have consented to the setting aside of the election as soon a sufficient proof had been made. The de mand as to the mis en cause Cormier wa dismissed with costs. Davidson, J .- I fully concur in the judg ment pronounced by the learned presiden of the court. The respondent has been i imminent peril. He escapes because he ha been given the benefit of the doubt. Th case affords an impressive instance of th serious defects which are inherent in th controverted election act of this province The election complained of was upon th 14th September 1001 -- over two years ago yet this petition has only now come to ar gament and judgment. In that interva enough evidence has been put on record to void a dozen elections, but the respon dent would not yield and the petitione would risk nothing. So every one of the corrupt acts charged against respondent's agent's was probed to the bottom, evidence now covering some 700 or 800 printed pa- ges was taken, and all the time the enquete judge sat powerless to close the proceed. ings or to apply a remedy. Authority ought to lie in his hands to summarily end an investigation when sufficient proof has been made to satisfy the purpose of the petition, and he ought also to be able to at once pronounce judgment or, if he chooses, o refer the record to the full bench. The present procedure is disas- trous to the efficient disposal of election petitions and involves one, or other, and sometimes both of the parties, in costs more enormous than any which attach to any other class of litigation. consent to serve For some time past the reports from Russia as to plots against the Czar's life have been very persistent. Disaffection was said to exist in the army, and all the signs pointed to a revival of the dreadful activities of the nihilists. These gloomy tidings are followed by the definite state- ment that the Czar's recent attack of sup- posed influenza was really an attempt to poison him. The unfortunate monarch will now have to provide himself with a taster as did the imperial tyrants of old. Dynamite and poison are not pleasant things for the Russian ruler to contem- plate, but he has at least the satisfaction of reflecting that he has no Grits within the boundaries of his vast dominions.

articles.headline: CHAPTER II. - DREAMERS.
articles.full_text: CHAPTER II. - DREAMERS. Took's Court, Chancery Lane, has not very sunny outlook even on the brightest o days; it is shut in on all sides, except at the narrow entrance, by tall antique houses with dusty shelves over their doorways and dusty stone steps belew. The open window shutters, begrimed with many coatings o onden smoke, are fastened by rusty hock against the walls. Adull wintry patch o sky hangs overhead; and from there a twi light falls upon hurrying figures-with their echoing footsteps and flitting shadows- passing in and out of this old courtyard When the evening becomes still more gloomy, and the patch of sky is a mere patch of black, a dismal street lamp in the centre of the Court threws a glimmer through its dusty panes upon the houses or each side; and where the blinds are not yet drawn, and there is no stronger light to op pose it, this modest gleam enters a room quite boldly. There is one room in particu- lar, in which a young girl is seated over cheerless fire, where this ghost of a light looks in; and it only seems to add to the cheerless surroundings. For the room is small, dingy, and threadbare in ap- pearance. The carpet is worn in places almost to the boards; and there are splashes of ink on the floor, and even on the walls, as if a shower of writing fluid had recently wiien. Although simply dressed in a dark serge, the girl appears out of place in the midst of such obvious poverty. There is little in her look and mapner to suggest contentment, or even submission. The knitted brow, the curl of the pretty lips, the expressive pressure of the fingers against the dark hair, indicate a self-willed and sensitive nature ; and so abscribed is she in her own thoughts, that neither the sound of a peculiar step in the courtyard, nor even the rattling of a latchkey in the door, attracts her attention. It is only when a lean shabby-looking man with a wizened face comes in that the girl starts and glances up. She tries bravely to hide her dejection with a little laugh as she holds out her hand to welcome him to a place beside her on the hearth. "Dreaming again, Rosa?"-and while speaking, the man sat down before the fire and began to warm his hands. "Dreaming again?" His tone, although reproachful, was not wanting in affection. "I was wondering," said she, while strok- ing a large black cat on the hearthrug at her feet, whether the impressions of my child- hood-the time seems so distant-could be mere fancy? How old was I, dad, when you first took me in?' The man regarded Rosa thoughtfully. "How old? Between five and six.-But I can't fix a date, my dear," he added; "that's impossible. Your birthday, you know, wasn t spoken of." Pausing a mo- ment to tap a little wooden box, he extract- ed a pinch of snuff and then resumed as though speaking to himself: "No; he was a reticent party, he was" -- and he shook recollection_"a very retisent

articles.full_text: UIS HERG REELIGITECTION ..... party indeed." "Twelve years ago," said Rosa-"twelve years to-day ?" "This very day. Twelve years this after. noon, my dear, since he left you under our care. And that's why," he added, "we call this your birthday. And now, as he shifted his reat to the table and leant over a portable desk with his back to the window, it became appear- ent that he and this little parlour must have grown inky and threadbare together. The man s face was sallow and creased like parchment that has been kept in the dusty corner of a lawyer's office for years; and his scanty hair was of a gray dingy colour that might have belonged to a dusty corner too. And yet the man's appearance could scarcely have failed to awaken sympathy. It was kindly in expression, and and there was something irresistibly pathetic in the gray watery eyes. "Then I am seventeen to-day," said the girl-"or am I eighteen? I think I must be eighteen, dad, 'she went on in a thoughtful mood, "for some of my dreams, as you call them, seem like reality .- What was the gentleman like?' "The party was keen-featured." Then he added musingly: "I should know him again among a thousand," "He never told you my name?" "Why, no. You told us that," said the man. " Mother asked you as soon as he was gone. "Rosa," says you. -But as to your surname, we never could make that out." "Ah! If we only knew my name," said ow voice " von would have THE MILI III OF TOM ADICE! Jose House found out long ago whether the home which I have so often told you about was really mine; and whether that beautiful face-a face bending over my pillow at night-was the face of my own mother. It sometimes seems to me as if it must have been true," she added, with a look of discontent return- ing to her face. "Is it not a shame, if my parents are rich, that I should live in such poverty as this?" The old man looked troubled. He took a quill pen from behind his ear and began to stroke his chin agitatedly, and looked at the girl and then at his deak. "Rosa," said he, presently breaking the silence, "what is the use, my dear, of thinking so much about the past? It leads to no good; it only makes one wretched.-Not that I've any right to expect," he added in an almost humble tone, that removed any suspicion of irony, "that a young lady born in the lap of luxury -if I may so express myself-could easily lead herself to take a much brighter view of this life. Before we came to town-before mother died-there were fields to run about in, and you were younger. But there's a bit of garden in New Square, just across Chancery Lare; and there's Lincoln's Inn Fields hard by; and when one listens to the sparrows, though it ain's much of a song, it makes one farcy, as the birds must do, that the spring ain't very far off now." The brightening hopeful lookon careworn features which accompanied these She words brought a smile to Rosa's lips. left her seat and went and laid her hand tenderly on the man's shoulder. "Daddy," sail she with a repentant look, "I will try to be more reasonable: I will try to think less about my sunny childhood. I always ge; dreaming more on my birthday, as we ca'l it, than at any other time. Don't I?" The man nodded and smiled. "But, daddy, I was not thinking alto- ge her about myself," she went on, "though I know I'm very selfish; I was thinking, if I could find my beautiful mother, that I could tell her what a father you had been
