I to me; and she would make you rich and happy." "Would she? Ah, my dear," said the man, shaking his head increduously, "you don't know the world.—But I'm forgetting," he suddenly added, with a glance towards . the window. "I'm expecting a visitor; he may be here at any moment!" "A visitor!" "I've been calling, as I was advised, at Pikington s," the man explained, "and—"Pikington!" She spoke scarcely above a whisper. "How that name reminds me of my old home! "And," t me, sent out a message to say that as soon n over and have a talk about the work. There's vacancy in the office; and it looks very much as if I should get the post. weeks the poor clerk had been out of employ-
ment, and his slender savings were exhaust- ed. He had confessed to Rosa only yester- day that the last shilling nad been changed, and that unless he got work they would have to face a serious situation. But he did not lose heart : he assured her that it was though it might meanstarvation—than break down in tears as she had done. Rosa thought of his words row, as she stood at the window and looked out into the she heard a quick step below, and saw a young man with a handsome face stop at their door and raise the knocker. She could see him glancing up at her by the street Sidney Trench-for it was he-having knocked at the old house in Took's Court, again glanced towards the window; and the glimpse he gained of the girl by the dim light thrown upon her set him wondering. Where had he seen that pretty dark face before? Next mement the door opened and the dark face was looking up inquiring-
ly at him. And now, so familiar did her
whole appearance seemed to Sidney, that he could scarcely suppress a smile of recogni- tion. Where had they met, and when? These questions rose to his lipe; but he could not give them utterance. He could only look at the girl in silent wonder and admiration. It was like a dream-scene that had flashed a only to yet and hawilder fuloritum night out and some some him. "Do you wish to see Mr Norris?" Her voice scarcely recalled him; for it przzled him, too, little less than the face. "Yes. Does be live here?" She led the way into the parlour. "He will be with you directly. -Are you Mr Trench ?" He was standing with his back towards the window. The girl lingered at the door, and was glancing at him with modest curios ity. Was it his tancy, or was there a look of recognition in her eyes too? He hastened to answer her. "My name is Trench-Sidney Trench. Have I the pleasure to address Miss Norris?' She hesitated a moment before answering; then she looked up into his face and said; " Me name is Rosa." An exclamation nearly escaped him. But at this moment the older clerk came in with a light. It was an antique reading-lamp, of which the glass was broken. Rosa went out, and Abel Norris closed the dcor. "Pray, be seated, sir;" and Sidney sat down by the fireside where the girl had been dreaming not many minutes before. Norris placed himself at his desk; he was more at his ease in that position. Taking the quill from his ear, he dipped it in the ick with some show of energy, such is the force of habit; then he waited for Sidney to speak. "You have had some years' experience." the young man suggested, "in a lawyer's cffi se ?" "Fifty, sir; fifty years, and one or two to

articles.headline: Untitled Snippet
articles.full_text: area "Your wife?" "That's what I should say-my wife. For when she died," he resumed, "we thought we would seek our fortune, so to speak. We have met with nothing but misfortune." "I'm sorry to hear that," said Sidney sympathetically; "and I hope your fortune will now mend." For a moment the young lawyer looked thoughtful. He then resumed : "All that I have heard about you," said he "makes me anxious, if I can, to serve you. And I would offer you without hesitation a place in our office; but I find it impossible to do so." Sidney Trench, without turning his head, glanced towards the old clerk; for he heard the pen drop from the man's fingers. He now observed that he was pressing his hands to his head in a despairing attitude. There was a lengthy pause. Sidney felt that after his conversation with Mr Pilking. ton, he would be acting decidedly in opposi- tion to his wishes if he engaged this clerk. How, then, could he serve one who appeared so deserving? He had roused his interest; and was he not also interested in the dark eyes that had looked up into his face when he came in? The young lawyer turned to the clerk. "Mr Norris," said he, "I have something to propose. Although I cannot promiee, at least not at once, a situa- tion in our office, there is no reason why you should not work here. I want some deeds and other documents copied. Will you undertake to do this for me? Norris briskly picked up his pen. "Here, sir, at my desk? It is the method I should prefer." "Is it? Then you shall begin, 'added the young man, taking a cheque from his pocket, "put this in your desk." The old clerk could not speak; but his trembling outstretched hand and the tears that sprang to his eyes expressed his grati- tude. "You have no family?" Sidney present. ly remarked. "No, sir, none," said Norris; "only Ross. Sidney regarded the man keenly. "The young girl who'-he hesitated slightly- "who let me in!" "Yes "Ab," said Sydney, assuming indifference, "a grandchild, perhaps?" "An adopted daughte ."-After a mo-

articles.full_text: .. How comes it that you call the girl Ross ?" "Ah ! we were just talking about that, sir, before you came. She told us herself that her name was Rosa; and that was all she could tell us, though we questioned her over and over again." Sidney Trench, thinking over all that he had learnt from Abel Norris, began to recall to mind in a dreamy way his early boyhood. He had had a playmate in those days-not little sweetheart. She was a child, he could well remember, with dark serious eyes and a willful manner. But he had been sent away to a school in Swi'zerland for three years, and she had gone out of his young life; for when he returned to England she was never spoken of in his presence. But d impressed him deen- an incident, which had impressed him deep ly, had one day occurred. Mr Pilkington had been appointed his guardian by Sidney's father, the late senior partner. It was a grave responsibility. Sidney Trench was a very young; and Mr P.Ikington, even at that time, was getting on in years; and should he die (this was when Sidney was fourteen), all the legal secrets—as fa as Trench, Pilkington, and Trench were roon cerned-would die with him. To read be tween the lines of legal documents which ay in deed-boxes in every corner of the old house would be impossible; and the calamity, if it came about, could only be compared to the loss of a bunch of keys which could never be replaced; for the clients would take their secrets elsewhere, and the great firm would dwindle into comparative insignificance. The very thought of such a mishap—as Sid- ney had been taught to believe in his won- dering boyhood-was enough to shorten his guardian's life. So, one day, in his youthful simplicity, he had ventured to put the quest'on to Mr Pilkington: " Is my little sweet heart, sir a legal secret;?' For the thought that his guardian might die, and he might never learn what had become of tha child, was the subject which troubled him most. But he had no sooner made this inquiry han he wished he had held his peace; for the follow- ing day Mr Pilkington sent him back to school, though the holidays were only half over. He never again ha the courage to question his guardian. This old dread of Mr Pilkington-though so many years had gone by -recurs to Sidney when he goes that evening to join him in the library; for he is but a boy compared to this aged lawyer, and the fear of offending him is still within him. And yet, if he had yearned in his boy hood to know something about that "little sweet. heart he is yearning even more now to solve the mystery of her disappearance. Mr. Pilkington is warming his wrinkled hand over the library fire; he looks at the young man under his thick eyebrows. Can Mr. Pilkington have observed-for they had met at dinner an hour or two after Sidney's visit to Took's Court-that Sidney is re- volving some problem in his own mind? Something in the old lawyer's manner as he bends and warms his hand suggests an un- usual sternness. "Sidney," says he, and he voice is stern too-"sit down and listen to me. -At least," he adds as the young man takes a chair beside the hearth-'aisten,

His silence does not dispel Mr Pilkington's displeasure; it seems to add sensibly to his irritation. "Be careful, Sidney"-the old lawyer admonishes him, raising his forefinger impressively. "A secret character-a man who does not confide in his friend-deserves no compassion! (TO BE CONTINUED.) The Etrongest of Women. The strongest woman on earth has not been long in making her appearence at the music halls, and, according to accounts, it she had visited the Aqualium some few weeks ago she might almost have entered the lists with Cyclops, for she seems to think nothing of would scarcely have been necessary to shear his locks. She might have gained her object by main force. Mme. Victorine, as I believe this muscular lady is called, is a Swiss, and for many years was ignorant of her extraordi endeavoring to life a nuge lender from cart. Smiling at their unsaccessful efforts she volunteered her aid, and, to their extreme surprise, accomplished the feat unassisted, The story reaching the cars of an eager exhibitor, overtures for introducing her to an admiring public were instantly made, and after a few weeks of severe training she made her first appearance. She is indeed a pro- digy, for in adition to her really marvellous strength she is not, like so many wonders, unplessant to look upon, but is extremely fair of form and face. This makes the third exhibition of unusual muscle in London, for Samson still has a number of admirers and sympathizers, while Sandow is drawing crowds at the Alhambra. A Trillion Kisses. The case of the Plymouth man who had his love-letters produced and read in court, should teach other lovers moderation in the making of osculatory contracts, says London
Tit Bits. In a single postscript the Ply- of his choice no fewer than 1,000,000,000,000 kisses, and as such contracts are not infre- quently made in love-letters, it may be well to give a thought to the magnitude of the undertaking. Whoever will take the trouble to figure it out will find that even if this amorous man ahould give the lady 15,000 kisses a minute (and we affirm that no person could hope to do more than that), and even if he could keep up this rate of osculation twenty-four hours a day, never pausing to sleep, eat, or take breath, working 365 days every year, it would take him more than 100 years to complete the contract, and by that time, it would be painful to reflect, the ardour of his love may have cooled. Even at the end of 100 years, counting 15,000 kisses a minute, there would remain an undelivered balance of 200,000,000,000, a number which in itself might appal the most industrious. We therefore feel con- strained to advise writers of love letters not to undertake contracts of such magnitude. Esquimalt Graving Dock. It is said that the British Government will soon be asked to contribute to the cost of lengthening the graving dock at Esqui- malt, British Columbia. The amount orgri- naily granted for the construction of this dock was $250,000, and now another $50,000. being just half the sum needed for the work, is applied for. It has been discovered that the dock, which is only 430 feet in length. will not be nearly long enough for the mail steamers which the Canadian Pacific Rail- way Company is constructing, and as the British Government is greately interested in the new mail service it is though that it will not be unwilling to aid in the improve- ment of the dock .- [N. Y . Times.

Her Majesty resolutely declares that however much she may suffer from dyspepsis in the future, nothing will induce her to take the same remedy. Queen Isabella's remark concerning the Brazilian revolution-"Decidedly the Al- mighty is no longer on our side' -which is going the rounds to-day, has a character- istic Bourbon flavor which has revived memory of an even more audacious effort on the part of a distinguished representative of the same family. It was Louis X'V who, upon being told of a series of disasters en- tailed by the English upon his troops, in- dignantly exclaimed, "Surely, the Almighty has forgotten all I have done for Him. Any one who walks through the woods at this season will note the deep velvety carpet of fallen leaves which covers the ground. Few realize how much protection this affords against frost. So long as land is sheltered enough to prevent winds from blowing away the leaves it is not apt to freeze very deeply. The leaves act as a mulch in the summer time, and this encour- ages a growth of roots near the surface. When the woods become thinned out so that winds sweep them bare, the soil often freezes down so as to kill the trees. No matter how hardy a tree may be, it cannot live when the soil freezes down to the depth of the roots. The trade of the same of the same of the same of the same of the same of the same of the same of the same of the same of the same of the same of the same of the same of the same of the same of the same of the same of the s A gentleman who has recently returned from Lisbon relates the following strange coincidences in connection with the death of the late King of Portugal. It appears that when the Cathedral bell at Braganza, the ancient residence of the Portuguese Royal family, was tolling for the death of Queen Marie 11., mother of the late King Luiz 1, in 1853, it cracked, In 1861 when the castle ensign was hoisted half-mast high at Bragarz 1, on the occasion of the death of King Padro V., brother of the late King, it was torn to pieces immediately by the storm. At the death of King Luiz 1. last month the Cathedral bell again cracked and the castle ensign was again tern to shreds by the wind.

Lord Wolseley Lectures in England Upon this Famous March. From the London Times, Dec. 9. On Saturday evening Lord Wolseley deliv- ered a lecture at Toynbee Hall, Whitechapel, or the "Red River Expedition," to a large up to the sending of the expedition. On the Dominion of Canada being created, among the provinces handed over to the Govern ment was the country known as Prince Rupert's Land, the inhabitants of which had descended from Frenchmen who had intermarried with squaws. The half-breeds objected to being handed over to the control of tue Canadian Government, or, as they them- up a form of government under the leader- ship of a man named Riel, who had been boupset this ridiculous government, as well as to bring Riel to justice that the expedition was sent. Lord Welseley's small army consisted of artillery, infantry and engineers. Then arose the questied how were they to get Canada. The route was 600 miles in length, and a greater portion of this was nothing but a howling wilderness with a large number of lakes. From start to finish there was a great rush, and men, who were only half fed, had to work in a way he had never before or since witnessed. Owing to the difficulties they met with the clothes the men wore became very disreputable; and as the flour which they carried was used the hage total to means their breeches. He was told before bad that the expedition would ever reach its destination, and that if He replied: "I have been told to go to rort shall get there." From start to finish the only stimulant the men had was a drop of tes, and not a man was lost. Lord Wolesley referred in amusing terms to the manners of without drawing breath for half an hour, and had he only been in England he would have been made, at least, a county councilor. Sir William Butler was able to render him invaluable assist- On nearing Fort Garry they found Riel had bolted, and he must confess there was a certain amount of dissapointment among the men at not having a little amusement with the enemy. They then took possession of the fort, raised the Union Jack and gave
three cheers for the Queen. That was prac- tically the termination of the expedition, which was accomplished by the combination of disciplined influence, by fine manly British spirit, and with a determination to carry out the mission with which they had been intrusted. It was by such feelings, as that on the part of our soldiers and sailors this great British Empire had been built up, and as long as that feeling existed in the naval and military forces they might never despair of the future of their great empire. Hotels in Mid-Ocean. A new thing under the sun is proposed by Captain J. P. Walker, a retired officer of the army of the United States. This latest Utopia is nothing less than a scheme by which the ocean shall be robbed of its terrors. Capt. Walker proposes to build a number of light-houses, houses of refuge, and hotels and plant themein the midst of the sea, anchoring them at intervals between New York and Queenstown. "From this beginning he proposes to go on un-
til all oceans and seas shall be detted with these structures, all connected with each other and with the continents and islands of the earth by telergraphic cable, and supplied with vessels of various kinds, which, with their crews, will constitute a deep-sea messenger, telegraphic, and life- savi ug service. 'While it would, perhaps, be going too far to declare that the realization of such a scheme is impossible, still there are difficulties involved which render it quite impracticable and improbable. Chief among these is the financial question. Though syndicates abound and millions of money are represented as being paid for this and the other industry, it is doubtful whether our modern Cræsuses could be induced to undertake any project which is so purely an experiment. It is not so sure a thing as buy- ing up breweries, distilleries and such like. Therefore until this question of cash is satis- factorily settled it will be just as well for those who seek summer resorts not to pre- maturely felicitate themselves upon the comforts and pleasures in store for them.

articles.full_text: There are an astonishing number of people in this world who had to live one Landred years before any one ever heard of them At the Birmingham Show the Queen took a first priz , 100 guineas, with a Shorthorn bred upon her own farm near Windsor, and she also gained eight other prizes. One of her Hereford steers weighed 1,960 pounds. and another beautiful Shorthorn steer scaled 2,408 pounds. On Friday last took place the annual sale of fat stock belonging to Her Majesty. There was a large attend- ance of buyers from all parts of the country and excellent prices were realized. The Queen takes great delight in this annual tunction, always inspects the stock previous to the sale, and gives the people who attend a good old fashioned English luncheon, with plenty of roast beef and beer. articles.headline: LASHED INTO WEALTH.
articles.full_text: LASHED INTO WEALTH. Mago's One Hundred Lushes Started His Five Million Dolla's. John James Mago, a middle aged, well dressed man, has been in San Francisco, says the "Examiner" of that city, for a few days waiting for the Mexican steam or to sail. H looks prosaic, but his career is as romantic as that of Monte Cristo. Mago is now o Guatemalan millionaire, who lives nine months of the year at Paris. Fifteen years ago he was a poor Eaglish collector of insects in Guatemala, and also acted as British Vice Consul at San Jose. One day Commandant Gonzales ordered Mago to appear before him. Mago sent word he would come in a short time. This incensed the commandant, who was ugly with drink, and he sent a file of soldiers after Mago, and when the bug collector appeared ordered seventy five lash- es laid on his bare back. This was done thoroughly, and when finished Gozzales shouted: "Give him twenty five more for lack." When Mago recovered, which was only after careful nursing, as his back was badly cut up, he made formal complaint to the British Government, The result was Gaute- mala was ordered to punish Gonzales, and to pay Mago $500 for every lash he received. In default of this English cruisers would shell San Jose and other coast cities. Guatemala readily punished Gonz sles, but tried hard to evade paying $50,000 to Mago. The Brit- ish, however, were inexorable, and the poor bug collector was made a rich man in one day. As he had more coin than any one in the country then President Barries entered into partnership with him. Mago became one of the largest coffee planters and also secured the exclusive fran- chise for building docks along the ports. No one can land on or leave one of these docks without paying $2 toll to Mago, while he also levies a tax on all freight. He also owns valuable mines and tracts of timber. His fortune is estimated at $5,000,- 000, all due to 100 lashes on his back. Mastering A Book. The book which makes a man think most is the book which strikes the deepest root in his memory and understanding. One of the educational maxims of the Jesuits is Vexatio dat intettectum [Hard labor gives discern- ment]. The maxim indicates that in the judgment of these educators it is not working at the easy but at the difficult mental task that gives intellectual perception. Men walk through a mountainous country not only for the pleasure to be derived from the scenery, but for the sake of the physical vigor which comes from climbing bills. The man who masters a book which keeps his mind on the stretch is, like the mountain- climber, braced up by the effort. He lays down the book refreshed, invigorated, and trained to master a more diment book. One day while skating, an English boy dis placed his knee-cap. He was taken home, and the surgeon ordered him to lie for three months on his mother's sofa. He suffered severely from the pain, and his wise grandfather handed him" a book to puzzle over," that his attention might be taken from the injured knee. It was a work on trigonometry, of which Henry Woodrow, the boy of sixteen, knew nothing. At the end of three months, when the boy was allowed to leave the sofa, he had mastered the book, without any assist- ance from any one, and in spite of the severe pain in his knee. Several years after the boy went to Cam- bridge, where he did so well in mathematics as to gain the rank of Fourteenth Wrangler. He went out to India, and, as Director of Public Instruction in one of the provinces, did such good work that he was called "the Nestor of Education in Bengal," and when he died the natives raised three thousand five hundred dollars to place his bust in Caius College, Cambridge, and in the Uni- versity of Calcutta. The Bengal educator used to say that his success at Cambridge and India was due to his mastering the book his grandfather gaze him "to puzzle over," when laid up with a displaced knee-cap 建筑上的东东 Force in Silence. In painting the great picture of the sacri fice of Iphigenia the artist, it is sail, exhaust- ed the emotions of grief and horror in the faces of the bystanders. "He has left nothing unsaid. How can he depict her father's sorrow ?" asked anxiously his friends who were watching the develop- ment of the picture. He threw a mantle over Agamempon's face. The blank stlence was more effective than any pictured woe. One of the most extraordinary effects pro- duced by absolute silence is recorded in the reports of a Convention in which the fore- most men in Virginia took part. John Randolph had a measure to carry in which he looked for the opposition of Alexander Campbell, afterward founder of a large sect. a man then noted for his scholarship and power in debate. Randolph had never seen the Scotch logi- cian, but he had heard enough of him to make him and his partisans uneasy. When, therefore, the gaunt stranger first rose to speak in the Convention, Randolph looked at him with such an air of alarm as to at- tract the whole attention of the Convention, and as he glanced around seemed to be ask- ing for sympathy in his coming defeat. He then composed himself to listen in rapt at- tention. Campbell, aware of this by-play, hesitated and lost the thread of his argument. Ran- dolph's face by turns as he listened expressed weariness, indifference, and finally unspeak- able contempt. He leaned back and yawned. Campbell sat down hastily. He had lost

articles.full_text:
SAM JONES' DAUGRTER ELOPES. She Marries a Young Man who was Not the Choice of her Parents. Anna U. Jones, daughter of the Rev. Sam Jones, the famous revivalist, was married at Chattanooga the other day to his former secretary, William M. Graham, now an cffi-
cial stenographer of the Cherokee (Georgia)
circuit. Five years ago Graham, who was
then 22 and the girl 12, were in love. Natur-
ally Mr. Jones objected to the intimacy, and the girl was sent away to school at Millers- burg, Ky. She did not take very kindly to Jones returned nome. Mr. Graham had be- come a lawyer, and was subsequently made circuit. Last Tuesday night the lover sought the aid of two friends, Prof. L B. Robeson and Dr. J. E. Mayes, in eluding the vigilance of Mr. and Mrs. Jones, both of whom oppos- ed the marriage on account of their daugh- ter's youth. Dr. Mages went to Chattaneoga to arrange the preliminaries, and Mr. Graham and Miss Jones joined a riding party at Cart- ersville, Ga., Jones's home. The plot was carried out. The young couple on their taken to the study of the Rev. Dr. Bachman of the First Presbyterian Church, who gett- ing a hint from a reporter, refused to per- form the ceremony unless a Southern Metho- dist clergyman assisted. Then a visit was made to Dr. Drumbell, who upon being told that the groom belong-

articles.headline: Untitled Snippet
articles.full_text: A Fountain of Life. On the fountain in King's Square, St. John., is chiselled the quaint spiritual truism which Jesus spake to a weary sin- ner, in the shadow of Jacob's well, at Sychar :- "Whosoever drinketh of this water shall thirst again, but whoseever drinketh of the water that I shall give him, shall never thirst." Beautiful message of love, Would I with garlands enwreath ! Fountain of life, from above ! Fountain of life, from beneath ! What blessings your crystalline pureness impart ! sing of the virginal life in thy heart. This one : - the water of earth, - Fraught with refreshing delight- Pare and pellucid at birth- Piessing to palate and sight,- But though for immortal ones sent from beneath, 'Tis leavened by sin with the virus of death. That one, - (hush wearisome strife) -Herald its praise abroad ! That, -is the Water of Life, Fresh from the Fountains of God, whose'-athirst-shall unto it nigh. And drink of its sweetness, he never shall die. Beautiful symbol of truth ! Thee, and thy lesson I laud,- One, the Elixir of youth, One, is the Spirit of God : By this, shall the human a blessing obtain, By that shall the Soul an Eternity gain. Speak to the mortals who pass; Ask them thy pureness to prove : Many-unheeding alas !- See not thy message of love,- And seeing, they grasp not the truth it would teach. Or measure the meaning, more subtle than speech.

articles.headline: BY JOHN IMBIE, TORONTO.
articles.full_text: BY JOHN IMBIE, TORONTO. The Old Year is dving, His moments are flying, On the "Ledger' of life may be seen: Opportunities lant To be faithfully spent,- Whether "profit or loss" hath it been ? Doth the Old Year's decay Leave us wiser to-day Than he found us just twelve months ago? Have we done what we might? Have we clung to the right? Doth the "Ledger' a "credit-note" show ? Have we cause for regret At "the losses" we've met Through sin, pride, or procrastination? Let us humbly arise, And resolve to be wise, The New Year may bring consolation! To thine own heart be true, For 'ois wise to review, And a "balance-sheet" strike without fear; In life's sunshine or shower Let each bright golden hour Be well spent as if Death might be near ! When our Lord shall appear, And our names we shall hear Sounded forth from God's great Book above, May the record then show That "the debt" which we owe Hath "been met" by His infinite love ! A Uhinese Funeral Procession. A remarkable funeral procession paraded the streets of Peking a few weeks ago. It was the formal public celebration of the buri- al of Teching Techu, a grand chamberlain and brother in law of Prince Kung. The bier was carried by eighty man, preceded by forty-eight flag-bearers, eight camels, and twenty four white horses. One hundred and sixty men followed bearing sixteen red planks, on which were painted in many coloured letters the name and titles of the dead nobleman. The whole procession was a mile and a half long.- [Ex.

articles.full_text: The Wizard's Latest Invention is Diaboilt cal in its Possibilities. Thomas E lison, the phenomenal inventor, has reached a critical stage in his career, and it would be a strange sarces n of fate, if his latest invention should make him posi- tively abborrent to the growing generation. Over in his lab ratory at L'ewellyn park is this invention. It has been tried and found perfect, and it is a phonographic clock which, instead of chiming the hours, calls them out at every quarter in a voice full of clearness. It may be fitted with any set to suit the purposes for which it may be in- tended. To a reporter it was exhibited The inventor was cheery and playful, as he always is. "The clock, said he, "i warmon's to th with ambinaginal wire it to mare out a rie are market now it might save you reporter a great deal of worriment. For instance and, you are at a political meeting with a' dezan speakers carded. They are to have a half hour. You know what a fiction that is. Bat now, if you had a clock like this, see how it would work," and here Mr. Edison place i a set within it. He pointed the hand to the quarter of an hour, and a voice came ringing out : "This speaker is half through." At the half hour the clock blurted out : "The audience will please not encore. The gentleman now gives way to another.' "The only fear I have," continued Mr. Elisop, "is that the young unmarried folks may not relish it. You are married? No? Well, I don's give this out as a bribe, but when you get entargled in the prelim. inaries come to me and I will give you one that you may present to the family into which you aspire to be admitted. It will be a fibber. I'm a little in doubt about the popularity of the parlor clock with the younger people." Mr. Edison has good reason to fear. A more tantalizing ornarent to a pair of ar- dent lovers than a matrimonial parlor phone- graphic clock cannot be imagined. Fancy, for instance, a Sunday evening in a cczy parlor with two hearts beating as one, start- led by a voice from the mantel : - " Good night, a fond good night. In another hour it will be midnight." Then dolefully at a quarter past and each succeeding quarter comes cut its hoarse creakings, until 11.55, when it blurts out :- "In five minutes more it will be to mor- row," and every ten minutes subsequently the sir is filled with its mandling, such as :

articles.headline: TO IT TOOK MINIT TOO INTIME COLUMN TO BEEN THE
articles.full_text:
TO IT TOOK MINIT TOO INTIME COLUMN TO BEEN THE "Ah! how still the hour." "Mabel, I am watching thee, ha, ha! " "Methinks I hear the spirit of thy mamma upon the stairs." Please don't heed me ; it is my misfortune that I must warn you that the hour is half- past 12." "Did I hear you ask me to get that hat?" Will you kindly remember me in your prayers?" "Look ous! I hear a footstep. Ha, ha! I was only fooling thee . I'll soon have to call father to go to his office And so the clock jabbers on most exasperat- ingly. Of course the words are set to suit the circumstances. If the wooer be a favor- ed person of course the language will be different, the tone of the clock will be sweet and simpering, and the words coy and cap-
tivating.-[N. Y. Press. Lighting Up. An anecdate which is told of the "An- gelus," Millet's greatest work, which was lately brought to America, may interest our readers. After the picture was first sketched in, a friend of the artist stood observing it. "How does the meaning strike you?" said Millet, who had previously declared that he intended by this picture to express the truest worship. The painter's own faith was as simple as that of a child and firm as that of a wise wan. "It means to me," said his friend, "that there is no use in prayer. There stand the worehipping peasants on their dull fields
beneath a dumb black sky. Where is their
answer?" Millet smiled, and with a few strokes of his brush brought in a ray of sunlight from the horizon. The whole gray sky lifted and arched itself; the landscape from that one beam was filled with hope and promise. The commonest house decorator, follow- ing the same rule, will tell you to light the inside edges of your roof if you wish the whole dwelling to appear lofty and cheerful to its inmates. Cannot our shrewd young readers gather some hint from this for their daily occupa- tions? If the every-day routine of your life is low-hurg, dull and gray, like Miller's fields, let in some cheerful beam of light upon it. Any monotonous occupation or round of duties, however good or useful, wears on the brain and nerves, and produces irritability and ill humor. There are mornings on which every member of a family appears at break. fast under a cloud, the result, perhaps, of overwork, dyspapsia, or some secret trouble. How is the beam of light to be let in, and the whole horizon of the day lifted? If there is an artist in human nature in the household with good will ar ... ot, he or she will contrive some little gayety for the even- ing, or an hour's stroll into the country, or will bring home a good novel. Any amuse- ment will answer which changes the current of thought and recreates the wasted powers. If your ordinary occupation brings you in- to contact with masses of people, treat your- self to a balmy interval of solitude; or, if, on the contrary, you are too much alone, go into a crowd. There is a magnetism, a stimulant, which reaches us from human beings, more powerful than any tonic. Tuese are small rays or night, yes is is surprising how quickly they lift our horizon and widen our day. At best, however, they are but homely, practical methods which serve only a tran- sient purpose. Every one of our readers whose life is hopelessly dull and dead, surely knows how to open it to the one true Light. He Has Magnetic Fingers. The scientists connected with the Johns Hopkins University are engaged in investig- ating the peculiar powers possessed by the fingers of Louis Hamburger, the 21-year-old son of Philip Hamburger, a well-known mer- chant of New York. When the hands of the young man are thoroughly dried and touched to any polished object they hold it like a magnet. He can thus raise up a quantity of pins which will dangle from them, his index fingers possessing the quality more than any others. He also raises up a glass tuoe freighted with a six pound weight. Profes- sor William Simon has him in charge, and proposes to give some scientific experiments befere the Johns Hopkins Scientin Associ- ation.

articles.full_text: HOUSEHOLD. Baby. Before the cheerful fire to-night, My wife and I are sitting. We softly talk of days gone by, And on our hearts, such memories lie Of baby. ar treasure was a boy, of course, And such a sturdy youngster, With hair of gold; and eyes of blue, And six white teeth, so straight and true Had baby. His chubby hands, all dimpled, too. And fingers, always itching,

articles.headline: IN A 101 HOURT WITH DAWN OUT CACE
articles.full_text:
IN A 101 HOURT WITH DAWN OUT CACE And other tricks, to our surprise, Did baby. He made my wife a slave, all day, Keeping him out of mischief. He'd pick up pins and dirt, you see, And put them in his mouth, would he, Would baby. And then, at night, when I came home, 9 He'd crow and smile, to see me. He'd pick my pockets, do his best, To grab my pipe (the little pest !) That baby. At hed-time, too, he'd ver us sore, With all his restless antics. And when we thought he was asleep, Around the door, who then would peep, tink habe And so to-night, we sit and think, Ol baby's ways and doings, And of those hands and voice, now still, And through our hearts such memories thrill. Oh ! baby. But, hark! From out the stillness comes, A voice to soft and cooing, That rascal, there, has just awoke, And smiling too, a master stroke, Our baby. Washing in Winter. I feel sure that among our many readers some women are to be found who do, along with sewing, cooking, sweeping, etc., the washing for their tamilies. While it is hard enough to do the washing any time in the year, it becomes infinitely worse during the winter months. The risk to be taken then is incalculable. The winter washings have been the finding an early grave. Call it a dispensa-
tion of Previdence if you will, I call it a result of hot steam from the tubs, combined with carelessness. Rather strong language, I know, but if you had seen, as I have, seemingly sensible women go from the steam-heated wash room to the clothes-line in one hard, and tweed in the lace of a Folth. ern or southern wind, proceed to hang up the weekly washing without having taken other precaution that to pin a shawl or some other light wrap over their heads, you would certainly agree with me that stronger things might be soid. If a mother does not care enough for herself to try to preserve her health, she should at least do so for her children's sake. But the washing must be done. Certainly, the washing must be done in winter as well as summer ; but why not exercise a little pru- dence? In the first place, the wash-room, usually the kitchen, ought not to become so heated by steam; the outside door should be left open, slightly, to admit cold air, or opened wide when the clothes are being taken from the boiler. But the laundress must not stand in the draught. Then when the clothes are ready for the line, I would urge you to let the "gude mon" hang them out; true he may not hang them as scienti- fically as you would, but you should be satis. fied. His hands are not so susceptible to cold as yours are. Indeed, I think it will hurt no man to help his wife wash when her one pair of hands must do so much. It will be better, much better for you to dry your clothes in the bouse. An attic to dry clothes in is a luxury possessed by few. Now, if you do not have your clothes dried in the house, and if there is no one to assist you, then do take some care of yourself. Pall down your sleeves. put a cloak on—a shawl will not do, for when you raise your arms it blows back, allowing the cold to strike you over the chest and langs. Put overshoes on, wrap something warm about your head, and wear mittens of cotton flannel or white yarn, if you can use them, and tie a silk handkerchief, or something equally close over your mouth. I make this emphatic for the reason that it is a precaution rarely taken, and yet it is a most necessary one. When one is warm, respiration is more rapid, and it seems as though air could not be taken in the lungs fast enough through the nestrils; the result is that breashing is done through the mouth, and the air as it were. The cold air striking the heated lungs will certainly bring on some de- rangement, and having the mouth tied up, thus compelling the nestrils to do their own work, cannot, you see, be otherwise than advantageous. We cannot afford to run any risks where health is concerned. Another thing I would urge is the wearing of woolen dresses during the winter. So many women wear calico and singham dress- es, which are sure to find their way to the wash every week, making additional work. A flannel or cashmere dress, after having been worn for best until it begins to look shabby, can often be made to do service as an every-day dress for one winter, any way, sometimes for two winters, and need not be in the wash, either, if one is careful. Many women who do their own work buy half wool dresses for every day. They of course line them all through. Mach of the so-called "cheap dress goods" will give as much wear as the more expensive goods. Of course it is closely woven goods that wear best. One ought to study how to save washing in winter. A pair of sleeves made to draw over the dress sleeves, a rubber run in at the

articles.full_text: POTATO CAKES .- Take cold mashed pota- toes left over from a previous meal and form them into little oakes, using a little flour to form them, but not mixing it into the potate; arrange en a pie plate, glaze with beaten egg and bake a delicate brown. PRINCESS PUDDING, -- Butter well a pud- ding basin, or plain mould, flour it well, and etick, in rotation over the inside, raisins, shoed candled peel, or dried fruit; fill the basin with layers of bread and but- ter, and between each layer, sugar, blanched and sliced almonds, and cut candied peel, with a grating of lemon peel over each layer; pour ever the whole sufficient custard to fill the mould-made with four beaten eggs to a pint of milk-cover the basin closely, and boil or steam from half to three- quarters of an hour. OYSTER PIE.-Line a buttered baking dish with pastry and place in it a layer of fine large oysters. Rub two tablespoonfuls of butter smooth with as much flour and place small bits of it here and there on the oysters. Sprinkle with pepper and salt. Follow this with another layer of oysters, dotted with butter and seasoned as befere. Continue this process until the dish is full. Poor in enough oyster liquor to fill the dish within an inch of the top and cover all with a rich pastry. Bake until a delicate brown, rub over with a little butter or white of egg and serve hot. ORANGE Snow, -This is made the same as snow pudding, except that the thin yellow part of an erange rind is boiled five minutes in the water that is to be turned over the had relating and the inice of four large sour oranges takes the place of the lemon jaice, the quantity of water being diminish- ed to allow for the difference in the amount of juice used. The gelatine is beaten and the pudding is served with custard sauce or whipped cream. Candied cherries or bias of fruit or wine jelly dropped here and there upon the snow of the pudding add much to its appearance and also to its flavor. Foultry and Meats.

articles.headline: BOILED TURKEY WITH CELERY STUFFIG.
articles.full_text:
BOILED TURKEY WITH CELERY STUFFIG. -Chop half a head of celery very fine. Mix with it one quart of bread crumbs, pepper and salt to taste, two heaping tablespoonfuls of butter, and two eggs. Stuff the turkey with this, sew up and truss. Wring a large equare of white cotton cloth out of cold water, and dredge it thickly with flour. Sew the turkey in this, and put into a pot of boiling water. Let it boil rapidely for fifteen minutes; skim carefully, then set back where it will simmer. Allow 3 hours for a turkey weighing 9 pounds, and 12 min- utes for every additional pound. Serve with celery sauce. Cut the tender parts of a head of celery very fine. Pour on just water enough to cover it; cover the sauce- pan and set where it will simmer one hour. Mix together two tablespoonfuls of flour and four of butter, and when the celery is tender add this to it, with one pint of milk, and salt and pepper to taste, and give the sauce one boil before serving. It preferred, a boiled turkey may be dressed with oyster stuffing and served with oyster sauce. Sub- stitute half a pint of chopped systers for the colery in the above stuffing, and to make the oyster sauce add half a pint of chopped sauce, allowing the sauce merely to come to the boiling point after such addition. ROAST GOOSE. - Stuff the goose with the following potato dressing: Six potatoes boiled, pared and mashed fine and light; one tablespoonful of salt, one teaspoonful of pepper, one spoonful of sage, a tablespoon-
ful of very finely chopped onion, two table- spoonfuls of butter. Truss. and dredge well with salt, pepper and flour. A goose weighing eight pounds will roast in a hot oven in from one and a half to two hours. To make the gravy: Wash the heart, liver, gizzard and neck, and put on to boil in three pints of water; boil down to one pint. When tender, put the liver on a plate, and mush fine, then return to the water in which it was boiled, Mix two tablespoonfuls of flour with half a cupful of cold water; stir into the gravy, season well with salt and pepper, and set back where it will simmer for twenty minutes. When the goose is done, take it up, and tipping the dripping pan to one side to bring all the gravy together, skim off every par- ticie of lat. Place the pan on the top of the stove and turn into it one cupful of water. Lat this beil up, in the meantime scraping everything from the sides and bottom of the pan. Turn this into the made gravy in the saucepan, boil up once, and serve in the gravy tureen. With roast goose serve apple sauce made as follows: Pare, core, and cut up half a dezen tart apples, and stew them in just sufficient water to keep them from burning. When soft remove from the fire, and heat and mash them smooth with suffi- cient sugar to sweeten, adding, if you like, a small bit of butter. Serve cold. ROAST DUCKS. - The directions given for reasting and stuffing a goose may be used for ducks, with the same method of making the gravy. Instead of apple sauce, currant or grape jelly may be served with them. GLAZED HAM. - Wash a fine corned-not smoked ham; soak all night in cold water, and boil about eighteen minutes to the pound. There should be plenty of water in the pot, cold at first, and brought gradually to a boil. Skim well from time to time. Let it get cold in the water in which it was boiled; take it out, remove the skin care- fully, and press soft paper on the top of the ham to take off the clinging drops of grease. Brush all over with beaten egg. Work a cup of rolled and sifted soda or oyster crackers into a paste with warm milk, butter, pepper, salt, and a beaten egg. Coat the ham thickly with this, and set to brown in a moderate oven. When again cold, pin or paste frilled paper around the knuckle. PRESSED TONGUE. - Put a salt tongue into cold water, bring it to a boil and skim; then allow it to simmer at the back of the stove for five or six hours. When tender. remove from the pot, skin and cut away the unsightly nortion at the root Prose the tim removed way I have seared and room . Troops and Alfa round to the root, and in this form place it in a small round tin or saucepan its own wize in circumference. The tin should be flat-bottomed and have straight sides. Cover with a cloth, over that place a small round of tin or a plate, and upon that a weight of at least eight pounds. After being under press for ten or twelve hours the tongue will turn out of the mould in compact form, and should be carved in slices across the top. Speak English. articles.headline: THE MYSTERIOUS RANGER.
articles.full_text: THE MYSTERIOUS RANGER. St. Louis, Dec. 30. -- Two notorio Indian desperadoes named Red Lend and Choctaw Pete, heavily loaded wi tanglefoot, took possession of the tor of Tishwawa Christmas day. After nea ly killing the town marshal when he tempted to arrest them, they emptied drug store and tried to ride their hors into the hotel. At this juncture a we armed stranger rode up to the hotel ar dismounted. The outlaws ordered hi away and cut the halter of his hors The stranger remonstrated whereun and any anger roundinger accept and the real of Choctaw Pete covered him with his re wolver and ordered Lendall to disarm him As Lendall approached the stranger sho him through the heart. A duel then of curred between Pete and the stranger and Pete was shot through the head and killed. After eating his dinner th stranger leisurely rode away. He is sup posed to be Winchester Frank, the crack shot and scout.

articles.headline: OF CITY NOW
articles.full_text: OF CITY NOW There promises to be changeable weath er with a good deal of downfall accom- panied by rog during the first week of the year. The chances are rather against frost, and rain is therefore more likely to be precipitated than snow. There are a good many positive as well as neutralizing aspects during this period, some of which are as follows: - The parallel declination of Mercury with the sun, the sextile of Venus and Mars and the quadrature of Mercury and Uranus on the 2d, the par- allel of Mercury and Juniter on the 3d terror or madiculary direct outside out out the trine of Venus and Saturn on the 4th and the quadralure of Mercury and Mars, the sextile of Mars and Saturn and the full moon on the 6th. Variable weather with a good many bracing days ought to follow and continue up to the 14th, the principal dominating aspects during this period being the parallel declination of Jupiter and the sun on the 8th, the paral- lel of Mars and Saturn on the 9th and conjunction of Jupiter and the sun on the 10th, when a low temperature and per- haps snow may be looked for. She does not wonder at not hearing from 1 him, for he said he should not write; bu e every day, as the evening mail arrives, find . her, dressed in her choicest, watching for him who comes not. "George, my dear cousin George, I have wished to ask your forgiveness, oh, so often 1 you must have seen my desire to do so; and drawing herself up, "you know my pride, it was long ere I could do it; but my beloved father's illness, that perhaps soften ed me, and your kindness to him, George- am I forgiven?" and Helen held out to him her matchless hand. Suppressing a groan of agony, and to hide the deathlike pallor of his working face, he turned away, and then, without a word, drew her to him, and clasped her in his arms, while one deep sob burst from his over- charged heart. When you spoke hurriedly that day, you remember, I had heard some- thing which caused me pain, and I was hurt and angry. You don't know how I repented afterwards having wounded you. Do not now ask me to tell you what it was I heard. You shall some day know all: I shall never conceal anything from you, George, then." "God bless you-may God bless you," was all his reply. They were together in the large drawing- room, but at this moment a summons from her father called Helen away, and the door closed on Asleigh, than whom the world scarcely then contained a more miserable man. Desperate was the inward struggle before honour gained the mastery : at one moment the spirit of evil whispered, "Cannot your marriage be annulled, perhaps denied, and Helen made your own?" at the next, happily for him, a better impulse succeeded. articles.headline: THEIR NOSES.
articles.full_text:
THEIR NOSES. The nose in general has the least charac de er of any of the teatures. When we me nd with a very small one we only wish it larger when with a large one, we would fain reque
the it to be smaller. It is a feature general to to be described by negatives. It is of impor ne ance, however, to the rest of the face. If er good nose will do little for a countenand e. otherwise poor, a bad one is a great injur ; to the best. An indifferent one is so con is mon that it is easily tolerated. A larg is aquiline nose is bad. It trenches upon th other sex and requires all the graces of Aspasia to carry it off. Those, indeed, wi Aspasia to carry it off. Those, indeed, will carry off anything. There are many handsom and ever charming women with such noses e but they are charming in spite of them, no h by theirassistance. Painters do not giv - them to their ideal beauties. We do no d imagine ngels with aquiline noses. Dignifie - men have them.

articles.headline: THEIR FOREHEADS.
articles.full_text: THEIR FOREHEADS. Of late years physiognomists have declared for the vidsom of straight and compact fore heads raher than high ones. We must own we have seen very silly persons with both e It must e allowed, at the same time, that a very rereating forehead is apt to be no accompaniment of wit. With regard to high one, they are often confounded with forehead merely bald; and baldness, whether atural or otherwise, is never handsome; though in men it sometimes takes a character of simplicity and firmness. According to the Greeks, have been the greatest judges of beauty, the high forelead never bore the palm. A certain concieness carried it. A large bare forehead gives a woman a masculine and defying lok. Family Financiering. "They tell me you work for a dollar a day; How is it you clothe your six boys on such pay f "I know you will think it conceited and queer. But I do it because I'm a good financier. There's Pete, John, Jim and Joe, and William and Ned. A half dozen boys to be clothed up and fed. And I buy for them all good, plain victuals to But clothing-I only buy clothing for Pete. When Pete's clothes are too small for him to get on. My wife makes 'em over and gives 'em to John. When for John, who is ten, they have grown out of date. She just makes 'em over for Jim, who is eight. When for Jim they've become too ragged to fix, She just makes 'em over for Joe, who is six. And when little Joseph can wear 'em no more, She just makes em over for Bill, who is four. And when for young Bill they no longer wil do. She just makes 'em over for Ned, who is two. So you see if I get enough clothing for Pete, The family is furnished with clothing com plete. "But when Ned has got through with the cloth- ing, and when He has thrown it aside-what do you do with it then?" "Why, once more we go round, the circle com plete. And begin to use it for patches for Pete."

11 Fish stories are always in order. Here i e a beauty from that admirable publication Forest and Stream: "It's not uncommon is opening fish to find various and divers sun e dries within their maws. On Lake Superio t | the great lake trout namaycush of the Ojib d bewas, seem to always be ready and willing to accept any of such things as are thrown from the cook's gallery of the steamers and a sailing vessels which plow its pellucid waters . It is not uncommon to find a fork or spoon beef bones, potatoes, broken wine glasses corn cobs, and even a bunch of keys are among the treasure trove from their omnivorous collection bags. But now a carp
comes to the front as a container of the neat-
est outfit of anything yet seen on the unsalt. ed sea. On Christmas morning Captain McCormick, an old salt and fish man, saw two fine large German carp on sale in Duluth Struck with its appearance, and thinking to please his friend, the doctor, he purchased one and sent it to him with the compliments of the season. Of course the doctor was pleased with the gift and ordered it tabled. You can imagine the astonishment of all when it was opened to find within a silk-lined case containing a large meerschaum pipe and cigar holder, all in good order, too. It was a genuine carp, imported from Germany, of the variety called papier mache. The doc- tor has it yet carefully preserved, and the smoker's apparatus, too, which he shows to his friends with very great pleasure. To make yellow butter in winter, just be- fore finishing churning put in the yolk of eggs. Cycling as a pastime seems to be growing in popularity almost every day, and that, too, amongst the middle-aged and staid members of society. It has often been sug- gested that cyclists could be of great service in times of war if properly drilled and train- ed as soldiers, and many of our regiments actually have cycling divisions. In a recent number of the Wheelman there is published a report of a most interesting inter- view which the editor of that paper has had with Lord Wolseley on the sub- ject. His lordship is of the opinion that cyclists can be of immense service in case of war, and can also be made much use of in

id A man with large business interests and a handsome income married a lady who, ac- r,
s. customed all her previous life to the luxuries of wealth, had never formed any clear con- e ception of the worth and purchasing power of money. For some months the indulgent husband gratified his wife's every whim. One day the lady, to carry out some ca- price, asked for a check for so large a sum that the gentleman was disturbed. He saw s that such prodigality, if persisted in, meant n | ruin; but not wishing to grieve his wife by a n | downright refusal, he determined to give her a lesson in finance. He therefore smilingly r remarked that he could not give her a check as usual, but would send up the money from his store. n | arout noon the promised money came, not in crisp bills, as was expected, but in silver dollars, the sum total filling several specie , bags. The wife was first vexed, then amused, and finally, as the afternoon wore away, be- came deeply thoughtful. When her hus- band came home to supper, she took him gently by the arm, and leading him into the room where the ponderous bags of specie were still standing, said : "My dear, is this the money I asked you for this morning?" "It is, my love," was the reply. "And did you have to take this money all in, dollar by dollar, in the course of your business?" was the next question. "Yes," he answered gently, "it represents the results of many weeks of hard labor." "Well, then," she said, with tearful eyes,

articles.headline: Untitled Snippet
articles.full_text: A Canadian Absconder Heard From. St. CATHARINES, Ont., Feb. 25-Mr. David Mills, a widely-known traveller of this city, writes to a friend here a letter bearing date 12th of January, from Buenos Ayres, Argentine Republic, South America. He says: " On the 9th inst. I was walking on one of the principal streets in this city in company with my wife, when I suddenly came face to face with a Mr. Macrae. He was walking alone and looked very crest- fallen and unhappy. He is certainly not the Macrae of old, his jaunty air and erect car- riage having disappeared under the trying circumstances of the last few months. He wore a light tweed suit and blue eyeglasses and appeared to recognize me, but neither of us spoke. I did not afterwards see him. He is not extraditable i whose population is about one-third composed of refugees from justice." It will be remember- ed that the A. M. Macrae mentioned in this letter is the dashing "Matt" Macrae, formerly secretary-treasurer of the St. Cath- arines Security Loan and Savings Com- pany; who absconded with some $30,000 of the company's money in September! last.

articles.headline: Untitled Snippet
articles.full_text: A Cheap Way to Warm Cold Feet. More than twenty-five years ago, I was sometimes troubled with cold feet. At one time while I was stamping upon the ground in the effort to warm my extremities, a com- rade said to me, "If your feet are cold try this." He raised his foot from the ground and struck some light blows with his hand upon the upper part of his leg, just above the knee. I did the same, with both legs, and instantaneously felt a flow of warm blood coming downward, and the feet be- came comfortably warm. The Night Air Oure. Dr. Felix L. Oswald has contributed an article to the Medical Tribune on "The Night Air Cure," in which he maintains that night air from the outside is far more health- ful than the vitiated, disease-laden night air of ordinary human dwellings. In Germany successful experiments have been tried in summer of having patients with pulmonary disorders sleep all night in the open air of the pine woods. At any rate it is all we have to breathe at night, and it had better be fresh and pure as possible. "Eye-openers and Night-caps." A physician, who declares that both the "eye-opener" and the "night-cap" are very injurious, says that the latter is the less evil of the two. "When a man," he says, "gets to drinking early in the morning as a regu- lar custom, he is pretty far gone. A drink refore breakfast is a pretty certain indica- tion of a half-dozen before sundown. The effect of a morning drink wears away very shortly, leaving the drinker collapsed just at a time when he is busiest at work, and it is natural for him to drink again to brace himself up. At night, however, while he sleeps, nature repairs the damage, or part of it, which he has done by soaking his stomach with alcohol. If a man must drink, he ought to have sense enough to steer clear of the "eye-opener." It is the last resort among drinkers and is the hardest to tear loose from." Air the Bedroom. Will there ever be an end of the need of saying that the room which demands most careful attention is the sleeping apartments. Bedrooms should be light, sunny and spa- cious, and there should be constant change of air, a window, either in the bedroom itself or in adjoining room being partly opened at night. If a chimney passes through the room, a chimney in use, an opening into the chimney covered with one of the simple perforated covers that may be closed at need, makes the next best ventilator to that of the open fireplace of the old days. And now that flannel and cashmere nightgowns are so much used, it will perhaps be easier to persuade people that all-day underwear, yes, particularly and especially the woven be removed Coughing and Sneezing. Coughing can be stopped by pressing on the nerves on the lips in the neighborhood of the nose. Sneezing may be stopped by the same mechanism. Pressing in the neigh- borhood of the ear, right in front of the ear, may stop coughing. It is so also of hic- coughing, but much less so than for sneezing or coughing. Pressing very hard on the top of the mouth is also a means of stopping coughing, and many say the will has im- mense power. There are many other afflic- tions associated with breathing which can be stopped by the same mechanism that stops the heart's action. In spasms of the glottis, which is a terrible thing in children, and also in whooping cough, it is possible to afford relief by throwing cold water on bling the soles of the feet the reet, or by ticking the soies of the reet, the which produces laughter, and at the same time goes to the matter that is producing the spasm, and arrests it almost at once. I would not say that we can always prevent coughing by our will; but in many instances these things are possible, and if you remem- ber that in bronchitis and pneumonia, or any acute affection of the lungs, hacking or coughing greatly increases the trouble at times, you can easily see how important it is for the patient to try to avoid coughing as best he can. Cold and its Victims. As might have been foreseen, the influence of mere exposure upon health and life has been unusually noticeable during the rigor- ous close of the past year. Several cases of reported in the metro- this kind have been reported in the metro politan daily press, and we cannot doubt that their number would be largely increas- ed if the facts respecting this matter were fully known. Discretion in matter of expos- ure is not indeed possible to all; but it might certainly be exercised by, or on be- half of, many persons, especially at the ex- tremes of life, much more commonly than it is. The spectacle of an aged man or infant out of doors in biting weather must in very many cases lack the excuse of necessity. It is, however, where poverty or illness brings privation that the pinch is most felt. The safeguards afforded by food, fire and warm clothing are most difficult of attainment. Yet the poor and their charitable helpers may take heart from the fact that the main- tenance of sufficient artificial warmth does not call for elaborate measures or lavish ex- pense. The hand of brotherly help will cer- tainly be appealed to, but it need not squan- der or exceed in providing such absolute necessaries as fire, plain bedding and flannel underclothes. Food of the simplest is alone requisite, if it be sufficient in amount and warm; while the absence of alcohol is an ex- cellent guarantee for needful economy and for more sustaining provision. Much of this care is within reach of the frugal poor: but the time is fully ripe for charitable or- ganization in relief of their pressing necessi- ties.

articles.headline: THE PLUM HOLLOW SEERESS.
articles.full_text: THE PLUM HOLLOW SEERESS. Death of a Woman Who Had Achieved Fame as a Fortune Teller. OTTAWA, February-Wordhas been receiv ed here of the death on Wednesday night of Mrs. Barnes, the famous Plum Hollow for tune teller. Mrs. Barnes, during her life, achieved far more than a local reputation as a secress, people coming hundreds of miles to consult her, not only as to what fortune had in store for them but also by those who had met with losses or were about to enter into important undertakings. Many came from New York and other American cities, some from west of the Mississippi. During the fifty years that she was actively engaged in fortune-telling she was consulted by an enormous number of people, and made a vast amount of money. She was about ninety years of age. She lived in a little log cabin in a district called Plum Hollow, about seventeen miles northwest of Brockville. She was a mild-mannered pleasant-voiced and exceedingly intelligent woman and presented none of the witch- like and uncanny appearances usually con- sidered an essential element in connection with successful fortune-telling. Her funeral took place to the Athens Cometery. She claimed to have exercised her alleged occult powers since she was seven years of age. Her father held a commission in the Eng- lish army under George IV and for her di- vining power was christened the "Star of Connaught." by King William IV, who presented her with a gold medal. Hundreds of people throughout the Ottawa Valley had

articles.full_text:
Too Familiar One may not, according to the etiquette of loyalty, speak too familiarly of kings and queens. As a subject was once remind- ed, who wished to give his sovereign a pair of stockings, "The Queen of spain has no legs." She must not be supposed to walk, talk, or eat like ordinary mortals, and if one cannot escape the inference that she really is like the rest of humanity, surely nothing need be said of it. When Queen Victoria visited Salisbury Cathedral, thirty years ago, there was, of course, a flutter of curiosity and loyalty throughout the town. Even the humblest houses had hung out some sign of rejoicing, and at the White Hart Inn where the queen intended to lunch, the landlady was fluttering about in her best silk, while the servants were gay with white waistcoats and flowers in their button-holes. But that this show of devotion was not merely skin-deep may be guessed from an occurrence of the late afternoon, when the queen had departed. In the coffee-room of the inn were two young men wno were complaining to the waiter because they were not given eels for dinner, although the dish was promised them. The waiter apologized profusely, and remarked, in the way of excuse: "Her Majesty has been here to-day." "Did Her Majesty eat the eels?" was the too familiar query, and at this the waiter's loyal soul revolted. "It's no business of yours or mine, sir, what Her Majesty eats," was his dignified To Stop Runaway Horses. A Chicago man has made an invention which will stop the wildest runaway team. He is a livery man. Beneath the driver's box a two-volt dry battery is located. in the top of which are inserted three copper pegs that project from the ends of the lines. Running inside the lines are copper wires forming a circuit through the horses' noses by small polished balls of aluminum which press lightly against the inner sides of the nostrils. The circuit is opened and closed by means of two buttons, one of which can be operated by the driver. Should he be thrown from his seat before he can press the button, another button located beneath the seat inside the carriage can be operated by the occupant. In addition to his device for stopping runaway teams, the inventor has made an electrical stimulator for starting lazy or balky horses and giving them " style." This is operated through the lines also, the current being applied to the horses' sides by copper plates in the back band. Pa's Opinion of Them.
