articles.headline: MOMENTUM IN THE CHRISTIAN LIFE
articles.full_text: MOMENTUM IN THE CHRISTIAN LIFE

articles.headline: BY REV. JOHN L. SCUDDEM.
articles.full_text: BY REV. JOHN L. SCUDDEM. (Congregationalist.) "Go in this thy might."-Judges vi. 14. History shows that great emergencies never fail to bring forth a crop of great men In all the notable movements of the past, the international wars and civil conflicts, the social and political upheavals, the intel lectual and religious revolutions, our atten tion is fixed upon one or more prominent individuals who are identified with these movements, and whose name are insepar able from them. The name Cromwell anach in English suggests that turbulent epoch in English history when the people stood up manfully for their rights against both King and Pope. Luther is synonymous with the Protestant Reformation; Garibaldi with the struggles of Italy toward political unification and independence. The name Bacon marks a transition in philosophy from the deductive method-one of the most remarkable changes in history; and Copernicus, ar equally interesting change in the realm of astronomy. The word Alexander is the best representative of the ancient spirit of con- quest, and Wendell Phillips of the opposite modern spirit of personal freedom. And so on throughout the list. Each occasion had its conspicuous man or set of men, who stand out in bold relief because they were men of power-natural-born leaders of their fellow- men. There never was and never will be a time without its great men. If the times are dull, and there is no special demand for pub- lic exercise of their powers, these men may live and die unknown to fame; but they are there for all that, and it takes only a little agitation to bring them out of their obscur- ity and place them in open view. When Rome was in danger of destruction by the Acqui and Volsci the people went instinct- ively to Cincinnatus, who was plowing on his little out-of-the-way farm beyond the Tiber, and forced him to become their lead- er. He threw aside his tunic, and putting on his toga, led them to victory. During our civil crisis a quarter of a century ago, when slavery threatened to demolish the Union, the people did not hesitate long in determining who should command ove courabt a long the ship of State. They caught a long, awkward, raw-boned man in Illinois, and put him at the wheel. And well did Abraham Lincoln honor and fulfil the trust imposed upon him by an appreciative people. 'Tis ever thus in the history of human events. The really great men outstrip their fellows and go to the front, because they are men of might; be- cause they have acquired a mental or moral momentum which carries them through diffi- culties before which the average man is forc- ed to succumb. Our text furnishes us with another such example. The Midianites had surrounded Israel and driven them from their homes into dens and caves. The mountains were full of these human vultures, who watched their prey with wistful eyes and said within them- selves, "Twill not be long before we shall pounce upon you and eat you up. We are only waiting for you to grow a little weak- er." It was under these distressing circum- stances that Gideon was sought by the people of Israel and made dictator. He was a man of valor and might, and for this rea- son they thrust him forward and gave him command. I need not cite further instances of this sort; history is full of them. The few that I have mentioned are illustrations of a general law, which applies with equal force to you and men in our particular spheres of life. We may never be great, as the world counts greatness-that is, we may never become renowned and have our names handed down to posterity for some brilliant achievement; but it is true whatever of suc- cess we do accomplish in any line of work will be largely due to the principle I have at of stored un now. mentioned, namely, that of stored up pow er of some sort, to the accumulation of ener- gy, which can be used at any moment, like money in the bank. I wish to speak upon the principle of mo- memtum in human life and character. We appreciate the value of this principle in the realm of mechanics; let us see if it has not an equal value in the domain of spirit. Take the following examples: Yonder is a teamster coming down the hill with a load- ed wagon. He notices that no sooner does the road reach the bottom of the hill than it leads up over another one, and in order to relieve his patient animal of the superfluous labor he makes use of this simple expedient: When he is a few rods from the bottom of the hill be loosens the reins, applies the whip and acquires a galloping velocity which takes him half way up the opposite hill, and all this is done with scarcely any expenditure of energy. About all the horse has to do do is to keep on his feet; momentum does the rest. It steals a march on both gravity and friction. From this country road let me carry you to a sawmill. You see that circular saw flying round at lightning speed, making hundreds of revolu- tions in a minute. Watch it now as that heavy piece of timber is brought in contact with it. The second that saw strikes its fangs into the wood it utters a shrill war whoop of defiance and keeps up the battle cry until its enemy is rent in twain and carried off to make room for the next victim. The resis- tance which that log of wood offered to those revolving teeth is something enormous; some thing which no one can appreciate until he tries to make his way through that timber with a common handsaw and vet. why is THE LANGE OF THE PARTY OF THE PARTY OF THE PARTY OF THE PARTY OF THE PARTY OF THE PARTY OF THE PARTY OF THE PARTY OF THE PARTY OF THE PARTY OF THE PARTY OF THE PARTY OF THE PARTY OF THE PARTY OF THE PARTY OF THE PARTY OF T it that the circular saw spins through it with ease and leaps out with a final twang of triumph? How does it overcome this tremendous resistance? You say it is steam that drives it through. True enough, but that is only a partial answer. Steam indeed gives the power, but not the uniformity of power which we observe. If you would find the secret of this uniformity you must go into the engine room and look at that massive fly-wheel, weighingtons. When this mighty balance is once set going, its own great mass gives it a momentum that brooks no opposition, and imparts a con- stancy of movement to the entire system of machinery. The buzz-saw, with this pon- derous fly-wheel behind it, can accomplish what it never could with steam alone. One more example. Let me point out to you what is known as a storage battery, an ingenious modern invention for accumulating electricity and holding it in readiness for work. Such a battery is a prodigious power, standing in the stable, as it were, with its harness on, and capable of being brought into action at a moment's notice. It is the best illustration of reserve power that phy- sical science affords. Now let us take these hre e examples of accumulated force, and

articles.headline: Untitled Snippet
articles.full_text:
see what they can teach us in the depart ments of body, mind and heart. It is every man's duty, I claim, to make 3 the most of himself, to be a man of might in whatever sphere of influence God has placed him by catching and condensing the powers at his control and applying then to some noble end. Looking at the average human life, we notice a shameful waste of power, men and women deliberately squan- . 1 dering their energies, physical, intellectus and spiritual, when by the exercise of a lit - tle conscientious economy they might be a hundred fold more powerful than they are and occupy higher stations than they at present enjoy. I never could see any spe- cial beauty in weakness. This quality may ladmiration. It should be the ambition of every one to be strong-a creature of accom- plishment, obeying the commands of God to go forward in his might. I remark in the first place that it is our l duty to develop and husband that peculiar bodily force known as vitality. These bodies of ours are curious machines, in which the vital energy may be gathered up and kept in readiness for the strains of life.
They are veritable storage batteries, built upon God's patent, and capable of being charged with a subtler fluid than electricity, and doing a much grander work. There is a great difference in these bodily machines and the amount of vital force stowed away in them. Those who come into the world with vigorous constitutions may thank their ancestors for charging their bat- teries for them and giving them the very Landon best start in life. They are regular Leyder jars stuffed with potential power and des- 1 tined to become forceful factors in the world. Others, less fortunate in their ancestry, per- haps, may thank Providence that their early life was spent in the country, where, 1 during the first score of years, they develop- ed enough vitality to carry them trium- phantly through their three score years and ten. These country boys have great reason to be thankful. They possess in special degree the power of endurance, the capacity for bearing up under the numerous drafts upon their energy. Their vitality is their momen- ern break-neck speed when others less cop- behind. And what a yearning there is in those of us who live in the city for an occasional run into the country! How we ache to get away from crowded quarters and dusty streets; to leave behind us the artificialities of civilization and come into direct contact with the invigorating forces of nature. What a stampede there is for the rural districts during the sultry summer months, where tired humanity may recruit its flagging energies and replenish it- self with sunshine and fresh air. This an- nual exodus country-ward is a deep protest against the physiological transgressions and inconsistences of city life. The body cries out for more sleep, more exercise more simple fare, more green grass and blue sky. All nature invites us to come and catch new strength. And wee to the man who does not respond to this urgent call. I believe it to be a religious duty now and then to in- terrup, our routine work, and fill up with fresh life. I believe in vacation not only for tired ministers, but for everybody. A vacation is like a running jump. When a man wants to make a long and successful leap he goes back a couple of rods to gather impetus. The headway acquired during that brief run sends him flying through the air. Now our vacations do for us what these little runs do for the jumper. They give us momentum enough to keep us flying through the rest of the year. That merchant is unwise who will not give his clerks a couple of weeks vaca- tion during the twelve months. Such recrea- tion will not only put color into their cadaverous cheeks; it will put cheerfulness into their hearts and elasticity into their entire composition. It will brighten them up all over and make them tenfold better workmen. Health is physical momentum; we need to get all of it we possibly can. The man replete with vitality can afford to laugh at disease. Noxious germs can find no abiding place in him. He sheds them as easily as water-proof sheds the rain. Now let us pass from the body to the mind; from the reserve power of vitality to that of discipline. Come back again to that farmer's wagon. You recollect that in order to travel easily over the up-grade in front of him, he whipped up his horse and gathered velocity and power on the down grade. In other words, he looked ahead, and made ready to mount the hill before him. What a lesson here for us who are travelling over the great highways of life. Our courses here are not over level roads which require little expenditure of energy and offer no obstacles to our progress. If I know anything of life it mlantifully provided with un grades T I find it plentifully provided with ap-grade-, and it behooves us sensible beings to prepare for them. To make a success of life, to pass with ease and comfort over the steeps before us, we need a careful mental training as well as bodily vitality. In youth, when travelling is comparatively easy, we should apply the whip to our intellectual faculties and gain that momentum of discipline which shall help us over hard places in days to come. No one can over-estimate the value of mental discipline as a preparative for the graver duties of life. And it matters little where we get this discipline, whether in the school-house and the college, or the more practical sphere of business. The special value of an education lies not in the amount of information picked up in the school room. That is a matter of minor importance, as every scholar will testify. In point of fact, a large proportion of what we learned in school has long since left us and passed into oblivion. We could not retain our hold upon the multiplicity of rules and dates and facts. They slipped away from us be- fore we were 20 years old, and, looking back, we are compelled to say that the best thing our schooling did for us was its training us to think; to apply ourselves to difficult tasks and overcome them; to depend upon our- selves and work out our problems without assistance. It gave exercise to our mental faculties and toughened them, just as the gymnasium develops the muscles of the ath- lete and sends him away a man of might. We may have left most of our information in the school-house, but what of that? The athlete does not carry away the Indian clubs and the rowing machine upon his back, he profits by their use, and comes out a man capable of undertaking any task. Precisely so, the real scholar, instead of cramming himself with multifarious information, trains himself rather to study, to master every subject brought before him whether he re- members it or not; he thus gains the indis- pensible qualities of self-reliance, persever- ance and thoroughness. The man who has these, whether talented or not, is sure to

articles.headline: Untitled Snippet
articles.full_text: . | succeed in the end. His mind is like a milldam, it is a reservoir of power, which e can be applied to almost any use. We see the same value of discipline in the businessmen to-day started out as poor boys, were at play. The discipline of poverty was a hard one. The pay was small, the work plenty and the hours long. Many a lad has chafed under such apparent hardship and murmured against Providence for the un- equal apportionment of her favors. But all this time, remember, he was securing the best of training, he was forming those busi- ness habits, without which in these days no one can succeed. While rich men's sons are growing up in idleness and ease, without in- ial training or a knowledge of the value

articles.headline: CHAPTING PROPERTY OF TO WITHOUT TOURS OF THE LINE
articles.full_text: CHAPTING PROPERTY OF TO WITHOUT TOURS OF THE LINE of money, this young man, through his in- dustry and economy, was developing into a commercial giant. It was really his priva- tions and enforced application that gave him the impetus to outstrip his fellows in the race for wealth. He steadily forged 1 ahead, while they, one by one, dropped be- 1 hind. There are blessed compensations in , this world, my friends; no bane but has a  corresponding blessing. The youngman start- ing out at $5 a week thinks himself under- paid, and perhaps he is from the standpoint of dollars and cents; but every day, if he is faithful, he is being paid off in increased efficiency. He is gaining industrial momen- tum, which by and by will pay him twenty or thirty or a hundredfold more than his actual labor's worth. During the first few years of our active, independent life most all of us were obliged to take a good share of our pay in experience. But experience. is a good school. It gives a grand discipline.  And now in closing I wish to say a few  words in reference to the third kind of To be a man of real might, to make an un- qualified success of life, one needs to add a strong moral character to bodily vitality  and intellectual discipline. Nay; this last is worth more than the other two combin- ed. Now character is a growth. It is the result of a gradually accumulated spiritual power. Its force is nothing less than the force of habit. When a man once forms the habit of doing right, and this habit becomes confirmed, he acquires what we may call the mo- mentum of righteousness-aspecies of mo- mentum which is unaffected by temptation. meneticin winds is critical control by company Solicitations to evil have no power to turn such a man out of his course or thwart his progress. Sin is no more to him than the log of wood to the buzz-saw. He cuts right through it and flings the pieces to either side, and the reason is that deep down in his soul is the flywheel of moral principle. To such a man, coming in contact with temptation is a sort of amusement, not a dread encounter. He goes through sin as a matter of course. He has been traveling so long in this one particular direction that he keeps on auto- matically in the same good rut. I know people who, during many years of holy living have acquired such a godly momentum that it is simply impossible now to throw them off the right course. Like the planets of Heav- en, they are true to their orbits. Nothing can overcome the mighty inertia of their holy habit, or cause them to swerve in their faithful revolution around the sun of righteousness. This is in fact the old doctrine of the perseverance of saints. Of what paramount importance is this principle in the education of children! The parent or preceptor who fails to apply it with all his might is guilty before God for a gross breach of trust and wasted opportunity. If we would save our children when the evil days come, as come they will, we must plant these godly habits in them early in life and cultivate them with utmost care. The roots must grow stout and strong and take hold of the rocks before the storm breaks. Your tree cannot do much growing in the thunder- ing gust; remember that. The growing and strengthening must be done beforehand. And what has been said of temptation is licable to our discours coments and also applicable to our discouragements and trials. We need divine power to carry us through these without wavering or doubt; nay, more than that, we need a store that has been accumulating for years through faith. It is a dangerous thing, we are told, for a vessel to lose its headway in a heavy sea. It is liable to get into the trough and be swamped. Equally hazardous is it for a man to lose his faith in God; and many is the poor fellow who, having thus lost his propelling power, has made shipwreck of his immortal soul. I have noticed that when great afflictions come upon them, irreligious men, are often- times very weak. They seem to labor heavily in the tempestuous waters and are at their wits' end, whereas the godly soul mounts the waves as lightly as a clipper ship. In the year 1885, when the Germanic, of the White Star Line, was making her home- ward journey from England to New York, she encountered one of the most terrible gales that ever swept across the Atlantic In the course of this tempest Capt. Kennedy said that a wave of mountainous proportions lifted itself up against the vessel and threat- ened to engulf it. It lay directly in the track of the steamer and stood higher than the top of her smoke-stacks. It was simply impossible for the vessel to override it, and so with her terrific momentum of eighteen miles an hour she plunged headlong into it and was completely buried from stem to stern. That was a moment of awful sus- pense to every person upon that steamer. It seemed as if their end had surely come. The skylights were destroyed and the water rushed in until the passengers stood waist deep in the cabin. One sailor was washed overboard, and the cap- tain in the wheel-house was knocked insen- sible. All the lifeboats were swept bodily away and the iron railing was torn and twisted up like twine. The vessel was lit- erally stripped by the seething waters; but being sharp and heavy, and possessing an irresistible momentum, she actually tun- neled her way through this mountain of water and came out on the other side. She trembled all over, as it conscious of her peril, and staggered beneath her ponderous load; but thanks to her tremendous head- way she burrowed through what to most vessels would have been a watery grave, and shaking off her liquid burden proclaime 1 her victory over this mighty monster of the deep Our trials, dear friends, are like those billows of the sea. We are compelled to meet them, whether we will or not, for in the voyage of life, before we reach the western haven of rest each one of us is certain to have his share of trouble. All afflictions are grievous to be borne, and now and then one comes which makes the soul shiver in every fibre of its being, and threatens it with destruction, Down goes the soul in the dark

articles.headline: Untitled Snippet
articles.full_text: waters of misery, and it is a question som times whether it will rise again and shake o its load of sorrow. As a matter of fact, som people never do survive these terrible ex periences; orce thus submerged, they giv up in despair and sink out of sight. But th true Christian, trusting in God and "strengthened with might by his spirit is the inner man," never loses his headway even though troubles rise up mountain high If he cannot go over them he has God-given power to go through them and come ou more than conqueror on the other side. Ou trials may strip us dear friends, but they cannot overwhelm us if the motive power o faith in God is strong and real. Take thi power to-day and make it your own. It wil help you through the trials of this life, and dive you an abundant entrance into the life

articles.headline: TELEGRAPHIC TICKS.
articles.full_text: TELEGRAPHIC TICKS. In Montreal there was a change of 48° in the temperature in 24 hours, more than the range for a whole year in Florida. The mayor, aldermen, and city officials o Minneapolis, Minn., to the number of 35 intend shortly paying Montreal a visit. The Assistant Secretary of the United States Department of State says there is no of record any treaty having been agreed upon between the United States and Newfound land. At its meeting on Monday night the To ronto City Council by unanimous vote ap pointed a special committee to enquire into the leasibility of securing water by gravi tation from Lake Simcoe. The Hamburger Nachrichten expresses con tempt for the threatened persecution of it self and Prince Bismarck, and says it will take full responsibility for everything the Prince has written, his motives being patri- otic and not ambitious or revengeful. In the Montreal Superior Court the city and Policeman Limoges were condemned to pay Courcelles the sum of $500 and costs on account of injuries inflicted upon him by the policeman, who arrested him with unneces- sary violence last September. A Jewish rabbi and a physician, living in Grodno, have been exiled for two years for sending a petition to the Government on behalf of a Jew boy, accused of larceny, who had been branded on the forehead with "thief" in three languages by a Russian doctor. Father Maissonneuve, a veteran mission ary, who went to the North-West in 1848, when he performed the greater portion of the journey in a vehicle drawn by steers, is at present on a visit to Montreal. He is 66 years of age, and quite deaf from the hard- ships he suffered. Saddler, who was arrested in White- chapel on suspicion of having murdered "Carotty Nell," was brought before the Police Magistrate the other day. Evidence was given that he was seen in the company of the woman shortly before her death, and the case was adjourned till the 24th inst. For Izaak Walton. What trout shall coax thy rod of yore In Itchen stream to dip! What lover of her banks restore That sweet Socratic lip? Old fishing, and wishing. Are over many a year, O hush thee! O hush thee! Heart innocent and dear. Again the foamy shallows fill. The quiet clouds amass. And soft as bees by Catherine Hill At dawn the anglers pass. And follow the hollow. In boughs to disappear. O hush thee! O hush thee! Heart innocent and dear. Nay, rise not now, nor with them take One silver freekled fool! Time's newer breed bring each an ache For ancient arts to cool: But, father, lie rather Unhurt and idle near. O hush thee! O hush thee! Heart innocent and dear. While thought of thee to men is yet A sylvan playfellow. Ne'er by thy marble they forget In pious cheer to go. As air falls, the prayer falls O'er kingly Winchester: "O hush thee! O hush thee Heart innocent and dear

articles.headline: LOUISE I MOGEN GUIMEY.
articles.full_text: LOUISE I MOGEN GUIMEY. Hood's Sarsaparilla Is a concentrated extract of Sarsaparilla, Yellow Dock, Pipsissewa, Juniper Berries, Mandrake, Dandelion, and other valuable vegetable remedies, every ingredient being strictly pure, and the best of its kind it is possible to buy. articles.headline: ALLEN DESCRIPTIONS
articles.full_text: ALLEN DESCRIPTIONS been indefatigable in his endeavours to n the best of those exhibits which wer hand in good time. Mr. Adam Brown deserves a great deal of credit for his v able assistance in making the best poss display of decorations and for the gen appearance of the Canadian departm With all the drawbacks referred to, the nothing in the exhibition which has attr ed more general admiration than the dis of Canadian products and manfactures. the second night, as part of the program an exhibition of Canadian views by li light took place in the grounds at the rea the exhibition. The views were very f and reflected a great deal of credit on gentleman who had been at great pains collect them all over Canada. They give better idea of our beautiful public buildi than all the pamphlets published by the partment of Emigration put together. the views were thrown upon the canvass interesting descriptive lecture was given Mr. Grenville. Many of the business men here have be examining our various manufactures, a are surprised at the admirable quality goods produced in Canada. It now become in order to examine and test prices and a freight charges from the various proving as compared with prices and freights fre the United States and England. The countries are our powerful competitors, though we have formidable rivals in France Germany, and Spain for this West Ind trade. Now, the first thing necessary h fore we can hold our own in this market a weekly line of good steamers from Ha nd St. John. As soon as this mark was ward over o course and boost on this mittel is opened up to us consignments may shipped of all the various lines which has been ascertained to be desirable. There no doubt that the Lower Provinces w have the advantage of shorter freights, by with a liberal railway rate for Ontario the province will not be far behind the race The various cotton manufactures should b able to hold their own in the West Indi trade; it only requires perseverance and little patience. The English manufacture has a firm hold in many lines; but in others once we introduce our goods, they woul soon become popular. There is a good man ket here for flour, potatoes, apples, canne goods of all kinds, butter, and cheese, and there is no market in which we cannot suc cessfully meet competition in these products Then again, pianos, organs, furniture, manu factures of wood, brushes, brooms, whis keys, bottled ales and porter can al be sold at a profit here. In anothe letter I will deal in detail with the market for these manufactures. Carriages buggies, horses, agricultural implements o certain kinds, soaps, perfumery, syrups Canadian wines are all in demand here, and at prices that will pay. The duties are moderate, and there should be little or no difficulty in disposing of these things or consignment at a moderate profit. The business men here are on the alert, and will give the Canadians equal chances, but no more, and it will rest largely with exporters from Canada to see that their goods come up to the proper standard. The trade of this island is an important one, and is largely in the hands of the United States manu- facturers, who will not easily let it slip out

articles.headline: Untitled Snippet
articles.full_text: The decision of judge Thayer of Missouri, if sustained, will do much to rob the Alien Labor law of its terrrors for those manufac turers and others who desire to import work- men from abroad. The case which the learn- ed judge was called upon to decide was that of a manufacturer in Missouri who wrote to workmen in England, telling them he could give them steady work, and sending them tickets, which they used in coming from England to this country. Judge Thayer holds that the letters and the sending of the tickets "do not constitute an express con- tract." In the light of this interpretation it will not be difficult to evade the law which unless modified so as to accomplish the thing intended, had a thousand times better be re pealed. Otherwise its existence on the statute books will only tend to break down

articles.full_text:
LORD ROSSLYN ese al- The Patrol Systen in Street Cleaning ce, lia One dces not require to read the No e- York city papers very closely to discov is that there is very great dissatisfacti li- among the inhabitants of the America et metropolis with the manner in which i streets are attended to. Not so very los ve ago one of their leading journals compare is their city to Constantinople, which for filth ill-kept streets has become a by-word amor ut the nations. It is now proposed to chang at this condition of things, if possible. A ne e. system, called by its originator the "patr ia
a system," is to be thoroughly tested. Th system divides the streets among th cleaners much as the streets are divide among policemen. Each cleaner has certain length of street under his charge he must wear a numbered badge, and prob ably a uniform cap, and must keep his par d of the street in order. In case any par d of a street is neglected, the citizens inter ested will be able to place the responsibility . Besides the individual cleaners, roundsmen or inspectors to look after the cleaners ar contemplated by the patrol system, and in 1 general such a supervision as is relied on to r keep policemen up to the mark. Beside this there is a collection system adapted to the piece-work cleaning. The system looks 2 very well on paper. Nor does there appear any good reason why it should not accomplish all that its friends promise. The chief objection against it is, that it is likely to be expensive. But if the results are satisfactory the difference of expense will not be gru

articles.headline: Untitled Snippet
articles.full_text: Chicago and the horld's Fair. Chicago is perplexed. The World's Fair which it was supposed could be carried through for $10,000,000 is now estimated to require at least $15,000,000, of which the greater part will require to be paid out be- fore any returns from the Exposition comes in. Where to get the more than $5,000,000 over and above the amount subscribed by private citizens and the amount derivable from the city's bonds is a question that is troubling the Executive Committee. Some suggest bonding the gate receipts to the ex- tent of $5,000,000, while others who oppose this as seeming too much like mortgaging a patriotic enterprise, affirm that the capi- tal stock of the Exposition Company must be increased to $10,000,000 without delay. Should the gate receipts realize phonin the gave receiped realize an onat to expected there will still remain a difference of nearly $5,000,000 between the expense of providing the show and the gains derived therefrom. Had the people of the garden city foreseen what they now know, it is questionable whether they would have fought | so persistently for the honor and-the labor.

articles.headline: Untitled Snippet
articles.full_text: Death From Fright. An inquest was held in London on atur- day, on the body of Ada Lousia Elflain, aged 16, a factory hand employed at a rope works. Emily Davis, a fellow worker, stated that the deceased had only been employed at the factory for about a fortnight. On Thursday, about mid-day, the deceased and witness were working side by side, when the deceased suddenly put up her hand, and witness knew that something was wrong. On going to see she found that the pin of the machine had broken. Deceased suddenly fell on the floor, and witness being unable to revive her, sent for a doctor, who on his ar- rival, pronounced life extinct. By the Jury: The pins did brake occasionally, but there was no danger attached to their doing so. Dr. Franklyn Hilliard, 126, Romanroad, de-

articles.full_text:
BY EDWARD BELLAMY. III-The (Author of "Looking Backward "etc., etc.) tion in It is assumed that the year 2000 will see er is the | Nationalism fully established as the basis uldering of the industrial system and of society, so ken out far as dependant upon it. Judging from the ferment signs of the times I think it would be quite wholly safe to make the date seventy-five years ekly oc. earlier, but for the benefit of those weak in an or the faith it is set well ahead. As there are he part | doubtless some who do not understand very l of the | clearly what Nationalism is, it may be well are out | enough just here to explain, so far as may extend | be done in a phrase that it proposes turning unions over all the business of the country to a will be single firm, of which all the people women were the property would be able woulden as well as men, shall be employes, and in the ill. | the proceeds of which all shall be equal part- y firms | ners. Leaving wholly aside, for the present nipping purpose, all the explanations as to the de- to pay | tails of this plan, and all questions as to ge non- its feasibility, it is simply proposed to point lying 3 out certain ways in which the position of en they women would be affected by its successful nen for introduction. Weare to suppose that every adult woman ool has | in the United States-while required, like to the every adult man (except as modified by sex while conditions), to perform some self-elected nctive useful work-had coming to her a regular annual income in the form of credit to be by the expended as she pleased, equal, say, to the sumed present purchasing power of $1000, $3000 or ed the $5000, more or less, according to the pros- perity of the national firm, said income to be the same in amount with that received by her brother, husband or father, but not to come to her through them or through any tland other intermediary, but directly from the rticu- national administration, as a matter of con- Mr. stitutional right. law- Now, considering the fact that woman, story owing to her comparative physical disqualifi- n this cations as a worker, has hitherto been, as a more rule, wholly or partially dependant upon the citi- favor or affection of man for the means of a aying secure and comfortable existence, it is evi- o on dent that a system like that described. name | would, by rendering her entirely indepen- other dent of men in this respect, make a great mself | alteration in her position. Obviously the most important single re- e an spect in which it would be altered would be well- as to her attitude towards marriage. She They | would no longer be obliged, as most women- antly now are, to look forward to marriage as iston offering, if not absolutely her only means of ry to support, yet at least as constituting ber the main hope of a secure and comfortable life .. mer The only possible motive which would; pint- then impel her to give herself to a man n to would be that she loved him. May and but | December might still mate, Beauty might ther still wed the Beast, but the sourest cynic Mr | would no longer be able to attribute an un- ect. worthy motive to the bride. However sor- tea did she might become under temptation, din- then there could be none, for not only would g of she be under no necessity of marrying atall. im- but the wealth of all her possible suitors just | being the same, she could have no motive, ath save love or admiration for marrying one act. | more than another. Not only, however, would Nationalism yer full backwirder woman diginty and independence vait before marriage, but equally afterward. ver | That event in no way would affect her rights te a as a citizen and a partner in the national con- who cern. The humiliation of complete pecuniary a dependence upon their husbands, of being se. obliged to ask for all they have, beyond bare so- bread and meat, which the best and noblest ow of wives now have to endure, the wife of the his year 2000 would never know. Let us suppose, on the other hand, that he ! the heart, remaining untouched, she had preferred to remain single. Would you gain a realization of the posi- tion of the "old maid" in the year 2000? If so, look at the lordly bachelor of to-day, the ter hero of romance, the cynosure of the drawing room and of the promenade. Even as that nd bright being, like him self-poised, serenely ny insouciant, free as air, will the "old maid" ho of the year 2000 be. It is altogether prob- in able, by the way, that the term "old maid" will by that time have fallen into disuse. But while the unmarried woman of the ed a year 2000, whether young or old, will enjoy the dignity and independence of the bache- lor of to-day, the insolent prosperity at pres- ne ent enjoyed by the latter will have passed ld into salutary, if sad, eclipse. No longer pro- fiting by the effect of the pressure of econom- d ic necessity upon woman, to make him in- dispensable, but dependent exclusively upon y his intrinsic attractions, instead of being able to assume the fastidious airs of a sultan sur- g rounded by languishing beauties, he will be fortunate if he can secure by his merits the y smiles of one.
In the year In the year 2000 no man, whether lover or husband, may hope to win the favor of maid or wife save by desert. While the poet, just- e ly apprehending the ideal proprieties, has always persisted in representing man at the feet of woman, woman has been, in fact, the dependent and pensioner of man. National- ism will justify the poet and satisfy the etern- al fitness of things by bringing him to his marrow-bones in earnest. But, indeed, we may be sure that in the year 2000 he will need no compulsion to assume that attitude. It implies no disloyalty to the womanhood; of to-day to believe that the personal dignity and moral freedom, unknown before to her sex, which will be the birthright of woman. in the twentieth century, cannot fail to react most favorably upon herself, ennobling her graces, clothing with a new majesty her beauty and making her every way more worthy than ever before of the reverence and devotion of man. There is another and profoundly tragic The second terres broughters A property aspect of the relation of the sexes, which by no means may be passed over in considering what Nationalism will do for womanhood. The same economical pressure which brings the mass of women into a relation of depend- ence upon men, rendered more or less toler- able according to the degree of mutual affec- tion, reduces a great multitude of women, who are not fortunate enough to find ade- quate masculine support, to a form of slavery more morally degrading than any other, and more complete in its indignity. This most ancient form of bondage, which has grown up with the race and flourishes to-day in the face of civilization and Christendom as wide- ly and vigorously as ever, which no wisdom of the economist, no zeal of the philanthrop- ist has ever availed to diminish, National- ism, by the necessary operation of its funda-

articles.headline: Untitled Snippet
articles.full_text: Mr. McLean in his address states th his reason for opposing Bryson is becau he did not fulfil his promises respecti the bonus. When Bryson asserted th the county would not have to pay a ce of it, he supposed that it was not o women or children he was ad lressing, b men who would put a common-sense i terpretation on his words. He did n expect to find an elector so ignorant as n to know that neither he nor anyone el could say with certainty what the decision of the courts would be; but he believe in his immost soul that the claim the bond holder was unjust and therefo unlawful. Weighty legal opinion co firmed him in this view, then what he be neved to be fact he asserted as fact. The courts have rendered an adverse decision but how is he responsible for that? What wrong has anyone suffered beyond disag pointment, and in that no one suffere more than himself. The attempt, then to lay the odium of the bonus on Bryson' shoulders is only a mean election dodge- he had nothing to do with it. It was Mr . McLean's mission to saddle us with it and he saddled us, entirely to his satis faction, realizing $11,000 by the job, a soon as the girths were tightened. . Nov the electors should consider which of the two men is more worthy of confidence Hector McLean, who moved heaven and earth to induce the county to grant the bonus, in which he unfortunately suc ceeded, and then put more than one tenth in his pocket, which comes out of the pockets of the electors; or John Bry son, who never took any part in rivetting it on us, made no money by it, but lost money as well as time in trying to free us of it. Mr. McLean brings no other charge against Mr. Bryson than that of the bon- us; this speaks well for the latter; it shows, too, that if Mr. McLesn has any- thing to say against him it is on some small and quite local matter that he is unwilling to bring forward as he knows it would not be acceptable to the majority of the electors, though it might suit him- self and a few wire pullers well enough. In view of the above facts which he that runs may read, we believe that just now the interests of the county are safer in Bryson's hands than in those of his wor- thy opponent. We rather mefer to trust the man who is not ashamed to say that he will stand by the great statesman who has raised Canada from colonial obscurity to the rank of a great arm of the British Empire, than the man who in his first ad- dress comes out as an Independent, in his second as Independent-Liberal-Conserva- tive, and whom we may expect to hear from in the next Advance as I dependent- Liberal Conservative-Grie National, and who having pledged himself to nothing may without breach of faith exchange his vote for some little subsidy to bring grist to his own mill.

articles.full_text:
Larocque, the murderer of the Mc ogle children has been sentenced to for hanged on the 4th of June at L'Orig In his address to the jury Judge McM on said: Gentlemen of the jury .-- charge that is made against the prise ers at the bar is one of that character w renders it double obligatory on you up weigh well every title of evidence ub- has been adduced before you at this to ew The responsibility which you have ta e. and the obligation of your oath is which may well appal the strongest n we But great as is your responsibility i one which you cannot avoid any m mer by than that which rests upon me and the event of the prisoner being for ad- | quilty Vone duty is to waich the or Samely a court courty to to workin the 6. pay ence well and give your decision with one fear, favor or affection. I ask you to un- ree. aside all impressions which you n have formed regarding this case bef on. you entered the jury box and I ask y ral ion to abliterate all predilections. The o the that you have taken that you will nd lar true virdict give" is one which will ! ner men who take an interest in the welf in- of their country to act in justice and ion yet the protection of society.' Continui on circumstantial evidence, illustration his remarks by two supposed cases.

then reviewed the evidence in every tail whilst the crowded hall was without ral a single sound. Concluding he sai ch | Lion, gentlemen on the jury, if you if at from the evidence that the prisoner w in the woods with the children on this : n. ternoon, he is called upon to answer i what became of them. He denies havi been in their company. He says 'I d not go in that road at all.' Now gentl n, men, was he the person who committe m this crime? On the other hand if yo iis have any reasonable doubt the prisoner 3- entitled to it, but if your minds are from et from doubt you will say so. With wh is the result will be you have nothing to d The law prescribes what the result wi E. be. The conclusion of this address relieve the pent up tension, and at five o'clock tl 1, jury retired. The excitement was renev st is than half an hour they filed into the d. places. "Have you agreed upon you verdict?" asked Clerk Fraser. "W a have" replied Foreman McIntosh "gui ty." A shudder ran through the hal 1. the muscles of the prisoners jaw twitche is violently and for a moment his complexion assumed a greenish whiteness but imme 10 diately returned to its clayey color. " Narcisse Larocque what have you t k say why the sentence of the court shoul not be passed upon you," asked th f- judge. Cool and collected showing n d agitation the prisoner stood leaning wit his arm against the rail of his box " e In passing sentence the judge assume . I his omeiai nat and said: Perhaps in th annals of crime in this country there i none more diabolical than that which wa e committed and which the jury very pro perly find you guilty. The circumstance a all point to you as the guilty party. You were last seen in their company and you being a friend of the family, you ought to have protected them from any hand rais e ed against them. Instead of that you voilate them and in order to cover up your crime, committed the deed of which you now stand convicted. I do not intend to harrow your feelings. Time will be allowed to you. My province is to pass sentence upon you. The sentence from whence you came within the pre cints of the gaot of the united counties of Prescott and Russell, to return to the place of execution on the 4th day of June and there executed according to law be- tween the hours of 8 and 12 a. m., and may the Lord Almighty have mercy on your soul.

Prisoner was removed without showing a tremor.

articles.full_text: Monday, May 4th. - The House met at at 3 p. m. on Friday, May 1st, with the newly elected speaker in the chair. A large number of petitions were presented, after which his excellency's speech from Throne was taken up for consideration. Mr. Hazen, of St. John, N. B., was the mover, and Mr. Carbould of British Col- umbia, the seconder of the address. Both gentlemen made able speeches, showing the progressive policy of the Government, in having acquired and opened up the North West, thus adding to the prestige which Canada enjoys in the world, and that while willing to treat on fair terms with our neighbor to the south of us, yet would not go so far as to imperil our con- nection with the motherland or forfeit medelon when the middle control of the solder our allegiance to the British Flag, under whose protecting folds we have so long lived and prospered. That the financial affairs of the country are in a healthy state, and that we were paying a lower rate of interest than at any time since confederation. Mr. Hazen said the people of New Brunswick had declared against unrestricted reciprocity by a majority of 4,599. Mr. Carbould said it was not a sign of disapproval of the Government's policy, that British Columbia had return- ed six members to support Sir John, -two by acclamation, and the opponents of
