articles.headline: EIGHT YEARS.
articles.full_text: EIGHT YEARS. Escape of a Would-be Suicide. Since 1871 the Congregational churches in England have increased from 3,069 to 4,730. A scheme for a Sunday theatre is being promoted in London and is expected to suc- ocea. A youth named Garnor died on Saturday in Stockport Infirmary from injuries re- ceived in a football match. On the railway works near Killybegs, County Donegal, on Saturday, a dynamite charge suddenly exploded, killing a labourer named M. David and injuring several others. The Barre Railway, or chemin do fer gliss ant, is in operation at the Crystal Palace. Perhaps it is the railway of the future. Last year the London youth wore their hat brims within half an inch of the nose. This year's fashion tilts the hat backward. A Lowestoft shrimp boat shipped a sea when crossing Holm Sand on Tuesday after- noon and was swamped. Two fishermen, brothers, named Smith, were drowned. The Kussian ship Vilriin was wrecken off the Lincolnshire coast on Tuesday night. The masts were cut away, and the crew were rescued by the lifeboat on Wednesday. In the the census at Camberwell Work- house, London, on Monday, Polly Thomson was returned at 104 years of age. In the same institution several of the inmates were stated to be 99, 98, 97, and 95 years of age. A novel feature of a menagerie s exhibiting at the Crystal Palace, London, is a huge cage containing a happy family of twelve lions, three Bengal tigers, and cheetahs, panthers, Polar and Thibe: bears, ponies, goats, and boar hounds, numbering twenty in all. An English North Country church has published a scale for contributions expected for the collection plate. The church will be content if it receive two-pence for every five shillings of income, or three per cent. A man in receipt of £30 a week is expected to give a sovereign. A small trial at Aerdrie, a weighman hav- - been dismissed by a committee of miners for drunkenness, showed that the Judge would place absolutely no reliance on the testimony of teetotalers, he declared that they were so extreme in their views that their evidence was sure to be colored. Owing to whooping-cough, James Davis, a potman, of Randolph Street, Camden Town, London, lost three children in one day. They were all little girls. It tran- spired that nine persons occupied one room, which the coroner thought was rather close. At Maidenhead Police Court on Tuesday morning. William Sadler, the man who was

articles.headline: TANCE ALLERS TO ALLERS TO COLORS OF THE PARTY OF THE COLORS
articles.full_text: TANCE ALLERS TO ALLERS TO COLORS OF THE PARTY OF THE COLORS charged with being the perpetrator of the last Whitechapel murder, was sentenced to seven days' hard labour for having been drunk in the town on Monday night. A band of moonlighters attacked the house of Michael O'Shaughnessy, caretaker, Doolie Bridge, County Clare, and fired a shot through the window. The police, hav- ing received information of the intended attack, were in waiting in the house, and fired buckshot, and dangerously wounded one of the assailants. Three others were arrested. Much sensation has been created in the mining district of Swansea by the elopement of a well-known prize fighter employment at the collieries with the wife of the land- lord of a Swansea hotel. The errant pair, who are believed to have set sail for America had, it is alleged, taken from the hotel £40 and several valuable articles. At Castle Eden, Durham, Police Court, on Saturday, six miners were committed to prison for fourteen days each in default of paying damages and costs adjudged against them for stopping Thornley Colliery on the --- occasion of the Silksworth evictions. Seventy more men refused to pay. A fund has been started to support the families of the imprisoned men. A London surgeon has just recorded an extraordinary case. A patient, a man aged 45 years, who swallowed a pin when seven years old, has just coughed up the pin. He was in good health for 24 years, but then developed symptoms like consumption. He was troubled with huskiness of voice and constant cough. Since the pin was expelled the man has recovered. The doctor is satis- fied the pin was in the man's larynx for 38 years. A Bolton mill girl named Elizabeth Ellen Monks committed suicide on Monday night by drowning herself in a mill reservoir near her home and the body was fished out yes- terday morning by the police. In her pocket was a letter addressed to her parents, and couched in a very religious strain. She said she had been driven to suicide by bad work, and that she had dreamed she would drown herself. She was only 17 years of age. A young man named Jasper Clark, of Eastbourne Road, Brentford, clerk to the firm of Messrs Ruston, Clark, & Ruston, sol- icitors, Brentford, met with a shocking death on Monday morning. About nine o'clock he visited Old Castle Inn, Isleworth, and in- formed the landlord that he had been shoot- ing birds. He was carrying a double-bar- relled fowling piece. A few minutes after taking refreshments he was found dead in the urinal with the top of his head blown off-it is thought, the result of an accident. A youth named Andrews visited athletic sports at Ramsey, Huntingdonshire. On returning home in a state of intoxication he committed a serious assault on a woman. In avoiding the husband, who pursued him, he fell into a reservoir, but escaped. He after- wards threw himself in front of a train on the Great Eastern Railway, and was cut to pieces. At the inquest the jury returned a verdict that the deceased "committed sui- cide at the instigation of the devil." On Tuesday Dr G Danford Thomas

articles.headline: OH THOUSERS TILL OF THEFT THE THEFT
articles.full_text: OH THOUSERS TILL OF THEFT THE THEFT held an inquest at the St. Giles' Coroner's Court, London, respecting the death of Charles Harcourt, aged 50 years. The deceased, a French waiter, had been out of employment for some time, and had been sleeping in a shed. On Tuesday morning a police sergeant on duty in Shaftesbury Avenue found him in a helpless and dirty condition. The man was William with

articles.headline: Untitled Snippet
articles.full_text: ill and unable to speak, therefore the ambu lance was procured, and he was removed to the St. Giles' Workhouse, where he soon afterwards died. Dr. Shoard deposed tha death was due to exhaustion when suffering from congestion of the lungs, accelerated by the want of food, exposure, and self neglect. The jury returned a verdict in accordance with the evidence. A startling incident took place at the Central Station, Liverpool, on Monday. An express from Manchester was observed en- tering the station at an unusually high speed, dashed into the stationary buffers at the end of the station, which were shattered, and the engine mounted the main platform. The station was busy at the time, and a nt angued There I scene of great excitement cusucu. Andre were about 300 passengers in the train, but none complained of injuries. The cause of the accident is unknown. The analysis of the registration in Chicago where voters are required to declare the place of their birth when registering, is of interest at the present time. Out of 172,353 voters who registered last fall, 81,172 were native American whites and 3,141 native negroes. Of the 88,061 foreign born voters 32,964 were Germans. Add to these 1,410 Austrians and 622 Swiss, and the total Ger- man-speaking element is represented by 34,. 996 voters out of 171,353, or about 20 per cent. of the whole. The Irish born voters number 19,335; the English, Welsh, and Scotch 7,384, and the Canadians 4,345. The Scandinavians, Swedes, Norwegians, and Danes together were 9,708 strong. There were 3,444 Bohemians registered, and 2,773 Poles. An exciting incident took place at Rich- mond Railway Station the other night. As the up train was entering the station a well- dressed man rushed to the edge of the plat- form, threw his stick on the line, and ex- claiming "Here goes!" deliberately jumped in front of the approaching engine. The train passed over him. On, however, a search being made, it was discovered that the man had had a marvellous escape, for beyond a slight cut on the face he had entire- ly escaped injury. At the police station he was identified as a well-known resident named Clifford. A note, in which he intimated his intention of committing suicide, was found upon him. The German Emperor has ordered that a list of officers who took part in the military races Sunday be presented to him. He is very indignant over the matter. It is in contemplation to manufactur- Martini Henry ammunition at the Govern- ment cartridge factory at Quebec this year, Major Prevost, superintendent of the factory. in a report to the Department, says very little is required in the matter of machinery to enable the factory to manufacture Martini- Henry ammunition. Most of the component parts of the cartridge can be made with the present plant, and a few additions at a trifl- ing cost are all that is wanted to meet a de- mand actually existing in this country, and which is sufficiently important to make it worth while adding to the yearly output of the establishment, with a view to reducing as much as possible the general expenses, which must of necessity fall heavily on a limited production. Major Prevost's sug- gestions bear on a point quite distinct from any question of re-armament of the militia with Martini-Heary rifles, which may or may not be contemplated. His proposal is merely to supply a demand which can be met by manufacturing at Quebec what until now has been imported. He says that, if made in Canada, it can be sold to the rifle sasociations at a cheaper rate than the im ported ammunition now costs. The Age of Decay. Birth, growth, maturity, decay, death- such is the norma! history of man. The three periods of life should sustain a certain proportion to each other: twenty years of growth, sixty years of maturity, twenty years of decay. This is what might be counted upon as the ordinary course of human life, but for the fact that we labor under a load of ancestral transgression of physical and moral law, supplemented and intensified by our own personal delinquencies and follies. How pleasant is the picture! Twenty years of happy childhood and youth, sixty years of intellectual progress and achieve- ment, with domestic and social joys, and then twenty years of slow, almost uncons- a decay characterized by sevenity of cious decay, characterized by scremely or mind, pleasing memories, and joyous antici- pations of a grander life beyond the grave. Sadly different is human existe co as we see it. We look with wonder upon Glad- ne, past eighty, still vigorous in body and mand, still strong and wise to lead the great Liberal party of England, We accept threescore and ten as life's natural limit, and expect only labor and sorrow if this limit is passed. We are doomed, we think, by our inherit- ance; and to some extent this is true. But we should remember the law of recuperation. The torn flesh heals; the broken bone re- unites. Diseases tend toward recovery. The weary toiler rises from sleep strong for new labors. The wise physician bases his hopes upon this law. And this tendency of nature to heal her- self may be greatly assisted by careful and intelligent living, so that it is always pos- sible that the man of unfortunate ancestry may secure for himself a good old age, and start his posterity upon an ascending plane. Do what we will, however, life must have its end. When the age of decay is reached, hidden changes are going on, the culmina- tion of which is the last great change. The muscles shrink; the brain shrivels; nerves lose their sensibility and active power; the arteries, perhaps, become chalky orfatty; the heart is weakened; the circulation en- feebled; and at last the end comes. During this final period, then, we must take things calmly; avoid excesses of all kinds; guard against exposures to cold; keep up a degree of mental activity; cultivate cheerfulness, and look forward with hope. At Portsmouth, on Saturday evening, a naval pensioner named Watts shot his wife and then attempted suicide. The parties had been separated for a month, the man work- ing in London and the wife living with her parents at Portsmouth. Watts came from London apparently with a view to reconcili- ation, and saw his wife at her parents' house. Before the interview has lasted ten minutes revolver shots were heard, and it was found that the woman had received two wounds in the head, one in the throat, and one in the breast. Watts was about to shoot himself when his brother seized his arm, and the bullet only penetrated his wrist. He was taken into custody.

articles.headline: Untitled Snippet
articles.full_text:
THE HERO OF 1812. Brock's Administration in Upper Canada— The Difficulties He Faced and Overcome. Brock's Administration in Upper Canada- General Brock was appointed president General Brock was appointed president Upper Canada on the 9th October, 1811.
On the 2nd December, the same year, he says, in a letter to Sir George Prevost: "I cannot conceal from your excellency that unless a strong regular force be present to fected nothing effectual can be expected." On the 4th February, 1812, Brock opened the session of the Legislature and urged upon the House: 1. A militia supplement- of the Halvage lary Act. 2. The suspension of the Habeas Corpus Act. 3. Analien law. 4. The offer of a reward for the apprehension of desert- ers. "The many doubtful characters in the militia," he says in one of his despatches, "made me anxious to introduce the eath of abjuration into the bill. It was lost by the casting vote of the chairman. The great in- fluence which the numerous settlers from the United States possess over the decisions of the Lower House is truly alarming, and to be diminished." The bill for the suspen- sion of the habeas corpus was also beaten by a very trifling majority. Willcocks, Mal- lory and Marcle were all members of this House and leading spirits of the Opposition. When war was declared Brock at once called out the flank companies of the militia. This produced a force on the Niagara frontier of 800 men, who turned out very cheerfully, and he calculated that all over the province the number would amount to about 4,000 men. In the dis- tricts originally settled by the U. E. Loyalists the flank companies were instant- ly completed with volunteers, an almost unanimous disposition to serve being mani- fested, and on these men General Brock seems to have depended to overawe the disaffected and to aid him in the field. In fact he said in answer to an address at Kingston that "it was the confidence in- spired by the admirable conduct of the York and Lincoln regiments of milita which had induced him to undertake the expedi- tion which terminated in the capture of Detroit." These men who were with him ... on he died at Ousenston were the sons when he died at wheenston were the some of the loyal veterans of the revolution. All along the St. Lawrence the same spirit was manifested, the men of Glengarry in particular performing at Chateauguay and in other fights the most brilliant service for Canada. On the 6th July General Brock issued a proclamation, ordering all persons sus- pected of traitorous intercourse with the enemy to be apprehended and treated according to law. His letters are filled with references to his anxiety as to the machinations of the disloyal and disaffect- ed.

articles.headline: HULL'S INVASION.
articles.full_text: HULL'S INVASION. On the 12th July General Hull invaded Canada at Sandwich, and the militia in that district behaved very ill. They seemed either to lose hope or to be disaffected. Five hun- dred of them, chiefly of those alien settlers, gave in their adhesion to the enemy, and a party of General Hull's cavalry, amount- ing only to about 50 men, led by a traitor named Watson, a surveyor from Montreal, were able to penetrate eastward as far as Westminster, about 110 miles east of Sand- wich, a conclusive proof of the apathy, to say the least, of the settlers in that district. The Yankee settlers in the Norfolk district also refused to turn out. At this time General Brock called the Parliament together, and on the 27th July, 1812, opened an extra session. In his speech he says, "A few trations have already joined the enemy; have been suffered to come into the country with impunity, and have been harbored and concealed in the interior. To protect and defend the loyal inhabitants from their machinations is an object worthy of your most serious de- liberation." His speech concluded with these well known and memorable words, showing in the face of all his difficulties and dangers, and in the face of overwhelming odds, the true heroism and confidence of a gallant soldier. "We are engaged in an awful and event- ful contest. By unanimity and despatch in our councils and by vigor in our operations we may teach the enemy this lesson, that a country defended by free men, enthusiastical- ly devoted to the cause of of their King and constitution, can never be conquered." Two days later Brock appealed to the militia of this place, the York flank com- panies, whether they would follow him any a province or out of it in defence where in this province of outoffe, in defence of it. The whole force volunteered cheer- fully, without a moment's hesitation. The House, however, refused to suspend the Habeas Corpus Act, or to act as promptly as he desired. The disloyal section, led by Willcocks, assisted by Abraham Marcle, did everything they could to thwart and embar rass General Brock. The state of the country certainly required prompt and vigorous measures, but many of the House of Assembly were seized with apprehensions and endeavored to avoid incurring the in- dignation of the enemy. In consequence of these difficulties Brock, feeling that General Hull's emissaries throughout the country were very numerous and active, called to- gether his excutive council on the 3rd August and made the following representa- tion to them: "That the House of A sembly, instead of prompt exertions to strengthen his handsf or the government of the militia, providing for security from internal treason by the partial suspension of the Habeas Corpus Act, auth- orizing a partial exercise of martial law con- currently with the ordinary course of justice, and placing at his disposal the funds not actually applied of the past appropriation, had consumed eight days in carrying a single measure of party, the repeal of the school bill, and passing an Act for the public dis- closure of treasonable practices before the magistrates should have power to commit without bail. That under these circumstances little could be expected from a prolonged sesssion. The enemy had invaded and taken post in the western district; was multiplying daily his preparations to invade in others; that the militia in a perfect state of insubor-

articles.headline: DITCH OTHER PROPERTY.
articles.full_text: DITCH OTHER PROPERTY. dination had withdrawn from the ranks in actual service; had refused to march when legally commanded to reinforce a detachment of regular forces for the relief of Amherts- burg; had insulted their officers, and some, not immediately embodied, had manifested in many instances a treasonable spirit of mutiny and disaffection; that the Indians on Grand river tampered with by disaffected

articles.headline: Untitled Snippet
articles.full_text: whites, had withdrawn from their vo unteer services, and declared for a neutra ity which was equally inadmissible a with the King's other subjects. That in th western and London districts several person had negetiated with the enemy's command er, hailing his arrival, and pledging their support. That the King's forces consister of the 41st 900 strong, part of the Royal Newfoundland 200, with a detachment of Royal Artillery and several vessels. That the extent of lars at Amherstburg, and he had made a large detachment of the 41st with militis from the home and Niagara districts. That the commandant at St. Joseph had taker Mackinac and might descend to Amherst burg, and compel the invaders to retreat, with the aid of the detachment now on the march to Long Point; but that no good result could be expected unless he had power to restrain the militia and general popula- tion from treasonable adherence to the enemy or neutrality by summary procedure, asked whether it would be expedient to prorogue the House of Assembly and pro- claim martial law.

articles.headline: VIGOROUS MEASURES TAKEN.
articles.full_text: VIGOROUS MEASURES TAKEN. The council adjourned till the next day, the 4th August, for deliberation, and then unanimously expressed the opinon that, under the circumstances of the colony, it was expedient from the prorogation of the Assembly that the gereral should proclaim and exercise martial law under authority of his commission from the King. On the 5th Brock prorogued the House and proclaimed martial law. In all probability the action contemplated by General Brock became known on the 4th, for on the 5th, day of prorogation, the loyal party carried in this same House a most spirited and patriotic address to the people of Upper Canada. In this it is stated that the population is deter- minedly hostile to the United States, and "the few that might be otherwise inclined will find it to their safety to be faithful," and calls upon the people to "deem no sacrifice too costly which secures the enjoy- ment of our happy constitution." The outlook must have been very disheart- ening to General Brock when he wrote this minute for the council on the 3rd August. With only a handful of troops and no money or supplies, with a House of Assembly weak and timorous, and containing a few infamous secret traitors, sufficiently influential to de- lay and embarrass every step for the defence of the country; with an invading army with- in our borders, and a portion of the militia in the invaded district mutinous and disloy- al. Mair, the author of Tecumseh, puts in Brock's mouth a fine picture of his difficul- ties and his manly courage: 'Tis true our province taces heavy odds; Of regulars but fifteen hundred men To guard a frontier of a thousand miles; Of volunteers what assistance we can draw From seventy thousand widely scattered souls- A meague showing 'gainst the enemy's, If numbers be the test. But odds lie not In numbers only, but in spirit too. Witness the might of England's little isle! And what made England great will keep her 80- The free soul and the valor of her sons: And what exalts her will sustain you now. If you contain her courage and her faith- So not the odds so much are to be feared As private disaffection, treachery- Those openers of the doors to enemies- And the poor crouching spirit that gives way Ere it is forced to yiela. The turning point was the pro- claiming of martial law on the 5th August. Then Brock was master of the situation, and the change in the prospects in a few days was almost miraculous. That very day the stirring address from the House went forth to the people. The next day Brock left for Amherstburg, arriving there on the 13th at midnight. On the 15th he was at Sandwich, with 330 regulars, 400 militia and 600 In- dians. On the morning of the 16th he cross- ed to the Michigan side of the river with these 1,330 men and captured Detroit, with the whole of Hull's army of 2,500 men and their immense stores and supplies. (Loud applause.) Two or three days after he set out again for York, where he arrived on the 27th August. The success at Detroit, so unexpected as it was, produced an electrical effect through- out Canada. It inspired the timid, fixed the wavering and awed the disloyal. After this event the disaffected saw that it was as much as their property was worth to disobey orders, and what they were at first compell- ed to do, after a little while they did from choice. Aliens were required to take the oath of allegiance or leave the province. Many were sent out of the country, large numbers left on their own account-pass- ports being furnished those desiring to leave.

articles.headline: POL DO DOLLES THE THE PROPERTY OF THE PROPERTY OF THE PROPERTY OF
articles.full_text: POL DO DOLLES THE THE PROPERTY OF THE PROPERTY OF THE PROPERTY OF Those who refused the oath of allegiance, or to take up arms to defend the country, and remained in the province after the 1st Janu- ary, 1813, were to be considered alien ene- mies and spies dealt with accordingly. When the militia of the London district were ordered out, Smith, the author already re- ferred to, says: " Many refused of their own accord and thers were persuaded so to refuse by a Mr. Culver and a Mr. Beamer and one more, who rode among the people for six days telling them to stand back. However, they were apprehended and the most of the people be- came obedient. After this they had their choice to go or stay, and some went." This power of compelling the traitorous to cease their treason soon bore fruit. Large numbers went to the States, among them three members of Parliament-Joseph Will- cocks, the leader of the Opposition, Benjamin Mallory and Abraham Marcle. At the next session Willcocks and Marcle, who were still members, were expelled the House "for their disloyal and infamous conduct in having traitorously deserted to the enemy." Mallory had not been re-elected in 1812. Willcocks was killed at Fort Erie in 1814 in command of a regiment in the Yankee army -Mallory served during the war as major in the same regiment. Fifteen traitors were tried at Ancaster during the war and sen- tenced to death. Seven of them were hanged together at that place by order of General Drummond and eight were sent to Quebec for punishment. A large number of the disloyal must have been arrested and put in prison very early in the war, for on the day of the battle of Queenston Heights, October 13, 1812, the jail and sourt house at Niagara were filled with political prisoners, as well as the block house in Fort George, amount- ing altogether to over 300 aliens and traitors in custody, with only a few raw militia to guard them. When Brock lost his life at Queenston he did not have many more than 300 soldiers with him in action, as the main forces had not come up. After the com- mencement of the war the officers of the

articles.headline: Untitled Snippet
articles.full_text:
1. army, the Indians and the loyal militia all volunteered their service to force the few s laggards into the ranks. They thought it e hard and unreasonable that they should s | bear all the burden and dangers of the war, - and numbers of them were zealously engaged r in bringing forward the disobedient. Some d | 40 men of Col. Grahame's regiment refused I to turn out in the neighborhood of Whit- of church township and retired into the t | wilderness, and the whole regiment volun- t | teered to go and fetch them in, an offer 1 Col. Graham did not accept, probably t feeling that such men were better in the · woods. The result of the war was practically that the disloyal minority were driven out, and t the apathetic, unable to avoid serving the Country, soon became enthusiastic in the . cause. Three years of war weeded out the bad elements a d welded the Canadians into a loyal and pat otic people. It also stop-
ped the Yankee emigration, and afterwards the country was filled up with loyal English Irish and Scotch, who settled here that they might retain their allegiance and remain under their flag. Canada can never again be called upon to face such dangers and difficulties. It seems impossible that the odds could ever again be anything like so great against us, yet there are too many sons of Canada born upon her soil and too many other men loyal to their sovereign and to the land of their adoption for a small fraction of strangers to be able to seriously endanger the national life.

articles.headline: TELEGRAPHIC TICKS.
articles.full_text: TELEGRAPHIC TICKS. The Inman Line steamship City of Paris is again afloat. The revolutionary forces in Chili have captured Copiapo. Richard Carrie, a London Township farme er, hanged himself in his barn. The Argentine Government will isoe. paper currency based on the silver reserve. Honolulu advices indicate that an attempt will be made to overturn the monarchy and establish a republic. The Anaconda mines, in Montana, are said to have been sold to a British syndicate for $25,000,000. A decree has been issued dealing with the St. Petersburg Jews in the same way as those of Moscow were "regulated." The Chinese Government having refused to receive Mr. Blair as United States Min- ister, that gentleman has been appointed Minister to Japan. Mrs. Grimwood, widow of the British political agent killed at Manipur, makes a statement which reflects severely on Com- mander Quinton's management. Mr. Forwood, a onservative M. P., in a public address said the Salisbury Govern- ment would dissolve Parliament if its free education plans were obstructed. At L'Orignal Narcisse Larocque was found guilty of the murder of the McConigle girls near Cumberland, and was sentenced to be bringen on oune a. B. P. Hutchinson, better known as "Old Hutch," a prominent speculator on the Chi- cago Board of Trade, mysteriously disap- peared yesterday. He has lost much money in his recent operations. His Buried Leg Pained Him. "That reminds me," said the man who is always being reminded of something. "What is it that reminds you, and what of ?" "This item about a man having his leg buried the other day. I wonder if he will have the same experience as a friend of mine. Strangest thing I ever heard of. You see, this poor fellow had suffered untold agony for a year or more after injuring his right leg by falling down stairs, and finally water and the second second second second second second second second second second second second second second second second second second second second second second second second second second second second second secon the member became so diseased that ampu- tation was necessary. The man nearly died under the operation, though that is not the interesting part of the story. The removed portion of the leg was taken away and buried. It is well known, of course, to sur- gical science that when a man has had a limb cut off he still suffers, or thinks he suf- fers, pain, which amounts to the same thing, in the part of the member removed. It was so in this case, and as my friend came back to consciousness his constant complaint was of the most severe pain in the buried foot. "' There is something pressing upon it," he would say, in what seemed like delirium. 'It's packed too tightly.' "Now the sufferer knew nothing of wher or how his lost limb was buried but as e matter of fact, it had been swathed in a lot of hay, packed tightly in a box, and the whole put under ground. Day after day went on, the suffering of the man with the buried leg and foot grew intolerable, until finally he begged his brother to dig up the piece of li'eless flesh, remove its wrappings, and change its position in the box. Only a sick man's whim, thought the brother, who was nursing the unfortunate fellow. Still, why he could never explain, he too was seized with a fancy that if he were to do as the invalid wished, and then tell him about it, the effect might be a relief to the sick man's mind. It's all nonsense, of course, he said to himself, but he went one night, just the same, dug up the limb, relieved it of its wrapping, turned it over in the box, and buried the grewsome thing again, thinking the next morning he would tell his brother all about it. The first thing his brother said to him when he saw him was 'Something queer happened last night.' 'What was that?' 'Well, you know what I have been telling you about my buried limb, how aw- fully it ached, and how it felt as if something was pressing upon it. Well, just about 10 o'clock last night, when the thing was aching its worst, I all at once felt a relief. The pain was completely gone, and I have not felt it since. "The brother was astonished beyond ex- pression. It was just exactly five minutes before 10 o'clock on the night previous that he had changed the position of the buried limb, and he had not told a living soul of what he had done. Rather curious, isn't it ?" What Tommy Thought. Tommy passed the parlor door just as his sister and her lover were concluding a con- ference about something, overhearing the remark "will put our heads together and see what we can do." Entering the library he heard his father remark of the spooning pair, "They're a crack-brained couple, any way." "Guess they're all mended now, pop," said Tommy, "'cause I just heard 'em say they'd put their heads together."

A very simple apparatus for obtaining as electric spark is made by a German physic st. Around the centre of a common lam chimney is pasted a strip of tinfoil, and an other strip from one end of the chimney to within a quarter of an inch of this ring. Their piece of silk is wrapped around a brush and the interior is rubbed briskly. In the dark a bright electric spark may be seen to pass from one piece of tinfoil to the other each time the brush is withdrawn from the chimney. Annual Convention of National Educa- tional Association. The Annual Convention of the National Educational Association of the United States for the present year will be held at Toronto, Canada, and as it will on this occasion be of an international character, it promises to be the most successful meeting of the series. Most of the Railroads have agreed to give half-rates, plus $2.00 membership fee to all who attend the metting, this rate being open to the public generally as well as the Teachers. Toronto people are making great preparations to welcome and intertain the visiting leachers, and numerous cheap ex- cursions are being arranged to all important points on the great Lakes, the St. Lawrence, and the sea-side, after the Convention, which will afford to Teachers the best opportunity for enjoying their summer holidays they have ever had. The official Bulletin, con- taining programme for the meeting, railway arrangements, and all other particulars, is ready, and will be sent free to any desiring it, on their dropping a Post Card to Mr. H. J. Hill, Secretary Local Committee, Toronto

articles.full_text: The Ontario Legislature have voted as increase in the salary of the Premier of $2,000 and $1,400 to the leader of the Opposition. A motion to increase the i demnity of individual members from six hundred to eight hundred dollars was withdrawn, on the grounds of unconstitu tionality. Hor. Mr. Mowat and Mr. Meredith have declined to accept an increase in salary. Commenting on the speeches that were made in the House of Commons on the occasion of Mr. White's appointment to the Speakership, the Empire correspond- ent comments as follows : Sir John's ad- dress, while paying a high and just tri- bute to the abilities and qualifications of his nominee, was purely formal in its character. It indicated nothing beyond the fact that the Ministerial party had selected a candidate, and one worthy of the position. Not so with the leader of the Opposition. Hon Mr. Laurier spoke gracefully, but through all his well turu- ed sentences ran a tone of bitterness, and perhaps a ring of defiance. The manner of delivery, more than the words them . mana auttina selves-though tome of these were cutting enough-justify the impression that this session will not be a peaceful one; that brotherly love and forbearance are not to be cardinal points in the Grit doctrine for the next few months; and here it may be said that this morning an intention ex- isted to divide the House on the Speak- eiship. It was known that the British Columbia and a part of the Northwest dole at ous had been d ay d by a la d slide on the C. P. R. West. It was at o e time thought they could not reach Ottawa to day, and the chance to snap a vote was eagerly seized upon. But the scheme ended in disappointment. The C. P. R. rushed a special through on fast time, the members came in during on damed mak the forenoon, and Mr. Laurier dared not force a division on a square Issue; but the respite is not for long. The Grit polic. is frankly announced to be one of ob struction in so many words. Exasperated at their defeat in March, they mean to be an opposition in deed as well as in name; a factious opposition for opposition's sake Afeaucus has already been called. The Grits will meet at ten o'clock to morrow morning, and the means to be adopted in opposing the address to the throne will then be decided upon. The new Speaker made one of the neat est speeches it is possible to imagine. He said just enough, and said it in a tone that justified the inference that in this Parliament, as in the pasr, the debates of with firm the House will be controlled with mill ness as well as with impartiality. Hints from the Dairy Commission. We cull the following from the annual report of the dairy commissioner for the Dominion, issued a short time ago, for the consideration and benefit of those of our readers who are interested in dairy pro- ducts:

articles.headline: PROFIT AND LOSS
articles.full_text: PROFIT AND LOSS I would like also to lay down this propos ition and make it clear, namely, that men who farm for profit should concern them- selves far more with getting profit by re ducing cost, than by trying to raise the market price. There is only one way in all the world whereby a man can raise for himself with certainty and equity, the market price of anything he sells, and that is by improving its quality. The quality governs to every man the price he may obtain. I will give you an illustra- tion. In all the large cities of the Do- minion butter ranges from 10 to 25 cents a pound. Now, no single farmer, and no combination of farmers can force the but ter market up or down. If it is forced up too much, then the butter that would otherwise go abroad is kept at home : if it is forced down the butter is sent abroad. Thus we cannot influence the market price. But any man can raise himself from being a ten-cent-a-pound-man, by sending to the market just the bulter for which the people will pay to cents. A man can change his place on the scale any time, by improving the quality of his pro- duct to that of superior excellence. Men are always looking for profit at the mark- et end, instead of the home end of their business; and being mistaken in the di- rection of their effort, they have small success. It is folly to keep your cow for six months without getting any pay and then come down on her in the spring and say "You have got to pay for your board or get out." I would have the cow make me a weekly offering, as the churches commend. Most of the churches have good business tact and are managed by men of good sense, and if they had more of it they would be appreciated more than Of I dilet modice of ablacement they are. A man will give a dollar a week to his church when nothing would would induce him to give $50 at one time. Make the cow give a weekly offering. A cow will give more milk if her milking season commences in October than if it begins between March and May. If a cow calves in March or April, when the cold weather comes in the fall she dries up anyway, and therefore boards on the man during the winter too long without paying for her keep. Butter is dearer in autumn and winter; skim milk is worth more, and if our cows generally calved in the fall we would be able to largely de- velop our export trade in dairy products. Butter made in the winter time is worth more and keeps longer; and calves grown at the time are more vigorous and can be attended to more conveniently, as they come at a time when the farmer has leis- ure to devote himself to stock-ras n; practises.

articles.headline: LINES,
articles.full_text: LINES, Written on the death of Johnie Grant, who died April 24th, 1891, by his cousin, M. A. Richardson. The Saviour called Johnnie to his home, He heard the gentle voice, We need not wish him back again. For he has gone with angels to rejoice. He used to appear once fresh and fair, Among the youthful crowds. But now behold he's dead and cold. And shrou is around him fold. His cheeks were once like rotes spread. His sparkling eyes so gay, but now we see that he is gone, He could no longer stay, The parents also mourn their loss, Of one they loved so dear, Weep not for Johnie, loving friends, He could stay no longer here. A few short years of trials pass, We reach the shining shore, Where death divided friends at last, Shall meet to part no more. Such holy love inflamed his breast, He would not seek on earth to rest, But strong in faith and patience trod, The narrow way that leads to God.

articles.headline: TENDERS.
articles.full_text:
TENDERS. SEALED TENDERS addressed to the under-
signed, and endorsed" Tender for Indian Supplies," will be received at this office up to noon on Saturday, 9th May, 1891, for the de- livery of Indian Supplies, during the fiscal year ending 39th June, 1892, consisting of Flour, Beef, Bacon, Groceries, Ammunition, Twine, Agricultural Implements. Tools, etc., duty paid, at various points in Manitoba and the North-west Territories. Forms of tender, containing full particulars relative to the Supplies required, dates of de- livery, etc., may be had by applying to the undersigned or to the Indian Office in Winni- peg. Parties may tender for each description of goods (or for any portion of each description of goods) separately or for all the goods call- ed for in the Schedules, and the Department reserves to itself the right to reject the whole or any part of a tender. Each tender must be accompanied by an ac- cepted Cheque in favor of the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, on a Canadian Bank, for at least five percent, of the amount of the tender, which will be forfeited if the party tendering declines to enter into a con- tract based on such tender when called upon to do so, or if he fails to complete the work contracted for. If the tender be not accepted the cheque will be returned, and if a contract be entered into for a part only of the supplies tendered for an accepted cheque for five per cent. of the amount of the contract may be substituted for that which accompanied the tender; the contract security cheque will be retained by the Department until the end of the fiscal year. Each tender must, in addition to the signa- ture of the tenderer, be signed by two sureties acceptable to the Department for the iproper performance of the contract based on his tender. This advertisement is not to be inserted by any newspaper with the authority of the Queen's Printer, and no claim for payment w newspaper not having had such au- thority will be admitted.

articles.headline: CHAPTER II.
articles.full_text: CHAPTER II. When I came down the next mor Aunt Cecilia was already seated at breakfast table. She looked up with a as I came in, and shook her finger at m "You have grown into a sad slugg child," she cried. "I have been down hour. If you had known how fresh th was blowing through the trees, you w not have tain in bed. I can t imagine w the sweet scent comes from that one in the early morning in town." I had no suggestions to make on subject, and so sat down and began breakfast. "Osmond," began aunt hesitatingly, she had watched me for some time in sile "I have thought over what you said night." " Well ?" "It cannot be, my dear boy," she speaking with evident exertion. "I ca tell you why I oppose your wishes; must not ask me." "You have some strong reason." "Naturally, I have, or I should not re what I see you wish so much. Are not the only one I have to love and gratify the whole world?" "But I think I ought to understand objected. "If you have a reason, why tell it to me. You see, aunt, this is a ser matter. It affects my whole life." "It is for that reason I am firm," said more gravely than before. "I k you cannot understand my motives; you must trust me, Osmond. We have co for the first time to one of those differen which will test whether you really love There will be more, but this is one. If can look back on the past, and see grou for confiding in me though you do not und stand what I am doing, all will be well tween us. If not, there is sorrow wait for us both. For both, Osmond; sorer you than for me, probably. - Will you to me, child; will you try to trust me?" "I will try," I answered; and so the s ject dropped for the time, but I was sor dissatisfied with my aunt's rejection of scheme. I was at that age when w the growth of an independent desire to th for one's self there increases also a dislike accept the judgment of others, even of th most loved and trusted. I was bitterly appointed; a sense of injury rankled in I I felt I was being unjustly dealt with; an went about all that day nursing my ind nation. Aunt Cecilia did not allude again to subject, but she seemed aware that the was a cold shadow between us; and I caug her kind eyes more than once studying face with an anxiously appealing expressi which should have brought me to her for at once, but which caused no other feeli in me at the time than one of petulance being watched. Towards evening I took my hat and we out for a walk. I turned towards Westmin ter, and had hardly set my foot upon t bridge when some one coming behind i thrust his arm through mine, and Sinclai voice saluted me. "Hullo! is it you?" I exclaimed. "He did you get here? Is Calthrop in town?" "I have done with Calthrop, he answe ed, shaking his head disdainfully. "T place was unbearable after you had left. How very odd that I should meet you ju at this moment! Five minutes more and would have been too late." "Too late for what?" "Why, to see me !-But tell me, who news you have?" "Bad," I assured him. "My aunt won hear of my entering the navy." "Won't she, by Jove!" Sinclair exclaime "You know I thought you would find diff culties. Why not?" "She won't tell me." "So! And what are you going to do?" I shrugged my shoulders. "What can do? Give in, I suppose." "Oh, if you mean to give in, you may a well do it at once, with a good grace," Sin clair said contemptuously. His tone stung me, and I asked quickly "In my place, what would you do?" "Not give way, certainly. We walked on for some distance in si ence. At last I asked him : "Where are you going now?" "Why that reminds me," he answered "that this is not my way. I am going to i ortanionon. " To Portsmouth?" "Well, why do you look so astonished! I can't go back to Calthrop; I haven't enough meney to stay in town; I am going to my uncle." Then with a sudden pressure of my arm he said: "Come with me, Osmond. My uncle will be able to help you. I know he took a fancy to you, for he told me so." "I don't see how he can help me," I answered. "If my aunt won't consent, she won't, and there the matter must end. I don't see what you want me to do. And how can I go to Portsmouth? I have no money. We had descended the steps beside St. Thomas's Hospital as we spoke, and were paring slowly along the parade which ex- termis before that building. Sinclair sudden- ly stopped, and leaned back against the river wall, thrusting both hands deep into his trouser-pockets. "I am going to walk," he said lightly. "Walk!" I repeated-" walk to Ports- mouth?" "It would take a longer walk than that to exhaust my constitution," he said. "As for yours, of course it is another matter." "If you can do it, I can," I said, rather nettled. "But why not go by train?" "Oh, why not go in a carriage-and-pair, or stretched at full length in an ambulance !" he cried contemptuously. "Because I'm not a girl, nor an old man. Because I want to see the world; because -- Well, there are fifty reasons, and the last is that I want to walk. So if you care to come with me, you may; if not, you may go home and knuckie down to your aunt." What tempted me I do not know; but without another word I thrust my arm through Sinclair's and we turned our faces towards the Westminster Bridge Road again. "You and better send a line to your aunt" Sinclair said, when we reached the top of the steps; "don't frighten the old lady unnecessarily."

To most men it is a for pleasure to feel themselves free to b ust their steps whithersoever they will; t boy, relieved for the first time of restra ub- it is simply an intoxication. ely I often look back upon that morning. my was in some ways the happiest I ever spe ith We walked leisurely through the pleas ink country, straying through field-paths, wh e to the reapers were already cutting the ea ose grain; lingering beneath shady trees w lis- the heat was at its greatest; talking alw ne. of the life we meant to lead, and seeing dI fore us a long vista of glarious successes The man to tonic 1 rance of Kini tong purchases ig- distinctions, at the end of which we sho be laid to rest in St. Paul's or in the Abb he leaving behind us a worthy menument in ere deeds. ght We plodded into Godalming late in my afternoon, and had some tea in a confection on er's shop. I should ha ent liked to rest in Godalming for the nigl ns- but Sinclair had evidently no intention he doing so, and I did not venture to sugge ne it. r's | The light-heartedness of the morning w almost gone now; and we walked on sile w ly enough, both more weary than we cho to admit. The sky became overcast; it w er. | unbearably sultry; from time to time a fe he heavy drops of rain splashed in the thi _ dust; and low thunder rumbled in the d st | tance. We left the main road at last, an it | turned into a byway which we were assure would bring us out upon the Portsmou coach road. The path led through this woods until it descended to the banks of at little stream, over which a rustic bridge w thrown. Sinclair cast himself down on the 't green bank with a heavy sigh of relief an bending over the rippling water, drank h d fill, and washed the dust and perspiration i- from his face. "This is hot work, eh, Osmond?" he said brushing away the water from his hair. "It will be cooler soon, I suppose." "I shall stay here until it is, at anyrate, s | Sinclair answered; and with that he lai a ministen comfortably against the roots an fell asleep. I had an idea that whilst h : | slept I ought to remain awake, and I trie valiantly to conquer my fatigue; but ver shortly all things round me became indis . | tinct ; and I lost consciousness in the mids of a vision of Aunt Cecilia shedding cool let tuce leaves for supper in the pleasant shad parlor of the old house. I was roused by Sinclair, who shook me , violently. "Wake, Osmond; wake up," he cried. "We have slept so long that the day has gone and the moon is up. Rouse yourself, my boy; it is cool enough now." I rose with some difficulty. My limb were cramped and chilled; and I felt hardly less tired than when I had lain down; but Sinclair seemed full of energy. He strode forward hastily on the road. I did not mean to admit that I was nearly exhausted so I set my teeth and followed him. We plodded along the dusty highway for two or three miles, hearing scarcely any sound but that of our own feet, for the country was marvellously still. The road began to rise at last; and we found ourselves on a steep ascent. "This must be Hindhead," Sinclair said. "I know the Portsmouth road crosses it." I had never heard of Hindhead; but at that instant I saw, upon the slope of a vast hollow on the right of the road, a little hut or shelter for cattle. "Sinclair, I can't go much farther," I said. "We cannot walk all night. Let us sleep there." "You do look pumped out," he said good-naturedly. "And I am tired too .- Well, we will try that hut. The door was open, and mone corner were several bundles of clean straw. We spread the straw a little, and lying down on it, were soon asleep. After some hours of troubled rest I woke with a start. The door of the hut was half open, as we had left it when we lay down, and the bright moonlight streaming through the opening reached almost to the straw on which we lay. I do not know how long I had slept-perhaps a couple of hours; but I was wide awake now, for the restlessness of extreme fatigue had seized on me, and I moved uneasily from side to side, seeking ease in vain. The broad band of light across the floor disquieted me, and drew my legs towards it in spite of myself. At last I rose, and moving quietly, so as not to dis- turb Sinclair, I went to the door of the hut. A light wird had risen, which refreshed me,

articles.headline: (TO BE CONTINUED).
articles.full_text: (TO BE CONTINUED). A Heroic Lady. A terrible fever epidemic of a most viru- lent type is raging in the Reynoyle district of Clifden Union. Dr. Macdonnell, the officer, a gentleman at all times remarkable for devoted attention to his poor patients, has caught the infection, and is now in ex- treme danger from what Professor Rye, of Galway, pronounces to be unmistkable typhus fever. Four, six, and in one instance eight members of the same family have been stricken down. In one cabin there has been a frightful instance of six human beings and four head of cattle huddled together in one room in a revolting condition of filth. Vet.

"Like many admirable people," writes 3 correspondent, "our Biddy had but one 9 fault. She was tidy, honest and obliging 9 but she would put kerosene on the fire * Her mistress had remonstrated in vain, and . 1 6 one morning entered the kitchen in time to see her with the oil-can tilted at a danger ) ous angle over a grate where there was still . a few sparks. " 'Now, Biddy, stop at once!' cried she, ) idignantly. "How often have I told you not to use a drop of oil on the fire?" "'Oh, sure, ma'am,' said Biddy, as she reluctantly set down the can, "it niver yet  did anybody harm." "There are accidents every day from the careless use of kerosene. " 'Ah, yis, ma'am, but not when a body's careful like me! But folks is that afraid of having it used! Why, Mrs. Windsor, at me last place, locked up the can fer fear I'd get at it! I remember that morning well, for we'd all had a bit of a fright." "Why were you frightened?" " Well, ye see, ma'am, that mouning I'd put on a dhrop too much, and it blew all ove covers off, and split the fire- board ! "The Obnoxious Mother-in-Law." . There is great deal of truth and common sense in Nellie Burns' article yet there is ssia no doubt that the obnoxious mother-in-law ced does exist in certain conditions, just as cer- the tain surroundings render fathers and moth- ers, brothers and sisters obnoxious. fter | Much of the trouble of this world might ert, be averted if each newly-married couple would begin life by themselves in a home of at their own. The home need not be a palace, . nor even a large sized farm house, but it should be under the exclusive control of the ow oocupants. I have known the friendship the between mother-in-law and daughter-in-law the to be broken forever by the mistake of try- aly ing to make two families into one, when had they dwelt in their respective homes they might always have lived on terms of be have the same methods of work un'ess ist they have been brought up together, and it is hard indeed for a mother—an accomplish- ny ed housekeeper-when her son brings home e, his inexperienced wife and installs her at the head of the houes. It the head of the houses, who, however hard she the daughter-in-law, who, however hard she may strive to please, is sure to fall short of ner experienced mother-in-law's ideal in the m- administration of the house. Fault-finding in begins, and the prospect of happiness is er blighted forever. Again, the children are a never-failing source of strife. Naturally, the line source of strife. Naturally, the like to undertake their training, but the like to undertake their training, but the r. severity on one day and indulgence the next, er the result being a family of spoiled children who will make wretched, not only themselv. is es, but all with whom they may come in y, | contact ot If there must be a mother-in-law in one'r n family it might better be the mother of the wife than of the husband, as the latter is out of the house the greater part of the time, and the daughter ought surely to be able to live in peace with her own mother. Yet, l y have known conditions of this kind under which life did not seem to be at all rose

articles.headline: colored. Indeed, I have noticed households
articles.full_text: colored. Indeed, I have noticed households wherein it was necessary to the peace of the family, for the wife to stand constantly between her mother and her husband. If she wished to go away for a week, the situation appeared as problemati- e cal as the old familiar puzzle involving the , man, the fox and the goose. The principal trouble, I fancy, arises from the tendency of the wite to repeat to her mother the story of any little difference that occurs between the married couple. The confidence of a I third party in such a case is always fatal to happiness. The dearest, most sensible mother-in-law that I ever observed wishedher sons to marry early in life (many mothers selfishly prevent the marrriage of their sons) and settle in homes of their own She attended a ... one of cherr own. Due accended scrupu- lously to her own affairs, believing her sons and daughters-in-law to be fully capable of managing their business. She always receiv- ed them cordially at her own home, and was ever kind and generous towards them. The result was a measure of devotion such as is seldom accorded to a mother or mother-in- law. But this mother was not dependent upon her sons or their wives for care or sup- port -- a condition which ought to exist in the life of every aged mother, but which un- fortunately is rare. articles.headline: HEALTH.
articles.full_text:
HEALTH. Poisoned by Cne's Breath When we breathe over and over again the same air, we gradually vitiate it by the con- stant exhalation of carbonic acid, which gradually brings the air up to the point where the difference between it and the blood—as regards the proportions of car- bonic acid-disappears. The blood ceases to be arterialised, and the vital functions are arrested. In vain does the air still con- tain a quantity of life-giving oxygen; the blood cannot take it up, because it cannot get rid of its carbonic acid; the conditions of exchange are absent. To place an animal in air overcharged with carbonic acid, is equivalent to a gradual prevention of his breathing at all. Suffocation results from vitiation of the air in precisely the same manner as from interception of the air. Professor Brown Sequard has recently been making experiments to determine whether the human breath was capable of producing any poisonous effects. From the condensed watery vapor of the expired air he obtained a poisonous liquid which, when injected under the skin of rabbits, produced almost immediate death. He ascertained that this poison was an alkaloid, and not a microbe. The rabbits thus injected died without convulsions, the heart and large blood vessels being engorged with blood. M. Brown-Sequard considers it fully proved that the expired air, both of man and animals, contains a volatile poisonous principle which is much more deleterious than the carbonic it contains. In the reign of King George II., the Rajah af Bengal took some English prisoners in Calcutta, and put 146 of them into a place which has been known since the Indian Mutiny as the "Black Hole." This place was only 18 feet square by 16 feet high, and ventilation was provided for only by two small grated windows out of reach of all. One hundred and twenty-three of the pris- oners died in the night, and most of the sur- vivers were afterwards carried off by putrid fever, due to the fetid atm sphere caused by so many human breaths. Some Not Weather Precepts. Comfort in summer depends almost as much on the food and drink that are taken into the system as on the clothing. If a man is careful about his diet, in particular about what he drinks, he may be reasonably com- fortable in summer, though he sits around all day with a silk hat, a tight-fitting collar, and frock coat. The unpleasant sensations of a hot day come as well from inside the body as outside. The feeling of parching thirst in the throat is more uncomfortable than the direct rays of the sun. The feeling that a man has eaten something that does not agree with him, or has had too many cold drinks, causes greater discomfort than torrents of perspiration. To be comfortable there must be an equilibrium between the interior apparatus of the body and the ex- ternal conditions and circumstance. No man who eats and drinks carelessly on a hot day will have this comfortable poise. A mistake many men make is not to drink until they are thirsty and not to drink anything at all cool until they are hot. A man may get up in the morning and feel fairly comfortable; he will eat his breakfast and drink but little. When he gets to his work it will be warmer and he will be warmer; he will then drink beer, soda water, lemonade, or ice water. In a little while he will be thirstier and he will drink some more of the same. From this time on as the thermometer rises he will become hotter and thirstier. It is not that he has not taken enough fluid to quench any amount of thirst, but that the fluid was not taken until he was thirsty and therefore does not quench his thirst at once. Eating satisfies hunger almost at once, but the food is not taken into the system for several hours, until the digestion and assimilation are completed. It is so with thirst even more than with hunger. Thirst is a local feeling, but it means that there is not enough water in the system. Pouring water down the throat puts water into the stomach, but not into the system for some time afterward, particularly if the water is cold. Coffee and tea quench thirst more rapidly when they are hot than when they are cold, be- cause they are assimilated more quickly. Then after the victim of the heat is loaded up with cold water he begins to perspire more freely. This means that he has put into himself more water that his system de- mands that the heat and is overloaded sys- tem combined are working it off. As the perspiration trickles down his face he goes and takes more drinks, and so keeps the un- comfortable round until night, when he tosses around damp and uncomfortable. In the same way that a short run exhausts a man's breath and makes dim sweat more than a song leisurely walk, so a number of iced drinks poured in rapidly tire a man more and make him sweat more than a mod- erate amount of fluids taken at long inter- vals of time, The best time to drink is in the morning. The stomach is empty and the fluids will be carried through the sys- tem and into the blood more speedily. A pint of moderately cool water then will do more to relieve thirst during theday then ten glasses of beer or soda water in the after- noon. A man is somewhat like a locomotive if the water is not judiciously administered to the boiler there is an explosion. The time to lay in the supply of fluids is before the man starts for the day. If he wants to more he may drink it terry minute and minute the series and slowly, and should not have it so cold that it will inflame the throat and the stomach and make them warmer. A cold bath makes the skin glow with warmth. So a cold bath of ice water in its reaction warms the throat and stomach. Medicinal Qualities of Foods. The medicinal properties of some foods are as definite as their nutritive, and as re- liable as those of drugs; indeed, the phar-
maccpæia includes the following so-called foods in its list of official drugs; asparagus, cabbage, carrots, dandelion, endive, garlic Indian-corn, leeks, lettuce, mushrooms, parsnips, sweet-potatoes, sorrel, sea-weeds, tomatoes, the cereals, spices, sweet herbs, sugar, honey molasses, the various berries, the only nuis, animaliats, eggs, oysters, many kinds of fish, nearly all fruits and their jellies and their juices, the wines, cordials, and spirits, the condiments, and salt especi- ally, without which life is insipid indeed. In their order the dietetic qualities of the condiments will be considered, and the special 强逐升图 action of various foods in connection with the receipts given for preparing them. Just as common salt is indespensible to

articles.headline: Untitled Snippet
articles.full_text: the health of cattle, the salts of potash pres- ent in vegetables and fruit are important to man. The good health of many vegetarians is due to this substance. The cookery of vegetables largely affects their dietetic value, and mistresses should instruct their cooks as to the proper ways of treating these important foods. In the first place the most strict attention should be'paid to cleansing them thoroughly from dust, sand, and injurious worms and insects; careful washing in plenty of cold salted water, with a brush or cloth, will suffice for roots, and careful examination of the leaves of succulent plants; the latter should be left blossom end down in enough salted hour. This will generally destroy all parasite life, so that the small creatures will fall of their own weight to the bottom of the water, unless enfolded between the leaves; therefore cabbage, lettuce, etc., should be carefully inspected before cooking. Soft water in cooking will so far soften the tis- sues of vegetables as to extract much of their juices and valuable salts, unless salt is added to it; and the boiling of peeled vege- tables withdraws much of their potash, the value of which we shall presently see. French cooks, having first thoroughly clean- sed them, will save the water in which they have been boiled for sauces and soups. We would suggest moderate salting, and then hava the water used in making the white sauce usually served with vegetables.

articles.headline: VITAL STATISTICS.
articles.full_text: VITAL STATISTICS. Interesting Particulars of the Three Great Ruman Events, Birth, Marriage and Death. The report relating to the registration of births, marriages and deaths in the Province of Ontario for the year 1889 has just been issued. It is a most elaborate and exhaust- ive one and contains many interesting figures. For instance, the total registrations made during the year amounted to 86,747, composed of 48,538 births, 14,880 marriages and 23,329 deaths. Compared with the registrations made during 1583, the births show an increase of 1585, the marriages an increase of 329, and the deaths a decrease of 405, making a total increase in 1889 of 1509. The proportion of the total registrations to every 1000 living was 40.3. In England there were 56.7 per 1000, in Scotland 45 per 1000 and in Michigan, a state similar in population to Ontario, 41.9 per 1000. The highest birth rates were in the counties of Carleton, 36.4 per 1000, York 36.4, Waterloo 32.4 and Prescott and Rus- sell 31.3. The male births in the province numbered 24,737, the females 23,801, an excess of 936 male births, showing a pro- portion of 103.5 males to 100 females. There was a small increase in the number of twin births registered. Three cases of triplets were returned in 1889, the same number as in 1888. They occurred, one in the County of Peterboro and one in the County of York.

articles.headline: SCORES MADE BY THE CHURCHES.
articles.full_text: SCORES MADE BY THE CHURCHES. Of the 10 500 hirthe during the year 958  Of the 45,000 births during the year, ooo or 2 per cent. were illegitimate. In 1888 the percentage was 1.3. Of the 29,760 per- sons married, 9920 were Methodists; 6022 were Presbyterians; 5041 were Episcop- alians and 4136 Roman Catholics. If mar- riage is a faiture, the Methodists won't pay ten cents on the dollar. The report shows that there are certain months which are generally chosen for tying the nuptial knot. October, December and January are still the favorite months, especially December, which heads the list with 1753 weddings. This fact may perhaps be explained by a gentle insinuation that Christmas and wed- ding presents might be considered one and the same. In August there were only 913 weddings. A temperature of 90° in the shade may drive a man to a quiet watering place which sports four German bands, but it evidently can't drive him to marriage. The number of males married under the age of 20 was 259 and females 2583. Over 20 spoony old gents tod- dled to the altar with the weight of three score and ten years, and 29 prim old ladies decided that at 70 they were "sufficiently decayed" to ask mamma's consent. Only two brides were older than their bridegrooms, one was 82 years old and the bridegroom 62 years, the other was 70 years and the bride- groom 61 years. The united ages of the old- est couple married in 1889 was 148 years. The bridegroom was 81 years and the bride 67. Four persons were married at 80 years of age and over, three males and one female. Nine girls of 14 years of age united them- selves to youths under 19 years and 30 girls were married at 16 years of age.

articles.headline: THE MARRIAGE MONTH.
articles.full_text: THE MARRIAGE MONTH. The youngest couple married was a girl of 14 years of age to a youth of 18 years. One old gentleman of 79 is credited with captur- ing a maiden of bashful 15. The sturdy set- tlers of Haliburton district are credited with being the most generative, the rate of births per 1000 of population being 41.3. The Frenchmen of Essex seem to be most thoroughly convinced of the advantages of marriage, and head the list with 14.7. York is second with 11.6. The death rate is high- est in Haliburton, and York is again second.

articles.headline: There were 1045 more births in Toronto in
articles.full_text: There were 1045 more births in Toronto in '86 than in '88, 188 more marriages and 93 more deaths. It would seem that man has a decided penchant for appearing on this busy scene during July, August and September, in time for ice-cream and mosquitoes. There were over 1000 more births in September,

The death rate to 100 of popu- lation in Toronto was 18.3, the lowest for many years. Phthisis claims more victims than any other disease, but pneumonia, diphtheria and nervous diseases each reap large harvests. The list of centenarians who died during 1889 is as follows: Jane Campbell, aged 102, Dufferin county; Margaret Menard, 100, Elizabeth Mooney, 103, Elgin; Sarah Thomp son, 109, Essex; Sarah Ann Griffith, 100, Frontenac; John Scott, 105, Haliburton; Margaret Phillips, 102, Anne McPhail, 100, Mary Martin, 105, Huron; John Blue, 100, Kent; James Doherty, 101, Lambton; Henry McVeigh, 100, Lanark; John Vaughan, 105, ile . articles.full_text:
The Cunard steamer Aurania arrived at Queenstown at midnight on Sunday from New York, having been delayed for 24 hours over her usual time by a disarrangement of her machinery. On Friday morning she shipped a heavy sea, ane a young man named David Gibson, of Dundee, in endeavouring to avoid it, fell over the starboard rail into the sea and was drowned. A boat could not be launched to rescue him owing to the heavy sea running at the time. A Paris telegram says :- Veys, a shoemak er, suddenly strangled his mistress, Mathilde
Hinque, as she was bending over to embrace him on Saturday morning. He then went out and gave himself up to the police, stat- ing that he had intended to poison himself carefully with a strong dose of salts of sor- sant failed rel and petroleum, but that his near laned him at the last moment. He had no fault to find with Mathilde Hinque, and his brain is supposed to have been affected by sun- stroke, from which he had suffered in Mada- gascar. The loneliest man in Europe is Herr Peter Lechner, who is connected with the Weather- Bureau service, and is stationed on the top of the Schonnblick Mountains, in the Aus- trian Alps. There he lives month in and month out, engaged in noting the meteor- ological changes in the highest station in Europe. It is the custom of the villagers on Christmas day to cut their way through the snow-clad valley and up the mountain, carrying presents to the lonely observer. This is the only time throughout the year that Peter Lechner sees a human face. The langua of India have a natron gaint The repers of Thora have a pation same- Piz Johanyan-to whose shrine near Muzaf- fargarh, in Lindh, pilgrimages are now being made. After innumerable prayers to the saint the pilgrims smear themselves with lampblack from his tomb, and the natives declare that cures often result from this treatment. A leper colony resides round the shrine, and the sufferers mix with their neighbors, none of whom have—so it is aver- red-ever been known to contract the disease. A Vienna telegram says :- News received from Parndorf, near Pressburg, states that all the horses in two stables there had to be killed on account of an outbreak of glanders among them. The veterinary surgeon and two farmers to whom the animals belonged were wounded in carrying out this necessary measure, blood poisoning ensuing in all three cases. The veterinary surgeon died last night, and no hope is entertained of the recovery of the two farmers. During a performance at the Bouffe Thea- tre, Paris, on Sunday evening, one of the audience raised a cry of fire. A terrible panic was the result, and a rush was made for the doors. The manager, however, at once came forward and announced that the alarm of fire was unfounded. The audience thereupon became reassured, and after a short interval the performance was resumed. Brother Anselm, who has just died monk and porter at the Monastery of La Grande Chartreuse, had been M. de Bre- court, once well-known in the best Parisian society. M. de Brecourt on coming home from shooting one day fired into a thicket, behind which his daughter happened to be standing, and killed her. In despair he entered La Grande Chartreuse, where he ended his days. The Warsaw papers report that the Vis- tula, having burst its ice, has risen inordin- arily high this spring and overflown the towns and villages lying on its borders. It carried away whole houses and barns on its course to the Baltic Sea. The Polish pea- sants of the inundated districts were depriv- ed of almost all their fowl, which constitutes one of the principal lines of their farming. Chickens and turkeys were drowned by the millions, and whole flocks of ducks and geese were carried off by the high waters. The papers of Kiev Russia report that there is a perfect standstill in the trade of grain in the whole region of the southwest. There is no demand for Russian grain in the foreign market, and prices are so low that farmers would not sell their stock unless they are compelled by the direct necessity. In the Government of Kiev itself almost every line of business depends on the grain trade, and since the latter is at a standstill there is no activity in any department of commerce. The commander of the St. Petersburg police force has issued an order that all Jew- ish stores and business houses should have signs with the names, patronymics, and families of the proprietors written in large showy letters. The cause of this new order, which is the nearest approach to the mediæ- val regulation by which Jews were compelled to wear yellow patches on their garments, is that merchants of the Hebrew taith do not write their names plainly on their signs, in order to avoid the too frequent intrusion of official extortionists and the prejudice of the unreasonable masses. The temperance movement which was re- cently introduced in Russia leads to some very amusing incidents. Listok of Saratov reports the following: Three peasants of the village of Potrovsk pledged themselves not to taste any liquor during the Lent season. The one who should break his pledge made himself liable to a fine of twenty-five rubles or to receive twenty lashes on his naked body. Not many days passed before two of the company found their third associate drink- ing vodka in a grog shop. They required him to pay his fine or submit to the lashing. The former he could not do because he had no money, so he had to accommodate him- self to the latter. He was stripped naked and lashed. But in their ardor his com- panions in the temperance cause forget the count, and administered to him more than the twenty blows that were due him. He calmly put on his clothes after the operation, and claimed that now his companions had broken their pledge, giving him more blows than their agreement had called for. The people assembled in the inn recognized the justice of his claims and adjudged his com- panions to pay their fines or to submit to the same chastisement as he. One of them submitted, and received his twenty blows without a murmur. The other one pre- ferred to pay his fine. Since their agreement had been broken already his 25 rubles were spent on vodka, by which half the village got reeling drunk. 192-275-2078 19-255 A snapper up of unconsidered trifles-a fondling asylum. The European Anarchists are busy mak- ing preparations for their May-day meetings, and are distributing fiery circulars in Paris, Vienna, and Madrid. All outdoor demon- strations will be prohibited.

articles.full_text: The Song of the Bacilli. Once I flourished unmolested, now my trouble never cease Man, investigating monster, will not let me res in peace.
